Beware of the tour guide. The building is well worth a visit but the tour guide was very rude. I know she had a job to do and several of the crowd did not listen when she gave her pre tour instructions but there are better ways of dealing with it than being rude and emit people. If you want to take photos you have to buy a separate pass, this was not mentioned when we bought our tickets. I had bought the guide book so had no need to take photos but was accused of doing so and made to feel like a naughty child. The areas outside the tour are very impressive especially the American Bar and less formal restaurant.
When inPrague- "do" at least one concert. This is such a lovely building that houses concerts and exhibits. We found that the overall quantity and quality of concerts in Prague was outstanding !

Municipal house. Wandered in here by accident and stayed for an hour or so. In saying that we were in Pragues oldest pub, Down the stairs to the restaurant/pub area and get a meal/drink and be entertained. The day we were there ended up in a party atmosphere with a man and woman on an accordion and double bass singing everything from german beer hall songs to wartime songs. Brilliant afternoon. Would recommend a visit just to see the bar. Oh and they do tours of the municipal hall itself if you can tear yourself away from the bar.

Old world charm. My husband and I attended a concert at the Municipal House Smetana Hall while visiting Prague. The achestics of the hall are wonderful. It is an old-world music hall, decorated in the fashion one can expect,with tall painted ceilings and marble walls and floors. The musicians were of a high calibre and the music was made even more enjoyable being in this wonderful venue.

Excellent Venue. Program was Four Seasons. String instruments consisted of 7 violinists, 3 bass fiddles.Guest violinists was Radana Vectomova. Excellent program. Sold out crowd. We bought our tickets at the Hotel.

Endless amazement. Do not miss a visit hear and be ready to be wowed, tours are available 2nd floor full tour well worth the money. Basement American Bar great coffe stop try to rest a while in one of the two small booths, if the weather is fine sit and people watch from the pavement side cafe.Return in the evening for a great meal in the basement restraunts and just drink in the atmosphere in amazing surroundings.

"Four Seasons" at The Municipal House Hall. We were so glad that we decided to attend a chamber orchestra performance of Vivaldi's "Four Seasons." The auditorium was beautiful and the music delightful!
Great memories.. A spectacular building that offers a great selection of concerts. There are restaurants offering a wide range of meals on the ground floor.

Czech Art Nouveau. This masterpiece is home to concert halls and cafes. The Art Nouveau architecture is stunning to see, especially the stained glass atrium. They offer a one-hour tour however we didn't do this.
Interesting but not much to see. Unless you're here for a show, there's not a lot to look at here just as a sightseer. They let you nose about for free though, which is nice.
beautiful architecture. A wonderful, amazing and aesthetic structure to study ,especially for people who enjoy the historical architectures.
I hour Interior Tour. Art Nouveau Masterpiece. Remarkable architectural and Interior design/decoration tour. Must see for architectural buffs.

Be aware!. It´s a very beautiful place, BUT they sell tickets to music performances in smaller rooms of the theatre without make this clear to the customers. They won´t lie to you, but they will let you think in whatever you think you´re buying. When I was there, there were lots of people really disappointed about a concert they believed it would be in the main room, with the main orchestra and it was in a very small room, close to the restaurant, performed by the chamber orchestra. "Nothing wrong about the music." a customer said, but it was not what she expected. So, my advice is: if you want to be in the theater's mais room, it´s name is SMETANA HALL. Any other name refers to smallest rooms.

Hidden gem you must go (great photography). Fantastic place to visit and a must seenot highlighted in the tour guidesThis art deco building was the best thing on our Prague visitit has two restaurants a cafe and a barwe had a coffee in the cafe near the entrance which was good and luch in the basement.you can see some of it if you go in but i would recommend going on the tourPhotographers remember to buy a permitThe rooms they take you through are amazingCant recommend it enough
Concert. Went there to watch a vivaldi concert the four seasons.definetly worth going. Always lovely concerts playing to add culture to your prague experience.

A feast for the eyes and music for the ears!. We went to a concert in the the incredibly beautiful Smetana Hall. Well worth it. If you're only in Prague for a few days check online to see if there's anyone interesting playing here.

Like visiting a different era well worth a visit. We went to the basement restaurant it was like being transported back to the 1920/30sIt was as if it was in a time warp, the walls were tiled, and whole layout was pretty unique, our party of 4 sat in a small booth. The waiters were dressed very smartly complete with long aprons. We only had a basic meals with a bottle of wine, and we felt the price was very reasonable . After the meal the Maitre D'hôtel came and explained the bill to us.

When you see it you will know it great art nouveau building.. Prague tourist maps arent always the most accurate and when we got out the subway we couldnt find this place so we asked a tourist information guide who emphatically pointed down the road and told us to go around the corner because when you see it you will know it. Even amongst Prague's many spectacular buildings there was no missing this building.Inside was spectacular and it would equal any art nouveau building I have seen.The best option is to take the straight tour. Some are in English so best to ring up and check the time of these tours. There are other options but they are not worth the money in my opinion. If you do the tour and want to photograph then you need a photographc license which costs 50 crowns ( approx 2 euros). Well worth paying for if you like to photograph and can be bought when you buy your ticket.The tour takes you through at least 7 rooms all spectacularly done out.We thoroughly enjoyed the tour.The address is Náměstí Republiky 5.

Hidden depths inside!. Amazing art deco building which is worth spending some time within. We ended up eating in the bistro/cafe for lunch which although expensive by Prague standards, it was worth it for the location. The interior of the Hall is amazing, but I have to say, the ladies toilets in the restaurant are absolutely incredible! Check out the art deco details - wonderful!
good place. I didn't have enough time to visit inside but from the outside view i really liked it, nice views from different directions and also you can people around

Great restaurants, fascinating side rooms, terrific local art store, strongly recommended. For many reasons, this should be one of the 5 top places to visit in Prague. The informal restaurant on the first (main) floor is beautiful, and has terrific, modestly priced food. The American bar in the basement, as well as the more traditional Czech restaurant, are distinctive & worth seeing, whether you eat there or not. The "side rooms" are stunning and distinctive, with remarkable art including frescoes & stained glass, that you can visit via a guided tour. The art store - located down a short hall from the front entrance, has extremely well done, modestly priced to expensive jewelry, art, toys and other things, many of which you can not find in the souvenir shops. Whether you simply walk around or buy, this is a very high quality shop.The main hall, site of music and other productions, is nice and is the site of frequent productions. The building is located on one of the city's major squares, easily accessible via public transportation and from many hotels. When you consider all that's available in this one building, I'd urge visitors to make this one of the first places to visit in Prague.

Interesting building with a unique, great pastry shop.. This is a very interesting art deco building that hold concerts We had a tour, but things and names seemed to blur after a while. I don't think one would just wander into the building without a planned tour. The coffee/pastry shop on the ground floor was terrific. They had a small band playing for entertainment. Definitely stop in here for pastries and a drink.

lots of different eating and entertainment places under one roof. the cocktail bar in the basement is small but good atmosphere and cocktails. trad. czech restaurant in basement too touristic for me. french restuarant on ground floor pricey but worth it. Cafe on ground floor good for people watching. Theatre ornate and spacious. Great architecture iinside and out
Fabulous Art Nouveau. We had a private tour of the Municipal House with our Rick Steves Tour group. Art Nouveau fabulous best describes this place. A must see place when one is visiting Prague.
great place to hang out. what an outstanding building in a very nice square there is a market close by were you can get good value food, drinks and gifts

Amazing Art Nouveau building. We booked a tour of this building and weren't disappointed. The internal rooms are in original condition with an amazing array of furniture and decorations.
Definitely worth doing the tour.
The American Bar in the basement is also a worthwhile stop for a coffee of drink.

Art Nouveau. Municipal House is an Art Nouveau enthusiasts dream. Two great restaurants on the premises, the elegant French Restaurant, and a more casual but beautiful restaurant across the hall. Downstairs there is the American Bar. A concert hall is open in the evenings for concerts that range from the turisty to seriously good music.
Beautiful art nouveau building. If you are I a fiend for beautiful period architecture, this is the place. Free and worth the visit.

What a venue!. This stunning Art Nouveau building will welcome you for a traditional Czech diner. We had a organised group diner in the beer hall in the basement of the building. Good traditional food, great service. But I have to say that the venue steels the show!

Beautiful Art Deco. Despite my review title some may consider the architecture an art nouveau style. I'm not an art aficionado or an architectural expert but the building and the décor are beautiful. We went to the Municipal House for lunch with a large group as part of a tour. While the food in the Pilsen Restaurant was not the best (traditional Czech dishes some of which were hits, some of which were not) the building is beautiful. I wish that we had had more time to explore the building both inside and out.
Classical concert lover hurry. if you happen to be in Prague during concert season, definalty check out the concert schedule and pay a visit, really worth experience

Variety of halls, restaurants and museums under one roof. We heard a lovely chamber music concert here in the large art nouveau hall and ate a wonderful lunch in the folkloric restaurant on the lower level. It has gorgeous wall tiles and an interesting menu with Czech favorites.
Catch a performance if you can. We saw the Bohemian Orchestra perform songs from Hollywood. Great performance and a beautiful baroque building. One of the highlights of our trip

historic place. it's a nice old building that speaks a lot about the history of prague. it houses a nice theatre and 3 very good restaurants. the best, on the street level , is the ''brasserie''... very well decorated.. then, ther are 2 very typical czech restaurants in the basement... with local food and a lot of different beers !!!

First Class. Great building where we enjoyed an hour long concert of Vilvaldi's Four Seasons with a smattering of Mozart. Great cultural experience prior to dinner. The Smetana Hall is a beautiful setting too.

Research who is playing before you book ; terrible acoustics in a historic building. Easy to find in the centre of the Prague old town lies Municipal House. There are several concert halls and orchestras who take to the stage here.To me, the place feels more like a 'tourist attraction'. Buy a ticket, sometimes on the day and sit on a wooden seat surrounded by other tourists. The acoustics themselves are terrible, as others have mentioned and the reverberations destroy the nuances of any decent classical performance.Your experience will vary depending on which orchestra is playing. Be warned, they are not all the same. One of the nights i visited was bad enough I walked out. An amateur performance at best, there was simply no cohesion nor emotion conveyed, with more than several wrong notes. I suppose it also reflects the price, with most tickets under 1000 Koruna. I do however recommend the Czech Philharmonic. They are amongst the world's best 25 orchestras.
This is Prague. This is Prague, at the end of the Street Na Prikope, the Tourist Paradise.You cannot miss this Majestic Hall, excellent place to visit and have a coffee.

Amazing decoration!. Absolutely beautiful building, tours start from 11am and be warned (as with most places in Prague) you will have to buy a photo pass to take photos, but it is worth it. The decoration of each rom is different and each is stunning, look out for the desk which when turned upside down resembles a Morroccan minaret.

See and learn all about the Art Nouveau style and Czech pride.. The tour was given by a very dedicated and enthusiastic guide whose pride in her country made it extra special. The Municipal House, in the Art Nouveau style, was built to showcase the shills of Czech craftspeople. Each room is gorgeous and unique and every detail, from doorknobs to hinges, is beautifully crafted. The stained glass windows are lovely and a wonderful contrast to church windows. Fabrics, wall treatments, furniture etc is magnificent. There was also an exhibit of Art Nouveau clothing, pottery, silver, glass and much more

Perfect acoustic for a classical concert!. The outside building it's impressive, but you must go inside and listen to a classical concert, it's magic..the ceiling, the decoration, the nice way they renovated all, it's a great piece of history. The acoustic in the Hall, is incredible. No microphone...just the sound of the instruments...perfect moment!
take pictures. Although we didn't go in but the place in namesti republic is a nice place to watch from the outside good for pictures
A must see place in Prague. A gorgeous building with a great value restaurant with a laid back atmosphere, my favourite place in Prague

Great buidling but don t attend a concert there. The building in itself is magnificent. The acoustics in the great hall are terrible. There are two floor seatings, A and B ( A being the mosre expensive one). We were seated in zone A and although the orchestra played wonderfully he acoustics were awful. The sound came to us distorted,dim and with echo

Fabulous place. This building is a must for lovers of art nouveau. The entire place is an absolute gem. Every part of the internal fixtures and fittings reflects the skill, craftsmanship and style of the era. Added bonus currently is the art nouveau exhibition on the third floor which is well worth climbing the stairs for. The mix of glass, ceramics, furniture and art is fantastic, and the costumes of the period are beautifully crafted. I had a lovely morning, but was too early for the first guided tour of the day, which was a pity. I'd love to go back for that. The cafe at street level is good and reasonably priced.

Stunning art nouveau. An absolute gem. We didn't get to look at the décor in the restaurant as Sunday service is just for buffet lunches, so our afternoon tea planned was coffee/cake in the café - soaking in the art nouveau atmosphere. Service was prompt and courteous. My raspberry cake was so fresh when the jelly topping came away from the fruit you still had a whole fresh berry complete with fine hairs!

Lots of experiences. Good tour, great explanations of all the different themes and artworks in each room. Mucha room is stunning. Get the photography pass just for that. The Art Nouveau exhibit is good too, many other artists and neat clothing and glasswork. Ended the night with a Vivaldi orchestra concert, top notch

Beautiful Building. This was my favorite building in Prague. The exterior is amazing! You can take a tour, eat a meal, have a drink in The American Bar or see a concert. The American Bar is a greasy example of Art Deco decor

Good food. Terrible service. The outdoor seating doesn't really allow for great people watching, but the indoor seating is stunning. The service is actually kind of terrible, but the food is fairly affordable. My meal was about 10 USD

A Wonderful Evening of fine French cuisine and Classical music.. If this is the building which had the concert hall then it is a must visit. Concerts are offered almost every evening and are reasonably priced. The hall is an architectural delight and the acoustics are excellent. Also next to this hall are two places to dine. A formal French restaurant Francouzska Restaurace and a more casual cafe for lighter food choices. Reviews for both can be found on Yelp

Worth a visit to the halls or the bar in the basement, just to see the Art Deco design and decoration.. I visited these halls more than once during my stay as they are stunning to look at, day or night, from both inside and out. I attended a classical concert in the Smetana Hall on one evening, where the acoustics were spectacular. The Art Deco styling throughout is beautiful.

Makes history interesting. When you tour the lovely castle you realize how many of the Chech treasures are in other countries. They have the buildings and the churches but most of the art is gone. The outside is free but there is a fee for the tour.

Municipal House Hall. Huge Art Nouveau building with a tower, front facade is amazing ... I recommend coffee in the restaurant, the atmosphere of old times ... For interesting to building a rounded whole.

For the art and architecture lover. This Art Nouveau building is the striking centre of the square. It is breathtaking in its design, colour and decor. Sit outside or go inside for an awesome look at the work of artist Alphonse Mucha best known for his art nouveau posters of the famous Sarah Bernhardt and others of the era.
Art Nouveau. Go see this if you love art nouveau buildings, they have a lovely cafe. There are also two art nouveau hotels around the corner.

Art Nouveau par excellence. Beautifully decorated building in art nouveau style with wall and ceiling paintings. We had tea and cake in the cafe, and would not have been surprised if Hercule Poirot had made an appearance. Pleasant, but pricey.

Outstanding building but expensive concerts!. The Municipal house is one of the most beautiful pearls of Prague. Art nouveau decoration, go take a look at every detail the building offers...
On the other hand, we bought some "not very cheap" tickets for the Mozart/Dvorak concert, we expected an orquestra, but there were only 6 musicians on stage... This is not worth the 40€/ ticket !

One of my favorite buildings in Prague. Stunning building, inside and out. An Art Nouveau treasure. The acoustics in the concert hall are great, but I would have been happy just to see this gorgeous building. Attending a concert there was a bonus.
Great people place. ornate building. Attended a motzart concert there. great people place outside it. Lots of events being held around the building.
Attractive Building. Went on the guided tour.. Was worth paying for as well informative and went into lots of the rooms.. Plenty of paintings and architecture to see
Do not miss this building. A beautiful Art Nouveau building, well worth paying for the tour. We ate in the cafe and had a few drinks in the Americky Bar (you get a discount with your tour ticket).

Fantastic experience. We attended a concert in the Municipal House while on a short break in Prague. The concert took place in the Smetana Hall which was beautiful. The decoration in the hall is quite stunning and the acoustics are perfect. As for the quality of the music on offer - simply wonderful.
Bohemian Jugend splendour. This is a beutifully restored Bohemian Jugend house with fantastic exterior and interesting details inside. Quite astonishing to look at!

Beautiful concert hall. So beautiful!. Take the time to book a concert and enjoy the ambience of this beautiful building.
Make sure to check out the beautiful dome.
Nice. This is the first building I saw in Old Town. I got off the metro at Nam Republiky stop and this is at the angle of N.R. and street that leeds to the Old town sq. Beautiful art deco.
an absolute must!. an absolute must-see for all architecture lovers. Prague's most marvelous art nouveau landmark - and a venue for good concerts.

Magnificent Buildings. This Prague`s foremost Art Nouveau building complex is located in Old Town Hall & surely one of the finest in Europe.Inside is a magnificent complex of buildings including the Smetana Concert Hall,Pizenska a lively Czech beer hall restaurant,the elegant Francousza French restaurant,a traditional cafe,American bar & an exhibition room.The beautiful building has intricate stonework,gold trimmings,frescoes & stained glass windows.Inside i was lead by a marble staircase to Smetana concert hall which itself is an architecture masterpiece with a mix of carved white stone,gold trimmings lit up by hundreds of lights.The declaration of Czechoslavokian independence was announced in this hall.Now a days it holds classical concerts housing the Czech National symphony orchestra.A visit to this exhuberant & sensual building is worth for its own sake even if you find the concert & French restaurant an expensive preposition.

Music Lovers Only . However, no wifi, the only connection available was the mans hotspot next to me. The concert I went to did not have outfit coordination whatsoever. The lady wore pearl earrings and the other woman wore diamond earrings. Really disappointing. Otherwise playing was decent. Good enough pitch for my ears. No popcorn, though the cappuccinos in the cafe were pretty good. Only complaint is that they did not offer sugar cubes. I came because everything else was closed, but the music was fantastic.
Concerts and food. Beautiful building, but concerts there are expensive. The caffe and restaurants there are also ok, as it was close to the hotel we did eat there.

Don't miss this Art Nouveau masterpiece!. The Municipal Hall is a must see for lovers of Art Nouveau decor. The hour-long guided tour is a feast for the eyes. Each room is filled with outstanding features, including marvellous mosaics and beautiful paintings, including murals and paintings by the outstanding Czech artist and designer Mucha. While you're there, book for a concert in the stunning Smetna Hall. The Czech musicians are phenomenal performers. The hall and concerts are worth every koruna!

Take the Tour to See It All!. If you are a fan of architecture, art nouveau design, marvelous craftsmanship and/or Frank Lloyd Wright-type things, this is a must for you! We like them all and were totally wowed by this amazing building and its many wonders. To see it all, pay to take the 1 hour guided tour (ours was conducted in English). It also gives you a discount coupon for a drink in the delightfully retro American Bar. Lunch in the main floor cafe was tasty and the setting exceptional. Check out all the details...even the hinges and door handles are gorgeous! The gift shop has some beautiful art nouveau jewelry, glass & ceramic pieces for sale.
A must for Art Deco Fans. If you don't like Art Deco you could be converted by the end of the tour. It's another of Prague architectural feasts.
Art Nouveau gem. The best of best for Pragues Art Nouveau architecture. Visit the cafe and go there for a concert. The interior and exterior are sublime. This site is mostly free as well.
Art nouveau lovers heaven. A must go experience in Prague. Glorious art nouveau. Just go down steps for a drink and check it all out.
Beautiful dining experience. The Municipal House Hall hosts concerts every night. There are two restaurants on the ground floor (Art Nouveau Francouzska and Kavárna cafe) and a beer hall underground.
Eat at the Restaurant - Traditional food - live music. A good place to eat and the live music makes all the difference. You need to book in advance as places are taken well in advance!

Prague music. We went to an evening performance at the Municipal House. Before purchasing tickets we inquired if it was air conditioned and informed yes. The music was amazing. The hall was very small and intimate and had great sound quality. The images on the ceiling and walls were beautiful. However, while the overall hall might have been air conditioned this room was not. It was unbearably hot. So go for the music, the ambience and the experience, but don't go on a super hot day unless you are prepared to melt.

Art Deco in a lovely building. The building itself is worth a visit, including its interior. many concerts take place in its main auditorium or in smaller rooms. he musicians are high quality, but prices are expensive. it includes a restaurant and a bar. You can buy tickets on site, while appreciating the Art Deco of this building and its decoration. Its surroundings are also worth a visit.

A graceful, gorgeous example of Art Nouveau architecture. This is one of the most graceful and glorious examples of Art Nouveau architecture I have ever seen. Concerts of Mozart and Vivaldi are offered in its performing space, Smetana Hall. Unfortunately, getting even a peek at the interior requires a ticket to a concert or one for a guided tour. Municipal House also has a coffee shop and a fine-dining restaurant, both with their original Art Nouveau décor. The building is a gem, inside and out.

Certainly notice outside features. Nice features to notice outside. Attended a concert in Smetana Hall and that room was as expected from pictures. Although gave a high rating, on the priority scale of inside visits (not associated with a concert) it would not be as high as others. However, it is next to the Powder Tower which will want to see as remnant of city wall. There are interesting streets to traverse from Old Town Square to here.
Very nice. We visited on a rainy day with our 3 childern (14,12,6). A very nice guided tour. The guid had good english. You get a very good look for all in interior. Good value for your mony
Outstanding. A mecca for Art Nouveau (Jugendstil) lovers. Very good exhibitions, fine restaurants and superb concert hall. The architecture and decor fo the place will cut your breath.

Amazing if you love Art Nouveau!. Took the guided tour of the building and were amazed that this isn't better publicised.The building is incredible! If you like Art Nouveau you will love this. It has everything and every detail of the construction has no money spared.There is so much to see that you can miss the small details that are so impressively Art Nouveau. Everything from the tiles to the door handles are exquisite and don't miss the fish tank-sadly not filled at the moment-it's fantastic!There is a very good shop too selling reproduction jewellery and Art Nouveau items which is also worth a visit.
amazing building. one of the most impressive buildings around market square. looks great at night and during the day. worth to be checked from different corners.

A must visit place. A beautiful building with many aspects. The cafe is amazing art deco (?) room. The coffee is good with a great selection of cakes available. The American Bar is a small, worth a visit but a bit of disappointment.
Fine Art Noveau. We did not have time to take the tour, but we enjoyed a meal in the restaurant surrounded by all that beautiful stained glass.

Just Beautiful. Unfortunately we did not have enough time for this beautiful Art Nouveau building. A 1900 building and showing some beautifull hall area. Entrance at 290Kr is steep in our view but this is the case with many other places in Prague - for example the Library in the Monastary which you cannot even enter properly and pay 200Kr just to peep through doors of a corridor (takes less than 45minutes) is hardly good value for money and we were told that if we want to take a photo then it will cost another 50Kr. Also maze on Patrin hill is not good value.

Must Visit. One of the best coffee and cake experiences ever! If you like Art Nouveau this place is heaven. The municipal house features lots of different areas - some of which you have to pay to enter. However, there are lots of free accessible areas to explore. The cafe interior is the best example of Art Nouveau and every detail is exquisite. The waiters are professionally dressed in whites and bring the brass and glass cake trolley to your table. The cakes are made in house and are delicious. A piano was being played the afternoon we were there and the atmosphere was wonderful. You can wander about in the public areas downstairs and restaurants and bar and marvel at the beautiful tile work. Well worth a coffee stop and not to be missed.

Worth seeing this wonderful Art Deco masterpiece for free. Awesome Art Deco cafe and restaurants both on ground floor and in basement. No charge to walk around, only to tour. Worth stopping in for sure
Decorative and charming hall. Quite an aesthetic hall, especially during the evenings when the choir plays..Located near the Palladium and town square
An excellent tour.. We took the tour which was very good. For seniors 240 and others 290. The main hall and many side rooms were decorated in a lovely fashion and much history was revealed.

Pearl of Prague 1900. probably most beautiful Art Nouveau building qe have seen. Build around 1900 with great style, just beautiful...we were lucky to seen everything inside thanks to our guide who have special contacts in Prague. We have seen concret hall, French restaurant, all nice decorated sallons and had coffee in stunning cafe house located at left wing...simply superb !

SO worth seeing the interior!. Fantastic Art Nouveau details everywhere you look. We did not try any of the restaurants, not attend a concert, but the public areas and views into restaurants alone are worthwhile.

Smetana Concert Hall. We attended a concert in this incredibly beautiful Art Nouveaux concert hall. Astounding. Because of the incredible acoustics, a small chamber orchestra filled the hall with it's sound. As a lifelong musician it was truly an experience of a lifetime.

must go place !. Ahhh ... the best breakfast in town ! American style, continental, english, just an omelette or an afternoon coffee served with brandy and a real style Saher tarte ! Great atmosphere, the old romace and feeling of being somewhere ages ago :)

Beautiful rooms and good guide!. We enjoyed this tour because I felt like our guide was very personable and knowledgable. I think this attraction has the potential to go the other way with a less stellar guide. While none of the rooms really blew me away, they were beautiful and it was interesting to see such a superbly preserved example of art neuvous. Since we opted out of going to Mucha's Slav Epic while we were in Prague, this was a nice substitute since he painted the ceiling of one of the rooms. Therefore, we were able to get a good feeling for his work on this tour.

Where the locals hang out. This is also a busy square but where real life is, not the touristy thing although it is a couple of blocks away from Old Town. There is a large super store and a large 200 store mall. A no fee money changing place. One would get better deals here than where the tourists are. Only be cognizant that because it is for the locals, you will come across some people who do not speak English. Very friendly and helpful ..."sign" language worked on both sides. Is a surprised how much I could get from our conversations w me speaking English and them speaking Czech. Fun exercise.

If You Like Art Nouveau.... Worth a visit to tour the place as it is an historic Art Nouveau masterpiece. You can get in with a discount using a Prague Pass, but you will pay extra if you chose to take photos. Lots of finely painted details on the walls of the various rooms that you would think at first glance were wallpaper or marble. You can hear concerts here or grab a meal at one of the restaurants on site.
ice from outside. We passed by it, nice building with a very nice front. Did nit get inside (not sure it is possible). All in all nice but not a must

Three days' sightseeing in Prague. It is good to have a cup of coffee here. The building is amazing and it is delighted to walk around the city.You must wake up as early as you can as the weather here in Aug is really hot. You cam also buy some concert or opera tickets here.

Dont skip the cafe!. Outstanding architecture inside - its an Art Deco gem. There's a piano playing, there are courteous waitresses and waiters serving you, and their selection of cakes and desserts is second to none. Is it a bit pricey? Perhaps so, but frankly you get what you pay for and that is a lovely atmosphere, and delicious things to eat and drink. Go there!

Art Nouveau paradise.. Breathtaking inside and out. We saw the Art Nouveau exhibit there and loved it. We were amazed by the fabulous Nouveau details in the entire building, and even got treated to a ride in the beautiful elevator.

Excellent tour, skip the concerts and cafe. On my third trip to Prague, I finally managed to find time for the Municipal House tour, and it was one of my favorite things in Prague. They only have a few tours a day, so my mom and I went to the box office in the morning to get tickets (not right when they opened, and it was high tourist season), but I think others had no problem buying tickets right beforehand. Our tour was large but not ludicrously so, and conducted in Czech and English, which meant there was plenty of time to take photos during the other language.Photo tickets DO cost extra, which in my experience is common for museums and other attractions in post-Soviet countries. It's not an expensive extra fee, and we only had to purchase one for both of us (we confirmed this with the guide before the tour started).The guide was knowledgeable and pleasant - not the kind of almost manic-funny guide you get on tip-based "free walking tours," but well-informed and good. The interior of the building is gorgeous and I enjoyed learning more about Art Nouveau. I'm a little puzzled by those complaining that the "mall" "across the street" instantly ruined the experience, as I don't recall noticing a mall and was busy looking at the stunning interiors of Municipal House itself. Overall, it was one of my favorite experiences in Prague, but I really enjoy architecture and history.If you're less interested in architecture and history, you can wander around the basement and some of the ground floor and peek into the restaurants for free, although it's less impressive.I would avoid both the restaurants and bars, which look incredibly overpriced (I'm guessing the "two for one" drink coupon with the tour brings the drinks closer to normal prices) and the concerts, which like all concerts marketed to tourists in Prague are a ripoff. If you're visiting in the off-season, there should be plenty of better options, and in summer I'd personally rather no concert than a low-quality overpriced concert.

Amazing Art Nouveau Building has much to offer. This beautiful building on the edge of Stare Mesto is connected to the Powder Tower offers a variety of activities that can fill more than a day. It's easily accessible by public transit Tram or metro to Namesti Republiky. If you're in Prague over several days you could attend a chamber orchestra concert in the evening, return in the morning for breakfast in the elegant Kavarna Obecni Dum; take a guided tour of the magnificent chambers surrounding Smetana Hall and spend time looking at the Vital Art Nouveau 1900 exhibit.If you've seen enough castles, palaces cathedrals and ancient buildings this is a great alternative.
Art Nouveau gem.. Wonderful art nouveau architecture inside and out. The downstairs restaurant is beautiful. The tile work is amazing. The American Bar is here, too.
Great place. The municipal house is a great architectural place. Also the cafe is worth to visit. In the Smetana hall in the municipal house are almost every day concerts.

Mucha should be proud of this building. This building is amazing the architecture and the design of the interior is absolutely fabulous. There so many different aspects to this building, with concert hall, basement Czech restaurant with traditional musicians, the wonderful café with crystal chandeliers lighting up the room, they were playing Jazz when we were there. They also have a formal French Restaurant on the ground floor. And the cakes on offer are to die for.

Concerts nearly every night in this gem of a building. Went to a "Best of the Classics " concert , all strings but amazing and very reasonably priced . Fulfilled my ambition to sit in a box in a concert hall .

An Art Noveau Masterpiece!. Very close to our hotel, the K+K Central and is right next to the Powder Tower Gate, which is the entrance to the Old Town Square. The building is designed in the Art Noveau style including its interiors and is mostly used for musical concerts. When you walk through the doors of the do not forget to appreciate the details in the lighting and its finishes - imagine yourself in a time warp and be transported to another period in time. When you have the chance, pop in and have a soda at the cafe next door to further appreciate the design. Food however was not very impressive.

Take the tour!. A celebration of Art Nouveau interior design and architecture with wall murals by Mucha which have to be seen to be truly appreciated.A highlight of our trip and proof that romanticism is not dead.

Beautiful Art Nouveau building with a lovely cafe.. We arrived here at 3PM and we could not eat in the French restaurant inside the building anymore as they only serve food until 3PM. So instead we admired the building from the outside, the hall and the lovely cafe where we had coffee, chocolate cake (Vienna style) and goulash.
Very cosy, good option. If you are going to travel to Prague check the agenda in Municipal House Hall. They have much options for cultural activities/concerts.

Extraordinary building!. Built in the style of Art Nouveau, it's my favorite building in Prague. I was fortunate to be able to see the exhibition 'Art Nouveau 1900 Vital ", which I recommend to all lovers of this style. The exhibition is open until the end of this year (2015).

Great building, worth seeing. From the outside this looks like it might just be a concert venue, but head inside and there are exhibitions, restaurants, bars and a lovely interior. Well worth spending some time inside looking around for the building as much as the exhibits. The beer-cellar type restaurant and fancy American Bar in the basement are well worth seeing.

Impressive Art Nouveau Features. If you like art nouveau you will love this building. As you enter through the front door your eyes are drawn in all directions. The acoustics from the centre of the room as you enter are amazing. The restaurant next door is equally as impressive although you pay for it in the prices.

Beautiful art Nouveau. Loved this building, full of wonderful architecture. The restaurant is delicious and not too expensive, especially considering the setting. We also went to a concert in the Smetana hall, which was most enjoyable. Highly reccommend

A beautiful Art Nouveau building. If you like Art Nouveau, this is one of your must places. Every detail in this building is eye capturing. e were lucky to catch an Art Nouveau exhibition inside as well. And don't miss the museum shop.
Stunning building. Absolutely stunning building and perfect spot to enjoy a cool drink while watching the crowds pass by.

Don't miss this!. This often overlooked building is a must see for it's art nouveau architecture. It is visually stunning outside but tours are offered of the many unique rooms inside. There is a room designed by Alphonse Mucha that is superb! Classical music concerts are held here several times a week and there are 2 restaurants as well. Tours are available in English and Czech with transcripts in other languages. Photography is permitted with the purchase of a $2. photo pass.

There is usually an art exhibition on display. You can walk around in the foyer of the building, visit a very 'arty' shop that sells some quite expensive things. Or take one or all three tours around the building at a price. There is also an expensive looking restaurant and an art nouveau brasserie. We just enjoyed the architecture of the building, both inside and out (the free bits)

Easily overlooked but not to be missed. My daughter is living in Prague & present & this is one of her favourite places. One evening we:1. had a cocktail in the picturesque bar in the basement.2. went to the Art Nouveau exhibition on the top floor.3. enjoyed a trip down (& back to the past) in the 1900 lift with seats & attendant. I just about remember this in posh department stores as a girl but a new experience for my daughter.4. had an excellent dinner meal in the cafe.

a nice tour. If you want to immerse in Prague's Art Nouveau scene, this is the place to go! There are guided tours in English that last about one hour and the guide will take you to the main rooms ( concert halls and cafés) around the building. You will be able to see Alfons Mucha's paintings in situ and appreciate the views over the city roofs.
Good quality and cheap price.. Choose the tourist menu before a concert. We had the pork schnitzel which was 2 large pieces. Wee cooked and the potato salad was excellent
Trip back in time. Not to be missed, the Municple House Art Nuevo architecture let you travel back in time. Sit in the tea room to enjoy a beverage and drink in the atmospheres.

Spectacular Art Nouveau Interior Not to Be Missed!. The Minucipal House was my favorite sight in Prague. The building is beautiful as are so are many, many buildings in Prague. It is the inside that made this such a highlight. The first time I visited the building, I ran around like a child in a toyshop, taking phtographs all over the ground floor and the floor below, where there is the beautiful American Bar and a 3-D model of the building. My husband and I had drinks and an early dinner in the Kavarna Cafe. I had the salmon dinner; it was good and reasonably priced. All the while we were there, someone was playing lovely tunes on the piano. The spectacular architecture, the food and the music all combined to make this my peak Prague experience. I returned two days later for another visist. I did not see a concert or take a guided tour on either visit. However, on my second visit, I bought a ticket to the Art Nouveau exhibit on the floor above the ground floor. While I was up there, I peeked into Smetana Hall - a gorgeous venue. The exhibit was interesting, too. I also visited the gift shop which has some unusual art nouveau items (on the expensive side) as well as postcards and more affordable objets. If you decide to attend a concert, make sure it is in Smetana Hall. Some concerts are held in smaller venues of the Municipal House. If I had had more time, I would have also taken one of the guided tours. Don't miss this special Prague sight.

Gorgeous building- but try the cafe for some of the best cake in Prague!. I think the title gives the explanation. Beautiful building, convenient also for the Powder Tower (next door), and for the shopaholics amongst you, Palladium shopping centre over the road. But by far the best part of the Municipal House is the cake in the cafe at street level!

If you tire of Gothic, Rennaissance and Rococo, try this Art Deco triumph. From the huge auditorium, through the amazing Restaurants that flank the entrance to the American Bar and beer cellar below, this whole complex is a triumph of the Art Deco style, and also of Czech nationalism as it was built immediately post World War 1 when Czechoslovakia was given independence. To begin or end a visit, you should take a drink or a meal in either one of the two Art Deco restaurants included in the site, for an experience of early twentieth century grandeur. The only downside to the guided tout we took was the knowledgeable but rather formidable guide, who bit the head off of unsuspecting visitors who "stepped out of line"! Seemed a bit of a throw back to the school headmistress, very much the old school variety

Palace of Art Nouveau. This whole building - theatre complex, restaurants, external architecture and internal decor, even the toilets - is a living museum of art nouveau at its height. Beautiful, and a fantastic example of the genre.

Prague Proms!. Saw Anna Netrebko and company in Smetana Hall. What a fantastic evening! The Hall uses risers with removable chairs, so sightlines aren't the best. Acoustics were wonderful. This was a highlight of our trip. The only reason for the lowered rating was the seating arrangement.
Concert. We enjoyed a camera orchestra there, playing Mozart, Dvorak, and many others. The building is vey beautiful inside!

Breathtaking Art Nouveau. The guided tour is a must. the information is in depth but not overwhelming. You will, however, be blown away by the perfectly preserved detail and design. The restaurants are excellent and once again unbelievably lush with Art Nouveau detail.

Simple to go to, lovely music, nice facility, fairly basic. Saw the Dvorak Symphony Orchestra here and it was one of the highlights of the trip. Wonderful violinist heading up the 12 pieces. The acoustics are very nice. The room wasn't full. The seats aren't plush. The hall is somewhat ornate but not plush like the really regal places. Still very nice and a great experience. You don't have to dress up. There's a mall right there and some restaurants, so it's super easy to do a little shopping, grab a bite to eat and see some music, then walk back to your hotel if you're in the area. I was really glad I'd booked this in advance. Recommend it if you enjoy symphonic music.

Beautiful Concert Hall. We enjoyed on of the concerts at the Municipal House. It is a wonderful experience when visiting Prague. There is also a café outside that was quite fun to people watch and enjoy a nice meal.
Amazing architecture. Great location at the edge of Old Town, lot's of history associated with this heritage building, it has a stunning facade and is located right next to Powder Tower.

A day in the city. Had heard of this place from friends and after out tour of the Municipal House which was wonderful with a fab tourist guide whose English language was better than people who come from English speaking countries went into Obecni Dum for a drink, but once we saw the trolley with the fab cakes, tarts and gateaus could not resist. The building itself took me back years ago when you used to go to the old fashioned tearooms and the staff were all dressed in black with white aprons, just wonderful.
Authentic Menu at a reasonable cost. Do try the huge downstairs restaurant...hundreds do seats where you can enjoy a great meal. The service was great even though the place is huge.
Your guide very demanding. This is a beautiful building but the tour guide needs to work on her friendliness and make her tour a little more interesting. The cafe beside the hall is magnificent.
very nice. like the the art nouveau decoration the atmosphere if you are in the neighborhood give it a try / close to the old city

Great tour!. I came to the Municipal House after a visit to the Mucha Museum, because it had been mentioned that he decorated one of the rooms, and I accidentally arrived just in time for the guided tour - buy a ticket and you won't be disappointed! We got to see all the rooms on the first floor, with a guide which was dedicated to explaining everything we were seeing and answering our questions. It was a very well spent hour in a very beautiful location. Just mind that you have to pay extra to be allowed to take pictures.
Fantastic Concert. Fantastic classical concert with such high quality accoustics, and then a very good dinner down stairs at a Czeck quisine restaurant

Take the tour!. I stumbled upon the building during a walk near the powder tower and was immediately impressed by the beauty of the Art Nouveau style building. I was contemplating buying concert tickets because I wanted a chance to explore the building and ended up getting tour tickets instead. I loved the beauty of the building and it was cool to learn a bit about the history too. Each of the rooms were decorated in such different styles, it just continued to be more and more impressive, culminating with the Mucha designed Lord Mayor's office. Amazing! If you are a fan of art nouveau style or Mucha, this building is a must see. I ended up taking pictures throughout the tour guides talking, because she doesn't give you much of a chance to snap pictures after she's done talking.

Great concert and good food. Dined at the restaurant before our concert by North Czech Philharmonic featuring Dvorak 9th. We really the enjoyed the restaurant and its ambiance. Our waiter was a great guy, forgot his name, gave us lot of attention and pampered experience. Took us inside and clicked a few very pics of our entire family. I gave him a big bear hug :-) and handsome tip. When we walked the pleasant surprise awaited us. VIP tags on our reserved seats. Looks like very few folks do advance booking as we did, so reserved seats were marked as VIPs. Lol!Great concert and I really enjoyed the Dvorak, 9th - From the New World, which melts my heart every time I listen.

Be careful buying tickets!. The music options in Praha are many especially in churches around the city. Be careful though when choosing concerts in the Municipal House. My friend and I bought tickets after seeing the CONCERTS in the Municipal House brochure that was available at our B&B. After buying the tickets, we come to find out, that the concert was not in the Municipal House but downstairs in the basement which was disappointing. Now, if where you hear classical concerts isn't an issue, then by all means go, because the music is wonderful. But do your research first because the advertising is a little deceiving.

An hour well spent. We took the guided tour of the interior of the building. If you appreciate Art Nouveau at all, you will appreciate this tour. The interior is just as breathtaking as the public areas. One room was totally decorated by Alphonse Mucha, if you are a fan of this truly great artist, you will be totally blown away by this room.This made up for not being able to see The Slav Epic, due to temporay closure. Thoroughly recommend.
Lovely Art Deco. We did the tour, which was lovely - so much architectural detail. If you are into Art Deco at all, this is an absolute must. Also had coffee at the cafe, it was just charming.

Great room to watch classical music. Saw the string orchestra here and it was a great evening. The Municipal Hall is in the basement, but don't let that fool you, it is a lovely room and the acoustics are great. Though because the chairs are on on a slanted floor, it is a bit difficult to see.

Buy the photo pass!. Take a tour, buy the photo pass - trust me! Spend the $5 for a coffee or soda in the amazing restaurant (no photos allowed). Free bathroom in the basement near the art exhibits where the tours start. Small gift shop has unique post cards. The most beautiful building I visited that wasn't a church.
Great for the enthusiast. Great if you're an Art Nouveau fan but a bit so so if you're just interested in Prague history. Great for the enthusiast but a bit dull for the casual tourist.

Pragues star art nouveau attraction.. This art nouveau masterpiece is probably the citys grandest building.Above the main entrance is a huge semi circular mosaic,entitled Homage to Prague.Inside there are sumptuously decorated salons cafes and restaurants.also inside,topped by an impressive glass dome is Smetana Hall,one of Pragues principal concert venues.

Drink your beer or coffee here !!. Beautiful building.
The restaurant is sooo nice.
Coffee shop , whether you sit inside or on the street is very nice, its decorations, an excellent service, nice things to eat

Need to see in Prague. unicipal House (Czech: Obecní dům) is a civic building that houses Smetana Hall, a celebrate concert venue, in Prague, Czech Republic. Its address is Náměstí Republiky 5, next to the Powder Gate in the center of the city.The Royal Court palace used to be located on the site of the Municipal House. From 1383 until 1485 the King of Bohemia lived on the property. After 1485, it was abandoned.[1] It was demolished in the early 20th century. Construction of the current building started in 1905.[1] It opened in 1912.[citation needed] The building was designed by Osvald Polívka and Antonín Balšánek.[1]The Municipal House was the location of the Czechoslovak declaration of independence.[1]

Absolutely beautiful…book a private tour. Wow! Another place that is so worth going to see and having a private tour so that you can see both the Women's side, so beautiful, and the Men's side, large, but not beautiful.

Prague Symphony Closing Night Performance. Spectacular evening. People were dressed in their finery. I will always remember watching the evening fall in the skylights above. Absolutely beautiful music in lovely place. I will always remember. (Ridiculously inexpensive)

Stunning devor and architecture - not to be misssed!. This is a must visit! The décor is superb - it's like stepping back in time. The meal we had here before the concert was exceptionally good and very reasonably priced with a good choice and good service.
Dissapointment. We experienced a mixture off classical music + ballet 7pm performance far from our expectations. It was a completely touristic activity with an extraordinary high price.

Amazing Art Deco building. The building is fantastic and a gorgeous salute to the Art Deco style. You can enjoy the ambience even more in the cafe, where we had lattes and cake. In addition, there is a fine gift store with beautifully made items, not the tacky stuff found in most places. I bought many beautiful silk scarves for gifts, made in the Czech Republic and with patterns by Mucha (the famous Art Deco artist). Walking around the tourist zone in Prague, you are constantly bombarded with people handing out ads for music performances by small chamber orchestras of a sort of greatest classical hits in lesser venues. This building has the famous Smetana Hall, with over the top opulence. We listened to the Prague Symphonic Orchestra perform Symphony Number 9 by Schubert and selections by Wagner, including arias from Tannhauser sung by bass-baritone Adam Plachetka. The price to hear such a high level of artistic quality in such a wonderful venue was less than the cost to go to the ones hawked by the street vendors! Buy your tickets in this building and make sure the performance is in the Smetana Hall.
Wow!. Amazing Art Nouveau building. Stained glass windows. Went to a concert one evening and it was wonderful.

The Architecture is an Extravaganza of lovely design!. Booked tickets for the "Four Seasons" concert! On our way in we spotted the Francouzska Restaurant and decided to add that to our day! The Restaurant was superb for our lunch/dinner at 2:30 p.m. and the concert at 7:00 p.m. was outstanding. What a lovely way to spend an evening. The building alone is worth a visit with the Arts Nouveau style - stained glass, tile picture inserts in the walls, stunnning wrought iron railings, lighting fixtures and paintings. Check at the ticket office on the first floor for a music venue - you won't be disappointed. We loved our afternoon and evening at the Municipal House! There are several restaurants in the building that are excellent!Don't miss a visit to this lovely venue!

Art Deco Building. Absolutely gorgeous Art Deco building in Prague. We saw the Prague Symphony Orchestra's closing concert - a wonderful way to experience the concert hall. We didn't eat there but the cafe looked very pretty. There are lovely Mucha murals all though the concert hall.

The name Municipal is misleading . This is an amazing complex and the word Municipal Building is misleading as the image in your mind will be of something bureaucratic and inelegant.On the contrary the buildings are beautiful and they house regular concerts. Tip Prague has more concerts and opera per capita than any city in the world I know off and it you like this kind of stuff you can view top notch productions at very reasonable ticket prices. Don't be shy to bargain for ticket prices.A number of high quality eating joints nearby make for a complete experience.

a beautiful building. This beautiful building has been turning into shopping center.It does has very nice French restaurant and a nice local restaurant. People tend to enjoyed themselves and drinking nice beers.
Stunning inside and out. We went to a performance of the Four Seasons by Vivaldi - unforgettable sounds and sights - like travelling back a hundred years to a time of great opulence.

Maximum Glory Of Arts Deco Design. If you are keen on seeing the perfection of a building's interior totally designed in Arts Nouveau style, then this is the place. Stained glass, curtains, furniture, wall paintings and coverings, aquariums, the lounges, coffee rooms, auditorium, washrooms and more are completely in sync. Nothing is unimportant in terms of design. Guided tour a must. Take photos freely.

Art Nouveau. Beautiful entertainment venue with fabulous art deco details. There is a cafe on the street level, and a beer hall in the basement. There are tours available, and you can purchase tickets for same day shows. A beautiful example of a beautiful architectural style.
Concert. Listened to a fantastic concert with a reduced string section. There was a varied repertoire. We later had dinner in the exquisite surrounding of the restaurant downstairs
The Four Seasons. A very nice performance of Vivaldi's "Four Seasons". Beautiful venue and good acoustics. It's tough to pay so much when the buskers on the streets are so good, but it was worth it.

Truly A MUST See!!. This is truly one lovely building! Went downstairs for a beer during daytime...but made reservations for dinner that night! Gorgeous Art Nouveau..opened New Years 1911!! Enjoyed our visit to this wonderful place!!

Beautiful Building by Mucha. This wonderful building was one of the most impressive sites we saw when we first got to Prague. Our hotel was close (Boscolo) and when we began our walk to lunch we saw this and were impressed by the outside, which is turn of the century architecture at its finest. It was designed by Mucha, and if you want to get an appreciation of him, visit the Mucha Museum (which is close by). He was a Czech nationalist, but also an artist of international renown at the turn of the 20th century. We went to it and there was an exhibition inside of the art nouveau movement which was excellent, featuring arts and crafts of the turn of the century. I did not see as one reviewer did any 'shopping center' but there is a concert hall which we could not visit. There are two restaurants in it but we did not have time to eat in them. Highly recommended to see and appreciate both in & outside. Don't overlook it going to Old Town.

A beautiful building. This is a gorgeous building. However, as it has been turned into a shopping centre, other than a brief look outside and a battle with the crowds, unless you want to shop....not much to spend your time on, but the architecture is definitely worth a detour on your way somewhere else

Art deco showcase. A high point of our weekend in Prague. This gorgeous building represents the height of art deco design -- the tiles, the stained glass, the fabrics, the woodwork, the lighting fixtures, the murals, even the radiator covers display the best period craftsmanship. Definitely worth arranging for a tour in English to learn the meaning of the symbolic murals. Bonus: a fabulous gift shop with well priced and distinctive period jewelry.

A bit of culture. This is a very nice venue (art noveau style) for live music. I recommend one of the late afternoon, hour-long concerts as a nice way to relax before dinner. I am not much of a classical music fan, but the setting and the music combined to make for an enjoyable hour away from the buzz of the city.

Just the most breathtakingly magnificent Art Nouveau building ;both inside and out.... It is a wonder to look at and marvel ,that it is still here in such immaculate condition for us to gawk at. The staff inside are not as nice though and their attitude to foreighers is condescending and rude in some instances. I reckon that they should be content and realise, that tourist monies are keeping the place solvent and act accordingly; a little bit of politeness and understanding would not go amiss.

Concert. We went to a concert in the Smetana Hall in the Municipal House.This is an amazing Art Nouveau style building with the concert hall, bars and restaurants. The concert was a program of classical excerpts played b y the Prague Symphony Chamber Orchestra. The standard of music was very good but the concert was only an hour long so not really value for money.

The Best of Classics Concert. We attended the Best of Classic Concerts at Smetana Hall, the main hall at the Municipal House. The concert is announced as The Best of Classics: J. Strauss, P. Mascani, Vivaldi, Bach etc. played by The Prague Music Chamber Orchestra, but it falls short due the too informal presentation of the orchestra and the lack of some instruments. The six violinists are really good musicians but is not enough for a real concert of the Classics.This type of concerts are offered at many places in Prague, and some of them are very good, but not always the perform fullfill the expectatives!

Great Building . Few steps from our hotel.. It's near the Powder Tower.. A restaurant at the ground floor.. I don't have the time & the chance to visit it just a look from outside but if you have much time pass to this building
Great design. Amazing building with a great art deco design. You can go inside and visit the lobby, or have a coffee in the restaurant. But to see inside properly you'll need to take the tour.
excellent concert. We attended the Budapest Festival Orchestra's tribute to Mozart and Brahms which was fabulous! Great location. Also had dinner at the outside cafe there which was quite nice.

Art Deco Extraordinarie. This is the second time we have been to the municipal house. What a treat for Art Deco lovers. From the moment your enter the building until you experience the art deco exhibit , you will be in heaven. One of our top 5 attractions in Prague and this is our 4th visit.

Try a concert here. Tickets were cheap for this place. We attended a symphony concert here and got box ticket seats for less than 20 GBP. The seats themselves are quite uncomfortable and small; the boxes aren't as large as they appear on the website. Further, there aren't any clear signs indicating where the seat is, my ticket said 'Box 2' but even the staff there couldn't tell me exactly where the seat was. (Hint: it was the balcony, and there's a little plaque with 'II' on it). The good part is that there isn't a dress code, even though the Prague locals do like to get dressed for this, so expect to see plenty of well dressed people but you won't stand out too much as there are still tourists in the mix.

Art Nouveau Splender. Take a tour and get 20% off on your order in the cafe! The cakes come highly recommended (the sandwiches not so much). In any case, this place is a fantastic visual experience! The Prague card gives you discount on the entry ticket.

Take The Tour. The Municipal House Hall is an amazing building both inside and out. You can only visit the lobby unless you take a tour which is definitely worthwhile. There are English speaking guided tours scheduled daily and you will see and learn about many of the rooms. You may NOT take photos during the during unless you purchase a photo permit, cost about $3.00 USD. Unfortunately they don't tell you this until the tour actually starts and not everyone in our group had time to purchase the permit.

Plzenska Restaurace. This basement restaurant in Obecni Dum is brilliant. The Art Deco architecture and decoration is fantastic. The menu has plenty of choice including traditional Czech dishes with knedlicky (bread dumplings) and the food served is excellent. We had lunch there. Twice! And good Czech beer is available. The service at lunch time was excellent. It can be very busy in the evening when there is also entertainment. So for an evening meal get there early or book in advance. Miss this restaurant and you will regret it!.
Great experience. Went here to hear the St Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra and what a night. From the beautiful surroundings to the fantastic music we have memories that will last forever.

A gem of a place. This is a fantastic example of Prague Art Nouveau. I have visited a number of other Art Nouveau sites in Europe and this once is magnificent. Before visiting, I was not familiar with a number of the artists who contributed, but I will be watching for their work now. We took a guided tour so we could see many of the parlors and meeting halls. Then we went back in the evening for a concert. It is a lovely concert site - very good acoustics. Don't miss this.

Prague Style Art Nouveau. The Municipal House is one of Prague's great (and there are many) landmarks.The exterior is stunning, particularly floodlit at night.A tour is essential to enjoy the wonders of the building inside.The building is of the Art Nouveau architecture style. The building exterior has allegorical art and stucco. There is a mosaic called Homage to Prague by Karel Špillar over the entrance. On either side are allegorical sculpture groups representing The Degradation of the People and The Resurrection of the People by Ladislav Šaloun. Inside, the Smetana Hall serves as a concert hall and ballroom with an impressive glass domeAt the end, just perch on an outdoor table late into the evening with a tea, coffee and slice of a decadent dessert and you have the full Central European evening experience!

Wonderful music experience. We went to a concert in Smetana hall in the Municipal House of Mozart and Dvorak. It turned out to be the Prague chamber orchestra not a full orchestra. They were 8 extremely talented musicians. They played Mozart and Dvorak for just over an hour. The acoustics in the hall were amazing. We all enjoyed the music so much. It was a magical experience. A must do in Prague.

A bit like tea at the Ritz!. Sumptuous and glamorous. I was there for dinner and the chandeliers sparkled, the piano tinkled and the waiters smiled. Perfect for honeymooners, anniversaries and surprise birthday treats and not as expensive as the Ritz.

Very interesting tour of this beautiful Art Nouveau building. Make sure you book a tour of this building to get to see areas that you would not otherwise be privy to see. They are just wonderful, especially the room designed by Mucha. It costs about £8 but the guide is great and very informative. Tour takes about an hour.

Cocktails in the American Bar. The Municipal House is a masterpiece of Art Nouveau and well worth a visit. Situated in the basement of this beautiful place is a wonderful bar with delicious cocktails made by a charming bar tender. These lovely cocktails round off your visit to the Municipal House perfectly. Certainly one of the highlights of a recent trip to Prague.

Performances for Music Lovers. and a wonderful, rococo dining room; limited menu but you are stepping into a different century. Municipal House is on the cusp of touristed Prague and the part of the city less mobbed.

Wonderful Music and Ballet Show at Smetana Hall. The Smetana hall is the main hall of the Obecni Dum and historically important to the modern Czech nation.It is beautifully decorated with stuccoed sculptures, stained glass ceilings, gilded lamps and a rather grand organ.It displays a blend of different architectural styles both Baroque and Art Nouveau.The ceiling and wall frescoes are thematically linked to music, dance, drama and poetry.We didn't do the full tour of the Obceni Dum but we enjoyed a concert at the hall.I had booked the tickets online and paid for the BEST seats, which turned out to be 7 rows from the front!The concert was lovely and involved both classical music and ballet.Most of the front rows were empty and a couple came in late and sat on the front row, much to my chagrin!I think you will get tickets on the day itself.The hall was not totally full.The prices of the concerts are also much cheaper than those in Vienna.After the concert, we went down to have a look at the distinctive Ameriky Bar, which is housed in the same building.It is the oldest bar in Prague and second oldest in Europe.It is quite small,but has a striking black tiled decor, which gives it a somewhat gangster feel.

Steeped in Art Nouveau. What a stunning building. Every detail was so vibrant and precise. The muted colours ,stained glass ,tiles ,furniture etc created by the very best from this period. There was a special lunch menu .; 3 courses for about £15 . Small exquisite potions that sent out taste buds reeling . Abit like master chief!

Great concert in the evning. I went to an evening Beethoven/ Mozart concert which was outstanding both in terms of beautiful venue and amazing talent of violinists and cellists. During my first day had visited the exhibition in the building - interesting. Only small negative was I found the lady in the ticket office quite unfriendly, although she started my booking then passed me to a man who was much more helpful and friendly. Would definitely recommend attending one of their concerts.

Fantastic tour of a beautiful building. This was our second trip to Prague and I have no idea how we missed this building on the first trip. It is a treasure! The building itself is absolutely beautiful and has been painstakingly preserved. Our tour guide made the experience so rich and interesting. She shared interesting insights into Czech history, music, and architecture and wove them into a fascinating story of this remarkable building. The tour was a good pace and length. The photography pass is worth the price because you'll never remember everything you saw -- but be ready to just use your eyes to take it all in too.

Absolutely beautiful. I really cannot recommend this place highly enough. Prague has lots of beautiful Art Nouveau scattered around the city, but this is most definitely the highlight. The building is stunning, inside and out, beautifully restored. We took a one hour tour, which took us through the big music hall, and then through half a dozen side rooms, each individually decorated. The best was the one decorated by Alphons Mucha, but they were all lovely in their own way. The tour guide was excellent, told us many things about the history of the building and what some of the motifs in the decoration mean. One of the side rooms is where the first Czech Republic was declared after the first world war, so the tour is worth it just to see that, if you are interested in history. There were also two exhibitions on, and we bought a combined ticket for these and for the tour (if you want to take photos on the tour, ask for a photo permit, which is not much more money but which the staff fail to mention to anyone that you require). The exhibition of Art Nouveau objects was gorgeous, absolutely worth a visit, glassware, furniture, jewellery and some stunning clothing. The second exhibition, of dresses by a Czech designer, we could not find, and none of the staff we asked seemed to know where it was; but her shop is on the ground floor of the building, so we saw enough in the window that we decided not to bother looking harder. There are also a cafe, a restaurant and a bar on site. We visited both the cafe and the restaurant on successive days, mostly so that we could sit and admire the amazing decor. The cafe prices were not bad at all, perhaps a bit higher, but not as much as you might expect. The restaurant is quite a lot more expensive, and geared very much to serious meals, not coffee and cake. Aside from the excellent tour guide, the service from everyone in the building (ticket office, cafe and restaurant) was uniformly terrible, but I love the building so much I can't mark it down for that!There are lifts, but finding someone who can operate them for you seemed to be extremely difficult, so if you have mobility issues it might be worth allowing extra time. All of the bathrooms I saw were up sets of stairs, also.

Absolutely gorgeous.. This is one of my favourite buildings in Prague. The city is full of amazingly beautiful buildings and this is no exception. Wonderful art. Have a fun time after in the restaurant below.

Interesting tour. We booked the tour the previous day and did the 12.30 guided tour. There were approx 35 people on the tour. You have to pay extra to take photos - only about £1.50 but seemed a little strange. Our guide did English and Czech. Very interesting building and fantastic examples of art nouveau. Tour took about 85 mins overall. Worth doing if you want to learn a little of the history and art of Prague.

Amazing art deco place!. If you like Art Deco -- or even if you don't -- this is a lovely place to walk around. Or you can eat in the café which is lovely. When I was there, there was an Art Deco exhibit which was fascinating and included furniture, art posters, clothes etc. Very interesting and focused on Czech artists though it also included others of wider European note.Definitely worth a visit!

Visit and Enjoy a conccert. The Municipal House has concerts and events all year long. Plan in advance and buy tickets tio one of the functions. According to a Music of a visiting orchesttra, who played in this scenario, it has a very privileged acustics. Booking ina dvance will give you a chance to pick what you prefer, but tickets are usually available at the ticket office on the day of the shows, if these are not the most popular.
Vintage. This is a big old building with bars and restaurants, great atmosphere inside but full of tourists of course.
Art Nouveau Exhibition. We went to a really wonderful art nouveau exhibition (with lots of Mucha pieces) in the municipal house - it's worth going in just to see how beautiful the interior is.

Amazing cakes and good tea. We decided to try eating here on a couple of occasions and were not disappointed. Our first visit was for an early evening meal and the majority of the party had the lamb, an excellent choice. The exterior and interior of the building do not disappoint and the gentle background music added to the ambiance. On our second visit we sat outside and watched the world go by eating sandwiches and cake and we had the best cup of tea in Prague.

Best art nouveau in Prague. Designed by Mucha, amazing inside and out. Treat yourself to morning tea but eat inside in the fabulous Art Deco Kaverna not outside with the smokers! We had coffee cake and cognac in beautiful room, so cheap!

Perfect Jugendstil. We didn't go inside the building, but I can tell you the exterior is awesome. It's a perfect example of the Jugendstil architecture. Personally I really appreciate this art. It has something magic and playful. This was the most beautiful piece of Jugendstil I saw in Prague.

Beautiful Art Nuovo building. A very nice building, well preserved and restored. Guided tours are provided several times a day. You cannot enter without a guide, therefore taking a tour is highly recommended (1 hour approx).

Art Nouveau masterpiece. This is an incredible building and a must for any Art Nouveau visitor to Prague. Take the guided tour round the main concert hall and adjoining function rooms - it is a treasure trove of art nouveau featuring work by all the key Czech contributors to the style - and more. The tour guide was excellent - and the quality of the interiors astonishing. Incredible that so much has survived in its orginal form and the restoration work is exemplary.
Beautiful building. Beautiful building outside, went inside to watch live Mozart and was amazing, worth seeing, try and see a show if you can

A fantastic building. We had a guided tour, I think it is the only way to see around. The building is much bigger than it appears and was well designed to have concert halls, cafes, bars and meeting rooms. All in very well preserved art nouveau style, beautiful.

Loved this place!. Fabulous building and we would recommend the guided tour - allowing you to see parts of the building and learn so much from our informative guide. American Bar downstairs is fabulous and we spent many hours in the stunning ground floor parlour/bistro enjoying a bottle of wine, coffee and cake and listening to the pianist and sax player. Highly recommend this place to just chill and watch the world go by - it was close to our hotel and we went back three times!

Chamber music concert you could skip. While the municipal hall building is beautiful and the program of music for the concert is wonderful... The performance was just average and the seating not very comfortable.We went to the 6:00 pm performance. Of course the music choices were exquisite and if you don't often hear classical music-this program is fantastic. But....if you do know your classical music you'd know the performance was just average

Beautiful Art Noveau building in Prague. The outside and interior of this building are full of amazing Art Nouveau details. Check out the tiles, the lamps... everything has been lovingly restored. There are 3 restaurants and and an American bar, each one with different decorations. There is also a beautiful concert hall.

Nouveau paradise. A paradise for art nouveau lovers, from the exterior to the sumptuous details on every surface in every room. It's a riot of sinuous colour. It's worth going to a concert in the Smetanova Hall - the music is bland and uninspiring (bits of the four seasons and Brahms' hungarian dances again .... please) but you get to spend over an hour looking at the hall - seats towards the back are best. Currently a collection of art nouveau objects/clothes/prints are on exhibition. The gift shop has a wide range of work by current and past Czech designers.

Incredible Prague experiences happen here!. We stumbled upon this place because we noticed the incredible art nuveau architecture and wanted to see what it looked like inside. We found an amazing place to see a Vivaldi concert, some of the best food in Europe and a great little museum. This place will always be special to us because it evokes another era in amazing ways. You won't be disappointed!

Do not miss. Art Nouveau interior. Be sure to take tour as each of side rooms adjacent to central concert hall has a different architect and design.
