Even lace curtains mimic patterns in wood or furniture. Excellent beer hall restaurant in basement and french restaurant at street level. Excellent museum gift shop.
Delightful..... Art Deco extravaganza...scrumptious cakes. Would have like to have done a tour of the place but short on time
Go inside!. From the outside this place is lovely--but, spend your cash on the conducted tour to see the magnificent interior, money well spent.

Beautiful. We really enjoyed this tour. The main concert hall is beautiful and our guided tour very interesting. We enjoyed seeing all the different decorated rooms. The only thing that could have made our visit complete would have been hearing a concert here. They do have several concerts during the week but that doesn't mean you'll be in the main concert hall. They use other rooms for smaller concerts.

Stunning building!. I stayed in Prague for a week and managed to see a lot. Visiting Obecni Dum was my favourite! The building is beautiful on the outside outside and 1000 times more on the inside. Breathtaking Concert Hall, with everything complementing each other, yet beautiful and delicate on its own. Then come all the pretty smaller halls and the one designed by Alphonse Mucha where I could spend hours and hours...Don't forget to pay for the photo ticket if you have your camera with you - it will be worth it! Only minus was the guide - a corpulernt lady with glasses who arrived entire 10 minutes late, didn't bother apologising and started speaking quite rudely instead.

Grand European Music Hall. Like others, we attended a wonderful classical concert and I highly recommend it. Wonderful setting, well worth seeing. Then head downstairs beneath the concert hall afterward to the opulent, art deco "Americky Bar." Despite the name, it's a beautiful place to have a drink after the show.

Beautiful Building. We attended a concert in the building and also ate at the Plzenska Restaurant in the building. The art nouveau style of the building is just gorgeous! I wish I had just walked around and taken more pictures, but then again its a picture absolutely every step.If you aren't attending an event there or eating there, I would definitely recommend taking the time to take a tour. If I ever get back to Prague, I will make it a point to get back to the Municipal House.

Art Nouveau masterpiece. Mucha is a favourite artist of mine. I have examples of his work at home and recently went to see the 'Slav Epic' which is of course...epic. The Municipal House is wonderful example of an art movement so involved with more than just paintings. The building is magnificient and the details are beautiful. Spend some time inside, look at the concert hall and most certainly have coffee and cake in the cafe. Don't forget however to look closely at the outside as well!

Beautiful art nouveau building. This is one of the prime art nouveau buildings in Prague and even globally. It's beautifully preserved and also hosts a restaurant. If you're interested in architecture, don't miss this.
Re: concert . We watched a concert at the Smetana Hall. Just getting to see the hall itself was a great experience. When you're in Prague, it's worth it to try to catch a concert.
Spoil yourself with lunch here. A great place to enjoy a traditional Czech business lunch. Wonderful décor - 1930 theme. It Is like entering a different era

A treasure for art deco-junkies. Actually the building itself is very nice, and it was marvelous how empty it was - as if we were on a secret mission without anyone knowing about us. And then, the exhibition. If you're not particularly in love with secession and art deco, I don't think it would be worth the 150 CZK-s, but if you happen to like this period (as I do, and I grabbed along my two exhausted parents), you couldn't be in a better place. A very pretty exhibition, easily worth a thin hour of your time, with all the interactivity and videos, pieces of clothing and interior design. And the posters! Amazing! Nota bene: this show is not for those who wish to see all the original pieces from all the big names put together. Also nota bene: the gift shop is disappointing (even though I would have been into buying any Mucha-themed stuff.

Cakes and more cakes!. We had Afternoon tea and cakes and more cakes from a serving trolley! Like past times! Beautiful art nouveau decorations and glass windows! In the basement a restaurant with nice Checkish food and The American bar. Go there to experience the Swining 20s

Just a block from the Prague Hilton. This is one of the lesser known attractions, but it is very well run,
and professionally curated. Very educational, and a very good option while the main National Museum is closed for renovations.
Superb for kids.

Art Deco Fans - Take the Tour!. So much has been written about the Municipal House that I won't repeat what others have said. However, I must point out that although one can see beautiful elements in the foyer, reception areas, and exterior, you do not get a true feel for this structure unless you take the tour. It's worth the ticket price, easily, and supports the preservation of the structure, so don't hesitate. Take the tour! If you are a Mucha fan or have come to Prague to see as much of Mucha's work as possible, you won't be able to go home until you experience the Mayor's salon, only available on the tour. I have uploaded five photos which I took during the guided tour. Spectacular does not even come close to describing this architectural treasure. I'd also like to point out that our guide's English was excellent! We visited over the Easter holidays and were able to walk in and purchase tickets w/out a wait. However, I am sure that in the summer it gets very busy, so I would advise booking ahead.The website describes the building as a national treasure, one representing the "golden age of Art Nouveau." This is certainly the case! I visited Prague twice before without venturing further than the front door and, having just seen as much of the building as is open to the public, I regret waiting this long. This building will change how you see Prague - it's a "must see" for any visitor.

Secession Treasure. I had read that it was not generally open to the public, but it is. If you like art deco and art nouveau (it has both elements), it is an astonishing frolic, both inside and out. I ate in one of the restaurants and the food was dreadful, but I didn't care because the surroundings were so lovely.

Municpal House. The most fantastic Art Nouveau building ever so well preserved and in constant use. We used the cafe, had a drink in the American bar and enjoyed the Art Nouveau exhibition. A must if you are visiting Prague
Nice building. Nice building both outside and inside. Inside there is a restaurent, but it is not cheap. But outside is free of charge, and you can look a bit inside at the windows.

104 year-old Art Nouveau building. Magnificent mosaic on the facade, as glittering as the neighboring tower is dark and gloomy. The interior is also beautiful and to see it fully, you may go to a concert. More information on www.obecnidum.cz

Marvellous concert hall. Had the chance to see Smetana’s “My Country” and also Dvorak’s “New World Symphony” in the city where they both lived. The seats were only 1000 CZK and there was no set seating so you need to get there early to get a decent seat. You could pay 1300 CZK for set seating which would have been in the stalls, but I felt that the view down there was not so good.The concert Hall’s art deco architecture is amazing.

Stunning. A unique and beautiful building. Stunning interiors, beautifully preserved and restored - all accessible to marvel at. The Czech Phil. performing Dvorak in the Smetena Hall was an a superb musical experience made unforgettable by the setting.Surely one of the great buildings of the modern world.

Best music ever. I had the chance to listen the Stabat Mater of Dvorak at the Municipal House. Hearing Dvořák's choral masterpiece in the city where he lived was a delight. The Municipal House's art deco is well worth seeing too. Great experience

Stunning architecture. very close to hotel we were staying in. Art deco style building. Very busy with concerts. We like that it is the temporary home of the Art Deco collection - normally housed in museum of decorative art which is closed for refurb

Beautiful building. If you like art nouveau then you will have think you have died and gone to heaven! Such an amazing space. Visit the American bar for a great cocktail or glass of prosecco - a lovely atmosphere. Some parts of the building are accessible only if you have a ticket to an exhibition or event but there is plenty to see even if you only go in the front door and down stairs.

Worth taking the tour. Taking the guided tour in this historic building is worthy. The Smetana Hall as well as the rest of areas included in the tour have interesting features. It's a pity that in this place too they are asking for an extraordinary fee for photo licensing (ok we got it, tourism is a highly profitable industry but do not take it that far people)... And this is not a complaint about the insignificant amount of money to be paid for the photo license thing, but it's about the whole profit-orientated approach.

Beautiful Building with some rude staff.. I enjoyed the tour very much, our guide was enthusiastic, knowledgeable and she clearly loves the building. You'll need to buy a release to take photos, not a bad price at 55 CZK. The artwork and architecture is beautiful and the history of the building is interesting. We went on the tour specifically as INXS filmed their 'New Sensation' video here. It was great to see the balcony in real life, although you can't go out onto it.After the tour we had a drink in the American bar (2 for 1 with your tour ticket on certain drinks). I then asked where the toilets were and was pointed in the direction of the restaurant by the helpful bar staff. However when trying to get to it I was stopped by the Maitre D and told that the toilets were for 'their clients only' and the public toilets were upstairs. So I went upstairs where another gentleman told me that the toilets 'are not for free'. He begrudgingly let me go through after I showed him my tour ticket.Now I appreciate that as a historic building they don't want hundreds of people traipsing through using the toilets on a daily basis but they didn't have to be so rude about it. These two gentlemen really spoiled the experience for me, so I probably won't go back if I ever visit Prague again.

Municipal House. The Municipal House situated next to the Power Tower was constructed in 1906-1911 from plans by architects Osvald Polívka and Antonín Balšánek on the site of the one-time Royal Court, built circa 1380 by Venceslas IV. The facade is decorated with a mosaic by Karel Špinar and a sculpture by Ladislav Šaloun. On the decoration worked Alfons Mucha, Max Švabinský, Mikoláš Aleš and Josef Václav Myslbek. It was here that an independent Czechoslovakia Republic was decklared on October 28, 1918.

Magnificent Art deco interiors. Its worth a visit to just admire the wonderful interiors , especially the restaurant. We also attended an evening concert which was enjoyable if a little short !, Unfortunately we were part of a sparse audience that night and felt somewhat swamped by the magnificence of the vast grand concert hall it was held in.

If you like art nouveau you will love this. Walked in here to get out of the rain and wow what a building. We signed up for the tour and make sure you pay the 55 CZK to enable you to take photos as I promise you will take loads.The guide was very informative enlightening and encouraged questions. You go to parts of the building that you cannot access otherwise and each room has a wow factor.The small details are exquisite hence why you need to be able to take photos as you can't take it all in.This tour is worth every penny we paid and the tickets give you a 2 for 1 drink in the American bar if you so wish.

Breathtaking. This huge place, so important to Prague's political, public and cultural life is not to be missed. Very close to the massive and heaving shopping mall opposite, it is a refuge of culture and sanity! Every single detail is pure Art Nouveau, inside and outside, and for a few Koruna you can see upstairs and the special room designed by Alphonse Mucha. Hadn't realised he was Czech - what a great artist he was. The main hall (great for concerts) is utterly beautiful. The design isn't the flowing, naturalistic Art Nouveau that we English relish, but is equally beautiful, Go downstairs to the American Bar (the oldest bar in Prague) and note the tiles on the stair walls. The restaurants either side of the main entrance hall are free to enter, so if you see nothing else, you MUST see those. Students of Art Nouveau and lovers of beauty should make a bee line for this amazing place.

Love this place. Cannot visit Prague without coffee cake and drinks here. It feels so opulent yet affordable. For me it is always a special treat here. No feeling of being rushed and a little jazz music always helps !

A classic. Only viewed it from the outside and looked into the restaurant. Wow. Wonderfully restored and full of life. If we had more time we would have visited the restaurant and taken in one of the concerts

Take the tour. We took the hour to an hour and a half tour of the interior and were delighted. The art work is wonderful in each of the rooms and the main hall is fantastic. There are several art deco styles and nouveau styles to see. Fans of Mucha will not be disappointed.
Great Place for a Concert and very good French restaurant. atmosphere, restaurant is serving very good french meals but not cheap of course, concerts there are amazing!!!

What a place this is !. A magnificent Art Nouveau building with concert halls and restaurants. The guided tour - normally twice a day in English is well worthwhile. Concerts are held - normally by Chamber Orchestras on a regular basis

A wonderful afternoon at Cafe Obecni Dum. The ambiance is so retro. The suits of the waiters, waitresses, the service, the little band of piano, guitar and saxophone.. they take you to elsewhere. Eat medovnik and have a cup of coffee while listening to the lovely music for a magnificent afternoon in prague.

More please. Fairly close to the Old Town Square in Prague A short walk along Celetna street and you are greeted by the Powder Tower. Go through the gate. The Municipal House looks special from the outside BUT you'll be astonished once you enter the Municipal House proper. Architecture is outstanding and the blending of curves to straight lines is astonishing.
A Wonderful Art Nouveau building.. Extraordinary well preserved building both inside and out. Both the restaurant and the cafe decoration - and food - delicious.

Classy performance at a classy venue . I recently attended a concert of the Prague Dvořák Symphony Orchestra here and it was an enjoyable experience. The Municipal House is a beautiful building, both on the inside and outside. I bought my ticket earlier in the day, and was offered a 950 czk seat for 750 czk, and seats at the back of the hall were available for a reduced price of 500czk. Upon arriving you are free to choose a seat within your designated area, so may be worth arriving early to ensure the best view. Although the front half of the seating area was fairly busy the back half was relatively bare, possibly because tickets weren't particularly cheap, so some visitors who had purchased the cheapest tickets moved forward once everyone else was seated. The concert itself was very enjoyable with an excellent piano performance, and my only real gripe would be that the seats were quite uncomfortable towards the end of the hour long performance. Overall though it was an enjoyable performance in a classy venue.

"Art Nouveau on all sides". We visited the "vital Art nouveau 1900", an exhibition which takes place in Municipal House.The building is of the Art Nouveau architecture style, is really impressive and reconstructed in about 1900.The inside of the building as much as the inside is full of stucco,mosaic and art nouveau statues.

Concerts should be lower in price. We recently attended a classical concert in the Municipal House (Smetana Hall) - the first time we had done so in this venue in Prague. We bought tickets at the door and were surprised to find that they started at around 25 Euro - we paid about 35 Euro for seats closer to the front. On entering the hall we were surprised to find that despite the hall being practically empty, our seats were right next to some other people! We asked whether we could move and told this was fine unless anyone else had those tickets. No chance! Out of about 2,000 seats I would say less than a quarter were occupied, and most of those the cheaper ones at the back. Nevertheless the concert was excellent. A string octet giving an absolutely faultless performance of favourites - Mozart, Vivaldi, Handel were featured among others. And the building is indeed extremely beautiful. Such a shame that they were playing to such low numbers and I believe with lower prices the concerts would be better attended.

Exquisite Art Nouveau style!. From the Old Town Square in Prague walk along Celetna street. You'll see the Powder Tower at the end, walk through the gate, and turn left. Even from outside the Municipal House looks special, but when you enter it, you'll be astonished! The best restaurant in the Municipal House is a Czech tavern in the cellars!

Art Nouveau alive and breathing. Went there for an exhibition, however the building itself is an art object through and thorough, it is amazing experience to see art nouveau interior and layout being actually used.

Art nouveau at its best. This place is a wonderful example of beuatifully restored art nouveau.
The cafe is a real must to relive a splendid past and the concert hall is stunning. The concerts of popular classical music are highly to be recommended.
Well worth a visit.
a good example of art deco building. it is best to attend a concert to see the ceilings. But one can still have an idea of a classical art deco building but going to one of its restaurants.
Great meeting place. This municipal house is breathtaking inside and out. It's also a great place to visit and see the symphony and the opera
Fabulous building, but snares tourist's.. This is a very imposing piece of architecture. They have tours and concerts. There is a restaurant and over priced café.

Fantastic concert!. It is a magic place to see/hear a classical concert, we were in the Smetana Concert hall, what a beautiful hall! The concert was just amazing, 70-80 musicians, plus a choir: very impressive. Note that the chairs were not so comfortable but well the music transported me to a different world!

One beautiful building. Stained glass, colored mosaics, tiled murals and gold trimmings. This is a beautiful Art-Nouveau building that is impossible to miss if you have just walked under the Powder Bridge at the end of the famous Celetná street.

Do not eat there. Even though it is one of the many beautiful buildings in Prague, I wouldn't suggest you eat there. The food was very expensive, especially considering how bad it was. If you ask me, admire the building from the outside or visit the exhibitions there (I didn't do it so I don't really know how good they might be) but as far as the food is concerned, just pick another place.

Art Nouveau Heaven. This is a must for Art Nouveau lovers, The exterior is superb but the interior is sublime. The cafe is well worth a visit even if it is just for a tea / coffee and a slice of cake. Very reasonably priced considering the quality and your surroundings. I also had lunch which was inexpensive and delicious.
Art Nouveau Treasure. It's just a materpiece. This is one of my favorite buildings in the world. If you have the chance, see it.
Amazing. That was my favourite piece of art. I love this style and it was amazing at night time. You can go to the concert and enjoy the music and the architecture at the same moment.

art noveau gem. if you like art noveau, this is unmissable. there are several guided tours a day - pricey at about 8 euros for an hour tour and extra if you want to make pictures. most deco details have been renovated, hardly anything is original apart from the many lamps. nevertheless, worth it if you like this kind of architecture.

Gorgeous art nouveau interior. I would highly recommend the guided tour of the inside of the Municipal House. The tour is conducted in English (with handouts provided for other languages). The various rooms on the tour are all gorgeous and with unique personalities--it was an art nouveau delight. The guide we had was obviously, and rightfully, proud of all of the Czech history and craftsmanship that are represented in this building. If you like architecture and design at all, be sure to include this during your visit to Prague.

Vital Art Noveau 1900. This is an excellent exhibition, with secessionist / jugendstil / art nouveaux pieces from the Museum of Decorative Arts, which is closed for refurbishment.It has posters, furniture, clothes, jewellery, glass and more. All good.Great shop, too.

Pretty outside . The outside it's nice. We been here for a concert, the guys playing were good, but the room we've been in not so, also they just put some improvised seats so if u want to see a concert just find a better place.

Municipal house tour. We went on the municipal house tour and wow what an amazing building with so much to see the tour guide was excellent and was passionate about the architecture which if you like Art Deco is a must I enjoyed it so much I would do it again

The art noveau. Out of many art noveau decorated buildings and interiors this is propbaly the one. And they know it, so while you can have a good look inside without paying or purchasing anything, you can also spend money in its restaurants, bars and cafees or concerts. All can recommend to some extent - quality is reasonable, price is higher than in most other locations. Also a good for spotting other tourists.
A must see in Prague. The best attraction in Prague, beautiful art deco style, well worth a guided tour which is offered and an evening concert.

Orchestral Ensemble.. Classic Art Deco building, listened to some beautiful music, Mozart and Beethoven. Found a great little bar downstairs which states it is the oldest bar in Prague. Wonderful place a hidden gem'

Cafe and restaurant. Have morning coffee and cake or afternoon tea in the beautiful nouveau cafe or spend more money for a posh meal in the even more beautiful restaurant. Wonderful architecture and good service.

Listening to the Classics. My wife and I decided on the spur of the moment to attend a concert of the Prague Music Chamber Orchestra who were playing some classical music by composers such as Bach, Mozart, Pachelbel, Dvorak and Strauss. The municipal building is beautiful and very ornate and you can join a guided tour for €7. The concert was in the basement area beside the American Bar and the Pilsen Restaurant. The restaurant is very authentic (and large) but we didn't eat there so I can't comment on the food. The concert lasted about 1 hour. The audience was relatively small, about 80 - 100 people, but the music was very good and in such surrounding was very intimate. Overall it was a lovely, unexpected experience and highly recommend if you like classical music and even if you don't the Chamber Orchestre were skilled musicians.
Live classical music in Prague. We went to see a performance by ten talented musicians. Great value for money. They performed Vivaldi four seasons plus others for a most entertaining hour.
Concert in Smetana Concert Hall. Best of Mozart and Dvorak concert by the Prague Music Orchestra was wonderful. Great architecture, decor, atmosphere. A memorable night in a great city.
Tea and cake!. This is a must for afternoon tea and cake! We visited twice, tea cake and a little liqueur. There was a saxophone player and pianist in the background. Very lovely indeed.

A perfect Art Deco feast. You must take a tour of the Municipal House as part of you visit to Prague. It was a revelation and a highlight of our stay. It has the most perfectly realised art deco interior, well maintained and all the spaces used in the spirit of their original function - as a palace for the people of Prague. We initially went to see the Mucha interior and it was certainly stunning. But the rest of the rooms were similarly perfect. The tour was not expensive and well worth it. Excellent coffee - cocktails too - in the American Bar if you can't face another beer, a beer-cellar type restaurant in the basement and ground floor cafe next to the entrance. Allow at least a couple of hours, more to take refreshments, but you won't regret it.

Highlight. We attended a concert by the Moravian Symphony Orchestra which included the New World Symphony, and the performance, coupled with the decor and architecture, made this about the highest point of a wonderful week in Prague.

Vintage Prague. I went to the Municipal House Hall to attend a classical Vivaldi concert.The moment you step in, you tale a trip back in time; the place is well preserved, with a hint of posh and grandiose, like they used to do them so well back then.The concert room was impressive for a buy-on-the-go kinda ticket, with waxed wooden floors, huge windows.. For a moment I remembered the famous Galerie des Glaces in good old Versailles..
Concerts & exposotions. You must see this building, it is very fabulous architecture of the beginning of 20th century, art nouveau.

Patisseries and Vivaldi. Worth coming here just to see and experience this beautiful art nouveau building, decor and the attentive service. Lunch in the cafe, was trad Czech, medium size portions and very tasty. The cake trolly's a must. If you have the chance, take in a short classical concert in one of the beautiful concert rooms (haven't been in the Smetana theatre yet). Aside from excellent musicianship, you get the ambience and classical music in bite size ...in our case, Vivaldi's Four Seasons, Pachbel's Canon and Hungarian dance music. One hour concert for £12 :-)

Outstanding. A truly awesome example of art nouveau as a total concept, inside, outside, above and below! Somewhere that has to be seen to be truly appreciated.If you want to know just how impressive the building is go and see it, inside and out it is a feast for the eyes.It is an extremely popular spot, in the winter it is warm and inviting and in the summer it is cool with the front main windows lowered to allow better ventilation. The menus are traditional, from breakfast through to delicious cakes and afternoon tea. For somewhere that is a true tourist hot spot prices are very fair. The service is excellent, nothing is too much trouble, and the staff are efficient and friendly.Access is good but parking is limited, try one of the streets nearby. One step into the café and a lift down to the two bars

Beautifully curated exhibition. We didn't have time to tour the building, but really wanted to see the Art Nouveau exhibition. Definitely worth seeing! Beautifully curated, highly informative, lots of gorgeous pieces, an amusing interactive game for the kids. We couldn't understand why there werent more people - was virtually empty. Examples of furniture, glassware, posters, jewellery; also clothing of the time, and an insight into the society of that time. Would love to go back for the building tour!
Perfect acoustics. I´ve visited Municipal House several times during the concerts of FOK, the acoustics is perfect and the building is beautiful itselves. Definitely recommending.

Dine in style. What a beautiful building inside and out, Mucha style at it's best. We had two meals here and will go again. The food is lovely, the service is great, the ambiance is nicely busy but also quiet, you have to choose your time of day. We chose this venue for my birthday lunch and had fabulous birthday cake.

Take the tour Art Nouveau love fest.. Ahhhh. This building is totally and completely Art Deco, but Slavic style. I love Art Deco and I felt immersed in it. Pay a few krone and take the tour and you will see things that you can't see otherwise. You will also learn a bit about Czech history. Stick around and enjoy a concert, either up in the big hall or in the charming small hall in the basement. Yes, not all of the basement players were the best in their field, but you can't beat the price and the feeling of intimacy. I hope to get back to Prague, and when I do I will take the tour again. Oh, and you can take photos to your heart's content.
Perfect architecture. Really amazing architecture, art n style with everything what you can imagine. Go there just to feel old Prague style and take a coffee and sit for a while

A feast for the eyes. This glorious building is a work of art. After admiring the gorgeous facade, take a few minutes to explore the tiled lobby, stairs and basement with their stunning light fittings, windows and fitments. The lift (elevator) is a work of art in itself.For a real treat, eat in the Plzenska restaurant in the basement - also reviewed here - which is stunning.

Beauty both outside and inside. Even if I am short of time being in Prague, I always spend at least few minutes admiring this beautiful buidling. Especially if you a fan of the Art deco (Art Nouveau) style, do not miss it. Observing the exterior focus on the Neo­Gothic corridor connecting the Municipal House with the Powder Tower, the contrast of styles is impressive. Inside the Municipal House you either join a guided tour or visit the exhibition named Vital Art Noveau 1900. Of course you can enjoy a concert there or have a refreshment in the French Restaurant. This place is very charming and it is better not to resist long.

A totally stunning building. We ended up spending quite a while here. A huge shop with some interesting items, some of which are well-priced. The basement bar is gorgeous and again fairly priced. Had supper here and saw a concert.

Beautiful facility. Attended a meeting here with about 500 coworkers. We broke into 3 groups, had dinner and award presentations. Entire facility is beautiful, full of character and able to handle large crowds. Everything was good with experience from social drinks prior to meeting to formal dinner. Centrally located. It is an easy eclipse from Hilton Old Town.
For Mucha Funs. It is a must see for those who adore the Czech master of the Jugendstil. It is near to the Mucha Museum and can be bypassed during a nice city walk around the centre.
Brilliant show. The instrument players were great but the guest singer, the guest violinist and the guest pianist, created a night to remember.

An Art Deco Delight. Had lunch time snacks here on 2 occasions beer was good sandwiches were varied and of good quality with chips! Staff are very obliging and friendly. Most of all loved the stylish interior the wonderful Art Deco lights, mirrors and furniture.

Incredible.. A jaw-dropping masterpiece of artisan work that should not be missed. It is a true public building that appears to be well preserved and utilized. Attended an exhibit of decorative arts that included works by Mucha and his contemporaries. Admission fee was nominal. Self toured the upper floor areas open to the public before visiting the American Bar for a cocktail. Felt transported back in time sitting in our banquette. The building interior and exterior tile, glass, wood and metal details throughout are incredible pieces of art, just beautiful. If time permits, would recommend a guided tour to fully understand and appreciate this building.
Architectural Art Nouveau masterpiece. Not all the rooms free entry, some on paid tours but well worth an entry, tea and cake in the café a great experience like going back in time

For Artdeco lovers. This place you can visit only with a tour. We have done it twice, first by ourselves and then when came to Prague with our family. The building is beautiful and all the rooms are different. Don’t expect it to be as reach as a palace, it is more like a historical administrative building with many rooms for different purposes. Both of the times we had out tour with the same lady who gives information of history, artists and meaning of the rooms décor. She also attentively watches that pictures are taken with no flash and only with a license for each camera! The tour is in English. If you want information on your own language ask for a printed copy at the cashbox where you buy tickets. There are no restrooms so make sure you use one before the tour somewhere else. The tour won’t be very interesting for children or for those who is not an artdeco lover but if you want to know about it more and to see some of Mucha works take time to visit this place.

Excellent example of Art Nouveau. The tour gave us the opportunity to see all the beautiful rooms. The tour guide was a bit abrupt but knowledgable. Well worth it if you have an interest in architectural design.

Nothing Spectacular. Yes, the architecture is gorgeous, but so is every other building in Prague. The concert is great, but there is an even more ornate opera house (State Opera House) nearby for better concerts and cheaper tickets. There are restaurants, a concert hall, and an art museum housed here, but consider skipping this if you're in a crunch for time. Otherwise, peek inside and have a look, albeit a short one.

Great Performance, Rude Audience. My partner and I attended a performance of Vivaldi and some other composers as played by a small chamber group of the Prague Symphony Orchestra, and the music was lovely. However, the tourists that packed the extraordinary hall were behaving like they'd never been anywhere before in their lives. Couples talked throughout the performance, multiple people left their seats, allowing them to bounce loudly against the backs. I can't take away more than one star for this, being that it's not really the fault of the management, it's just something to look out for.
died and went to heaven. if you are a fan of Art Nouveau, Mucha and all the beautiful architecture of the 1920s you just HAVE to visit this place

Pleasant concert. I went to a Vivaldi concert at the Municipal House having been handed a flyer outside. It was a good programme of music, and the chamber orchestra played very well, but the concert was a bit short given the cost of the tickets. A nice way to spend (part of) an evening if the pieces on offer appeal (they seem to vary from day to day), but I wouldn't recommend paying for anything more than the cheapest of seats. I booked via my hotel, but you can also call the venue or book from the Municipal House lobby - and there were plenty of empty seats, so it's unlikely to be a problem if you decide to go on a whim.

House is ok, but guide was bad. We had no choice but to take a tour or see a show, so we took a tour. You can't go through it on your own like I wish we could. The voice of the guide was fine and she was very knowledgeable, dressed nicely but her voice was just annoying and she is not a sight for sore eyes. She told us all of the information that we didn't want to hear, not very interesting. I would advise seeing a show here or just googling the inside. There's a lot more to see in Prague than this

Welcome surprise. We were handed out a leaflet for Vivaldi's Four Seasons the evening we arrived (December 21) on looking through when we arrived back on MS Florentina there was a performance at the Municipal Hall for the following evening. That day we had a tour of the old city and on reaching Wenceslas Square diverted to get tickets for that night in the Art Nouveau Municipal House. Had a coffee in the fabulous cafeteria but resisted the amazing cakes. We enjoyed the performance so much as it was so unexpected in a beautiful surroundings and an incredible experience. If you are given a flyer for any of the concerts that seem to go on everywhere around Prague do accept and take up the offer don't think you will be disappointed.

Great location for concert in historic setting. We spent a pleasant evening in Prague attending a Bohemian Symphony Orchestra of Prague Christmas concert on the 23rd of December. The venue is gorgeous, and a number of historic events in Czech history have occurred there. The seating is simple, our seats in the B section were just fine, they are elevated a bit, and we had clear view of the orchestra and stage. There would be no reason to pay extra to sit in the A seats. The BSOP is an acceptable but not great group, but the festive nature of the music and the setting, plus reasonable price, more than compensated.

If you love Mucha, you will love this. It has Art Nouveau style throughout, much by Alphonse Mucha. We went into the cafe on the left for lunch. it is so beautiful and lunch was good,and reasonably priced with a very happy waiter. We have been here to concerts, to an exhibition this time on Art Nouveau. There is an Art shop further back, go to the left of the staircase. It is expensive, but beautiful. There is also a restaurant for more formal dining on the right side as you go in. This building, next to the Powder Tower is lovely, from outside and inside

Beethoven and Mozart classical music in Municipal House. While in Prague, we decided to the one thing that's sure to be on any culturally inclined tourist's list- attend a symphony or a ballet or a classical concert. Since it was last minute, we booked it through a helpful and patient lady at the tourist helpdesk near the astronomical clock in old town. We chose Beethoven & Mozart, since the opera would be in Czech and we didn't want to get into subtitles. So we booked 2 tickets for 800 czk each.Municipal House is a beautiful building, both inside and out. Our first brush with western classical music was an experience to remember. Being trained in Indian Hindustani classical music myself, I was trying to follow the notes and connect them with our "raga"s here. The musicians had a very high level of mastery over the notes and the instruments. One cannot help but go into a trance.Just a little disappointment- the wooden chairs were uncomfortable. They reminded me of our wooden benches, the kind we sat on in school! Maybe they need to come up with some more comfortable options for a better experience. That is the only reason that I'm giving 4 stars.

Beautiful interior. We decided to stop in for dessert, wine and a beer late in the afternoon. The trolly cart came around and we ordered the Schwarzwald cake which is a black forest cake. It was delicious. The art deco restaurant is a gorgeous. They definitely don't make them like this any more. Definitely worth dropping by and enjoying the cake and atmosphere. Wonderful break from walking around.

Symphony. My husband and I made a point to see the symphony one night at the Municipal House and it was great! We ordered our tickets online and picked them up at the box office before the show. The whole building is beautiful - both inside and out. It was our first symphony and we had a great time. The orchestra was amazing and there were special performances by an organist and a flute player for their Christmas themed show. The only negative comment that I have is that (and this might be a naive thing to say, since it was our first symphony) that I thought there would be more recognizable songs since it was a Christmas theme, but most of them were original scores - which were still beautiful.

worthwhile tour. I did the tour here today (your ticket gets you 2 for 1 on a small selection of drinks in the American Bar which is a pleasant enough place). It's worth doing the tour of the place to see the wonderfully ornate performance spaces and function rooms. My guide spoke pretty good English, and was quite engaging. My only gripe, another 55k to take photos.

Its not just a restaurant review its a full experience........ Our experience started in the restaurant. We had a nice lunch, it was pleasant and the selection was good. The architecture does add to the experience and the lady coming around with the old fashioned t-trolley was really sweet and just because it was there made to order a desert!My only thing that I would say spoiled it slightly for me was the fact that people can still smoke in so many places including restaurants. After a nice meal and an Irish coffee to top it all of we went for a look around the building - it was absolutely stunning!! If you go to Prague you must have a look around this fabulous building!!

See a show. The cafe is beautiful, but there is no need to eat or drink there to appreciate it. This building is best from outside, or from inside the concert hall. If you can see a show, you will appreciate the unusual design and gorgeous organ.

Best of classics concert. We went to the municipal house for a 'best of classics' concert. The building and hall are very lovely, apparently the most important Art Deco building in Prague. The concert was very enjoyable, the musicians skilled and the selection of music was tasteful and varied. We were under the impression when booking that it would be a full orchestra, but it was actually an all string instrument concert, 8 musicians altogether. This was a slight disappointment, but it was enjoyable nonetheless. When we got there most people immediately stood in a queue to check in coats and bags ( which they charge 8 crown per item to check in, so bring change). We checked our things, but I later discovered that some people kept their things with them in the hall, and by doing so they avoided standing in the long line afterwards to collect their things...I'd keep my stuff with me next time.. The concert was about 1 hour long, not bad, but the 1260 crowns per ticket ( about £45 ) was a little steep for such a short activity I think.

Palace of Art Nouveau. Having seen the Mucha Museum and being a fan of Art Nouveau we came here for a tour of the building. Brilliant! The paintings, the furniture, the hardware. All really exciting. A bit of history and culture. Then downstairs to the Czech restaurant for skewered suckling pig, chicken, veg and chips after a big basket of bread and a few Pilsners.
Amazing interiors & built!!. Nicely constructed with some good historical paintings put up here. Great decor. Smetana Hall is absolute beauty!!!

Vivaldi concert. Listened to the four seasons vivaldi and it was devine. The sound, skill, atmosphere was perfect. The location is central and it is very laid back. Nothing to fancy so you can pop home on way back from day out. The building is one the best art deco buildings and there is an excellent art deco shop inside not to be missed.
Tea room. Went there a few years ago and had to visit again. Excellent, good food, even better cakes and great atmosphere, very efficient staff
Gorgeous!!. Had our lunch here one day and it was absolutly stunning was nice especially to try some proper Czech Cuisine really recommend.

Beautiful building of the 20the century in art nouveau. This house was designed in the beginning of 20th century by Balšánek and Polívka. Inside there is several halls, most famoust is Smetana hall (B.Smetana is the most famous composer of the Czech music). On the facade there is mosaic "Homage to Prague" by K.Špillar. In the 14th century in this site there was Royal Court.

Stunning building. When trying to navigate ourselves through Prague on our first day I spotted this beautiful building, we decided we would pop in to have a coffee during our trip.We came back a few days later and actually had 2 banana milkshakes - which were so refreshing - and also treated ourselves to a slice of cake from the dessert trolley. My partner had a rich chocolate slice with ganache and nougat, whilst I had a traditional honey cake that could not have been tastier. The two slices of cake and milkshakes came to 380ck about £11.50 which is a similar price for this sort of thing back home in a cake shop, without the pianist and historical building, so good value.The building is beautiful, inside and out. During our cake and milkshake there was a pianist playing which was wonderful, a tradition that I love.

Great value for money. We attended a concert which not only included an orchestra of about 20, a superb Soprano and several ballet dancers. We have attended other venues in Prague on previous visits but can definitely recommend this venue as top notch. In the U K we attend several "Proms" each year and can say that our enjoyment at this venue was equally good.

Beautiful music in beautiful surroundings. During our stay we attended a performance of mozarts requiem in the main hall and the next night came back to hear a chamber orchestra the next night.Tickets were available in the lobby and although reasonably pricy (we paid 800-1000czk per ticket) the performances were outstanding and the location is perfect if you love art nouveau.Highly recommended

An amazing building and interior. Well worth visiting to see the art nouveau interior as well as the exterior. A good gallery on the top floor, which had an exhibition of art deco/nouveau when we were there. The large bar in the basement was not busy during the early evening happy hour but filled up later. A great place to enjoy a beer or two in lovely surroundings

Absolutely Beautiful Building. The Municipal House Hall in Prague is well worth a visit. We went on a tour of it (with a group of Czech schoolchildren and the tour was in Czech!) and enjoyed it immensely. Even though it was in a foreign language we still were able to comprehend what we were seeing. The sheer beauty of it was somewhat overwhelming. Definite must see if in Prague.
Stunning. A beautiful, historical building which houses some great restaurants. We attended a wonderful classical concert here during our recent visit...well worth visiting.

Brilliant Find!. We had walked past this building for two days without much interest. However it was St.Martins Day while we were in Prague and we found out the restaurant on the lower level of the building had traditional Czech food and ceramic Art Nouvo decor. Food portions were huge and very reasonably priced. Lovely find and staff very friendly.

Beautiful building with so much to see. Wonderful building, we took a tour which was excellent. There are many rooms all beautifully decorated and the guide told you the history of each room. Later on we also had the pleasure of a live concert with the local community. Fabulous.
A must place to visit. The decor & atmosphere in here is second to none as well as having a fantastic restaurant but also being the place to go for afternoon tea !!

A glimpse into another world. My favourite place in Prague to sip a glass of champagne. This is one of the most stunning buildings in the world. From the chandeliers to the tile and metal work. Breathtaking and a glimpse into another world. Living history.

Cake and Cognac. Such good value. For just under £6 you can have a delicious portion of cake plus coffee and water or liquor. No rush, just take your time and enjoy the atmosphere. Do try to use Czech language when asking for the bill or to say thank you, they'll love you for it.
Group Pilgrimage. It is very informative to know the site of the municipal hall of each country. It is quiet and safe though many tourists around.Czech are friendy.

Not as impressive as I'd expected. This was the only tour we did in Prague, and to be honest I was slightly disappointed. It's in the Art Nouveau style but very understated - the best thing to me were the views from the window! There are some murals by Muca, but they just didn't seem that striking. Maybe one for Art Nouveau enthusiasts?!

Art Nouveau Masterpiece. First of all, take the guided tour. That way you get to see all the glorious rooms and their splendid art and early 20th century finery.This one was hardly on our radar but ended up being one of the highlights of our 10-day visit to Prague. It is extraordinarily beautiful. Pay extra for the photo permit - you will be glad you did!
The Cafe. We didn't eat at either of the restaurants, and did not attend a concert in the theater, but found the cafe a perfect place for a relaxing lunch in that glorious interior space.
Nice place but not WAW. We were in the 5 days and had a great vacations, nice place but not excellent, would recommend doing something else for the same money you pay to go in there.

Good Old Fashioned Czech Food. For authentic (and good) Czech food, this is the place to go! Centrally located and the decor (Art Deco) is excellent. Typical Czech music played live and the staff are fairly polite and friendly.

Best Art Deco cafe in Prague - don't miss the coffee, liquor and cake menu. The cafe in the Obecni Dum is worth a visit just for the surroundings, combine it with wonderful cakes and coffee and it is hard to beat.

Fantastic Surroundings, let down by the Staff and the Food. Put Briefly and Simply:Shared a family meal (4 adults 2 Children). Waited 15 minutes for Drinks Order to be taken.Waited further 10 minutes for Food order to be taken.We were on of 3 tables occupied, and 5 staff on the floor.Staff decided they would prefer to play a game of throw a ball of paper into a bin than attend to their Customers - RIGHT NEXT TO OUR BOOTH!Waited so long for the food to come that one of the waiters asked if we would like to look at the deserts before our main course arrived.Served bread, but was flummoxed when we asked for a bit of Butter!Food arrived was of good proportions however, the Pork Knuckle was extremely Fatty, and not completely cooked through. The Chicken Skewer would fall foul of the Trade Descriptions (Mushroom and Pepper Skewer would be more appropriate). The Schnitzel had never seen the inside of a frying pan or a knob of butter in its life. Ribs were quite good, Steak also. Duck very good.Bill was not as good value as one would have you believe.Would I go back? No, would i recommend? No. This is a shame because it had come very highly recommended.

Art Nouveau. Municipal House is the city's foremost Art Nouveau building. It's perfectly restored and is beautiful from all aspects. Certainly a place to see.You can come there for concert, for coffee, drink or dinner. I'd suggest to take a tour of the house and enjoy gorgeous Art Nouveau architecture and decor.

concert. Went to a concert in this beautiful hall. The setting was wonderful but surpassed easily by the musicians,,,,,,we listened to Vivaldi and it was wonderful. Huge restaurant in lower level,,,,,,we did not eat there but wish we had,,,, it would have been extremely convenient.

Fabulous but book ahead. Excellent knowledgeable guide- told you enough of the basic facts and very clear. A one hour tour which we booked ahead online. You can't see these rooms without going on a tour. Make sure you leave enough time at the end to have a drink at the end in the "Americky Bar" in the basement you also get 2 for 1 on some drinks after a tour

Art Nouveau at its best and a lot of history.... Before you walk into this building for a dinner or a concert, step back and take a good look first from the outside. The allegorical art above the entrance - called Homage to Prague was beautifully restored after the fall of the communist regime. The interior is of course magnificent and absolutely worth the visit. I have not taken a tour, but remember it quite well, especially the concert hall and ballroom. Years ago, growing up in Prague, it was very trendy and fashionable for high school kids to take ballroom dancing lessons there.The highlight for the "fortunate" kids living in Prague was a prom in this building's ballroom. It was amazing:) ...and one of the few "luxuries" tolerated by the communist party. I am very grateful that the restoration of the building was done so beautifully and that people from all over the world can appreciate its beauty and the artistic skills of the czech nation.Municipal House was the location of the Czechoslovak Declaration of Independence signed in October 1918.

Wonderful building, so-so symphony experience.. The building Itself is absolutely gorgeous and certainly worth 15-30 minutes browsing. We caught a concert here as well which I thought fell a bit flat due to having only 30 musicians present (no brass, 1 percussionist) in such a large hall. Overall a nice experience though and I'd try it again with a different concert and perhaps different seats (we caught the movie theme concert and were in row 7 of the "VIP" section).

"One of the places to be seen". Lovely building next to the Powder Tower, with popular terrace, nice coffeeshop and restaurant, as well as beautiful concert hall. The only gripe this time is that, after ordering the house wine, I was charged for a more expensive one. In fairness, I had been brought a better wine that I had not ordered (how was I to know?...) and accepted the offer to split the difference. However, in retrospect, I feel a proper public relations-minded manager might have given me the benefit of the doubt - but then again, arguing about a fiver seems stingy...
Do the tour. The tour is very information and well worth the time , when tour is over sit in the Americky bar for a coffee or drink, the art deco decore is amazing

Extraordinary art nouveau building, with a fascinating cafeteria. Not much from the outside, but inside it's a gem of Art Nouveau. The cafeteria is a wonderful room, gloriously OTT. Decent coffee, OK food at decent prices. Cakes were a bit disappointing, though.

Special Visit. Taking a break whilst exploring in Prague, make sure you stop over. Seeing that it was late November when we were in Prague and it was already quite chilly outside, a stop over for a coffee at the Municipal House was a welcome break. The setting is elegant and the coffee and cakes an absolute treat. Definitely worth a visit.

A delightful surprise. Attended a Vivaldi string concert and we're both impressed with the beatiful interior, the entrance staircases to where the concert was held. The room appears to be multi functional but impressive nevertheless with chandeliers and high ceilings. Concerts are given most evenings.

An art nouveaux gem.. We took the 150 krn. entrance to the art nouveau exhibit within the building which is spread over two large halls. Beautiful collection of crystal, furniture, period clothing, posters, etc. The building itself is gorgeous and we had an extra bonus of being able to listen a bit to the orchestra rehearsal. We did not have time to take the guided tour of the building but imagine that it may be worthwhile.

Don't miss this!!!!. Love the art nouveau and art deco downstairs in this incredible building. Great restaurants upstairs for coffee and a pastry or lunch and dinner. Don't miss a concert here, they only last 60 minutes.

Not the Ritz, but a great look and atmosphere.. We had afternoon tea in this art nouveau set restaurant (10 minute walk from the Old Town Square) - which every one said is a 'must do' place. Service was excellent, the cakes were really good - and it was great value. Well worth the visit.

Fantastic concert!. This hall is stunning and any lovers of art nouveau should see something here. It has a restaurant and cafe right inside the entrance both of which seemed to have menus at reasonable prices. Be aware the cafe you just sit down and wait to be served. Most people including ourselves waited for asomeone to seat us only to see locals just walk through and sit down. I had pre-booked to see the Prague symphony orchestra before leaving the UK via a separate website however collecting tickets was easy and we did this half way through the day while in the area. The hall is quite something and the acoustic for the concert were great. There is not a ridged dress code like in some UK concert halls and while most people were in suits. Quite a few were just in jeans and t-shirts. The cost to see the concert was only slightly more than the guided tour you can go on.

Very nice building. It's elegant
It's classic
It's beautiful
It has rich history
It's an excellent place
love it
love Prague

Bring your camera. This building is an Art Nouveau treasure. The tour takes you through only a few of its floors, but enough to give your eyes a complete feast of its beauty. Take in a concert, have a drink at the American Bar or a meal in any of its three restaurants and continue experience. You could spend a whole day here and then go to the Alphonse Mucha museum to continue your Art Nouveau feast.
Fantastic. We went in to see an Art Nouveau exhibition which was brilliant. Little did I know till I entered that the building was an exhibition in itself.
Outstanding. My first symphony and it was brilliant. I loved the building. Loved the performance and ambience of the place. If i ever return to prague, i will make sure i catch a performance there.

Stunning building. We visited this building initially to go to the Art Nouveau café (Kavarna), but found that the whole building is absolutely stunning. The décor in the café is fabulous - the food is also good and reasonably priced for such an amazing place.Every part of this was decorated by the leading Czech artists of the day and has now been beautifully restored. A lot of it is freely open to the public ie American bar, restaurants, foyer area. You can also pay to go on a tour to see the concert hall and various other public halls and rooms. Absolutely stunning, especially if you like Art Nouveau. We went after a trip to the Mucha Museum which was a good combination.

A Must see if you you like Art Deco. Enjoyed our visit very much. We took a guided tour, a good idea as most rooms are closed to the non paying tourist! You will need to pay extra if you would like to take photos during the guided tour. It has been restored after the previous regime let it fall into decay.

A Must Visit. The Municipal House is one of the special treats of Prague. The interior is stunning and divided into function rooms, a concert hall, bars and restaurants. It is overwhelmingly beautiful.

Good concerts. Some good reasonably priced concerts at the halls. Some of the halls are better than others but the acoustics are good and the decoration lovely. There are varied concerts but mostly classical with a bit of everything, orchestra, singer and ballet . Most last just about an hour so fits in with other activities

Special Art Nouveau exhibit. We walked here after visiting the Mucha Museum. They have a special exhibit of Art Nouveau in Prague that was of interest. The exhibit is on an upper level, and one of us doesn't do stairs, so we took the elevator. A beautiful, old fashioned elevator with an attendant! We had a peak in the theatre - no time to attend a performance, but maybe next trip - it's really beautiful. We had lunch in the cafe - surprisingly not crowded. Service was ok, food was good, and the decor is fabulous.

never mind the food look at the design. Quite honestly, the quality of the food here would not matter. You are paying for the experience of sitting in the most amazing restaurants with a range of early 20th cen designs.

The experience of a lifetime. When my choral group announced that Smetana Hall in the Municipal House would be the first of our three European concerts this past July, none of us knew what to expect. Truly, it was as great an honor as any chorus could hope to expect. Grander than Carnegie Hall, wonderful audiences who truly love and appreciate classical music. I'll never forget the sensation of standing in that choir loft, looking out on that great audience, surrounded by majestic sculpture, friezes and stained glass. The acoustics were astonishing, and in the end, our approximately 1,000 audiences members (on a Tuesday night in July!) gave us a an eight-minute standing ovation. If you are a musician who ever has a chance to perform here - grab it with both hands. Whether a musician or not, go and hear a performance. Like Vienna, Prague is a city of great music and it just doesn't get any better than Smetana Hall.

An Art Nouveau masterpiece.. With concert halls and restaurants, this is well worth seeing. There are concerts pretty well every evening, for example of popular classical music for an hour starting at 5.30, plus full symphony concerts.

Visual if not gastronomic feast. Visually beautiful (like so much of Art Nouveau Prague). The French Restaurant is not cheap (eg. £30 for a bottle of Chilean Sauvignon Blanc, c£20 for a main course and they don't serve tap water). The surroundings are lovely, the food well-presented but alas not quite up to the standard one expects at those prices. The waiters are, in typically French-style, slightly over-assertive and impatient. On the evening we dined, the clientele seemed to be predominantly tourists. Presumably well-heeled locals will take their custom to less tourist-oriented establishments.

Brilliant Concert Venue. We attended a concert in the Smetana Hall in this beautiful complex of venues, restaurants and bars. It's grandeur is spectacular and added to the overall atmosphere of a superb musical experience.
Spectacular Venue. Chamber music and other events in the hall and a range of food in wonderful art nouveau decorated restaurant and cafe.

Beautiful building. The building itself is worth a visit - I was amazed by the beauty and craftsmanship on display. I visited an exhibition on Art Nouveau which I enjoyed immensely. There was a whole section on fashion which I hadn't expected, and which was very interesting.

Lovely venue, good music, hard seats.. This once- palace is a great example of Art Deco style in the heart if the Old Town. There are at least two performances most evenings, some classical some more contemporary. The Smetena performance hall is a reasonable size, but except for side box seats which are slightly elevated, the rest of the seats sit on a flat floor. This can make viewing the stage a bit of a challenge if there is a relatively full house although it was not crowded during our stay. Seats are hard and can be uncomfortable even for an hour- long performance.
Massive and detailed. The building is located next to the Prasna Brana, and it's an introduction to the Republic Square. The details are amazing. Worth the time to visit.
Stunning. A magnificent building, we were given a very thorough tour of this magnificent building. Well worth a visit and we had excellent hot drinks and cake in the cafe downstairs.
Beautiful Art Nouveau Style and good coffee and cakes. Wonderful setting to enjoy a break from sightseeing. The characteristic chandeliers are a reason in the,selves to visit

Elisabeth or Eliška. I feel a bit cheated. We should have 1 hour tour in English but to our group were added some Czechs. So the guide had to say everything twice and then we didn´t got much time in Mucha room (the most beatiful room of the whole complex) where we could see all of important people of Czech history and we had to quikly leave and go home. It wasn´t very welcoming. Even thougt the building was staning and I belive that lisening to a concert in the Smetana Hall would be beautiful.
What a treat. We took in a performance here that included strings, ballet and opera one afternoon. Loved it so much we went looking for another performance on our last day in Prague.

Art Nouveau at its best. A beautiful and iconic building which lends itself well to three restaurants with their own styles (the French one didnt like us visiting just to take photos though), the tours are overpriced and they will charge extra for using your camera, but the mosaic is very picturesque, consider what you want before you pay out for a 3 hours tour which you may not actaully want depending on time available. Downstairs the Art Nouveau architecture comes to life and the ' Amerika' bar is fabulous and the staff very welcoming.

Best Of Hollywood Movie Music by the Bohemian Symphony Orchestra of Prague. My wife and I happened to be walking by the Municipal House, and someone handed us a flyer. We didn't think anything of it and when we went for a coffee had a proper look. The Best of Hollywood Movie Music by the BSOP. Why not we thought, an interesting way to spend an evening. We went back for two tickets - 760czk (around £20) and it turns out most of the tickets were gone. We managed to bag a private balcony area, classed as the cheap seats. They were brilliant seats!!On to the orchestra - strings, bass, piano, percussion, clarinet, flute bassoon..Music from Once Upon A Time In The West, Pearl Harbour, Romeo & Juliet, Forrest Gump, Jurassic Park, Les Miserables, Moulin Rouge, Evita & Titanic to name a few.The Orchestra were highly professional and played superbly, especially fantastic playing from the lady in the teal dress on violin!! The room - Smetana Hall -is beautiful. 1200 seats, ornate decoration, sculptures and paintings accompanied by brilliant acoustics. The stage is dominate by a large, original Art Nouveau pipe organ.Definitely a place not to be missed, if there is something on which you like the sound of.

Worth the trouble. There are only so many tickets available for each tour. What they don't tell you is that you need to buy a photo permit for the tour. This was unexpected as none was required for the art Deco exhibit also in the building that I toured earlier. But, the building is gorgeous. I felt that we were rushed along a bit as our guide also was leading the next tour.

Expect to buy your tour ticket in advance. Tours sell out quickly. Probably go the day before to secure your ticket. I was lucky and got my English tour ticket the day of as soon as the box office opened. Five minutes later, and I would have been out of luck. (The tour was for three hours later.) Be aware that many non-English speakers will buy the "English" tour ticket as people really want to get in and look around...so be patient. Good guide in spite of the rude Chinese who didn't listen or care to do anything but snap photos. Well worth the entrance fee.

An absolute gem of the city. A most outstanding example of Art Nouveau. The whole building is impressive outside and even more inside. It hold an art nouveau exhibition, very interesting and represenative, concert halls and two restaurants of the ground floor. Everything about this building is magnificent. A must see and visit place in Prague.

Stunning Art Deco of The Municipal Hall. The Municipal Hall was one of our favorite places in Prague. I enjoy Art Deco, so we signed up for a tour. Once on the tour, we were just in love with this beautiful building, which was so much more than we realized, and which,łLk was as impressive as any other place we visited in Prague. Smetana Hall, the Mayor's Room, and the Oriental Parlour were really amazing, and the other rooms were also...you can only see these rooms on the guided tour. Paintings, statues, decorative elements everywhere. If you are a fan of the artist Mucha, you will especially want to see it!Please note that although there are tours most days, the tours are not at regular times every day. you can see upcoming tours at this link: http://www.obecnidum.cz/en/turistic-tours.html. You can buy tix online or in person.Be prepared to pay for a photo privileges pass if you want to take photos. I would suggest this. We had expected to find postcards with good photos of the place, but there were none.Until December 2014, there is also a special exhibit, called Essential Art Nouveau, in the upstairs. they have many items from the museum of decorative arts. It was excellent, and it helped us understand the movement better.

Nice pitstop to admire the Art Deco architecture. We popped into the Municipal house during the day and saw the lobby; the downstairs gift shop (which incidentially looks very similar to being inside at Rockefeller center's corridors), and admired to the two restaurants on each side. If you like art deco architecture, this is nice stop.

A temple to Art Nouveau. Inside and out, superb craftsmanship and design (by quite a few artists) - statuary, stained glass, mosaic and tile, majolica, textiles, woodwork. One spectacular room after another. Also a great guide very patient with answering questions well beyond the topic.

Opulent. If you like Art Deco you must see this building, free to walk around the entrance, down to the bar and just admire the tiles on the stairs. Restaurants both sides of the main door are beautiful

Very Lively. Beautiful building in a central location. The restaurants inside were worthwhile. Went for a business reception and then stayed for a networking dinner. The restaurant was the one in the basement - beer hall styled. The food was fantastic - many delicious pork options.
Beautiful Art Deco Gem. What an amazing place. Just gorgeous with all the glass and chandeliers and staircases, lovely. Had a light meal at the cafe and went to an opera. Loved it.

Gorgeous art nouveau building. Loved the look of the building and rooms. the art store is exceptional in terms of the quality and quantity of items. I found the hours and fees confusing as the person manning the booth was unfriendly and unhelpful.
Tea as it should be. Go to the café for afternoon tea with strudel to see a little of how life might have been for the wealthy before WW2. Beautifully preserved and very reasonable prices.

Wonderful. Spent most nights here as it's near the hotel. Great to have a selection of classical music concerts even though the one with the ballet exerts was terrible worse than a school end of term concert!
A Beautiful building. It is an ornate and beautiful building. I went there to get my opera tickets, but for a governmental building, it was very beautiful.
Stop off here for coffee. A great place to pause during the afternoon. The waiters sweep by with trays of tea, coffee and cake and the coffee house itself is large and elegant.

The most spectacular building we saw in Prague. This is a facinating building and a major monument of Art Nouveau in Prague. You have to go on a guided tour to see the major spaces, worth it. We also went to a pricy one hour tourist kind of concert--apparently all the churches and major musical venues do them--to see Smenena Hall--worth seeing. Go to the American Bar in the basement, the tourist restaurant in the basement is vast and serves tradtional Czeck cusine. There is also a beer hall on the right of the American Bar. The French Restarant is worth peeking in, we had coffee and cake late one night in the other restaurant on the first floor, also a fanstastic interior! There was a special Art Nouveau exhibit which was excellent in two exhibition spaces. Very well done, All of the interpretation was in Czeck and English. The catalogue looked great but extreemly expensive. All the good Art Nouveau textiles, ,posters, glass, ceramics,furnitute paintings, sliver and other consumer goods came from the Museum of Decorative Art for this show, so there were only a few pieces of Art Nouveau left to see at the Museum. It will take you a couple of days to see the whole of this spectacular building.

Only visited the cafe!. This is a stunning building, with a beautiful entrance. There are two eateries inside, one French and one cafe style. The decor in both are of an art nouveau feel with stunning chandeliers. Well worth a sit down just to marvel at this. Given the location prices are a little dearer by Prague prices though still cheap by UK standards.
stunning decor. This building is amazing and well worth the visit. The attention to detsil is mind boggling. The acoustics are amazing.

A must for Coffee and a Cake. This is the place to have a break while walking in Prague with coffee and a cake. You have to the cakes brought around in the trolley as they are excellent. Separate cost of 100KC but well worth it great surroundings to sit and watch the world go by.
Beautiful. Worth going to the cafe just to marvel at the chandeliers, very reasonably priced refreshments. Make sure you go to the central stairwell to look at the tiles, just beautiful.

ART NOUVEAU BEAUTY. Municipal House - Art Nouveau jewel in the city centre of Prague. Beautiful from outside. Beautiful and exceptional inside. Coffee Shop, French Restaurant and Czech Pub downstairs. Concert Hall. Love this palace.
JAW DROPPING ART DECO. Took a wonderful tour of this magnificent building. You won't see these rooms by peeking into doors. The grandest art deco/nouveau experience I've ever had.

Art Nouveau - the essence. A real appreciation of the essence of the Czech take on the classic fin de siècle cultural phenomenon of Art Nouveau. Impressive guide, stylish rooms, some wonderful detail in lighting, furniture and painting. A warning - buy your photo licence when you book the tour- they don't tell you till it's too late.

Swan Lake Ballet. Bought tickets for the ballet and it was worth every cent - or Euro. The Czech version of Swan Lake was gorgeous. We had a great night out. Little tip .... the champagne at half time is not so good - if you want a sparkling, ask for the Prosecco. Loved the show.

OMG!. I am a huge fan of Art Nouveau and so paid a visit to the exhibition being held here, but the whole building is just an amazingly beautiful example of art nouveau architecture. A real delight. Loved it!

Hollywood Movie Hits with the Symphonic Orchestra. went for a concert with the bohemia symphonic orchestra of Prague. AWESOME experience. almost cried with "Don't cry for me Argentina", the atmosphere and beauty of the building were just divine.

Amazing cake and incredible interior. Brilliant place to grab a drink in an outstanding interior. The cake is incredible – comes around on a little trolly and you pay separately (not expensive). Stop here for food or a drink – it's def part of the Prague experience.
furthest walk from my hotel today. On my first day furthest walk from Marriott hotel. Building is magnificent full of A. Mucha paintings. Inside was also restaurant but for my taste too fancy.

A must if you love Art Noveau. A totally gorgeous building. Art Noveau central in Prague. Every room is absolutely stunning.
Do not miss this if you love Art Noveau!
Visit. If you like Art Nouveau - or even if you don't, take the tour. It's inexpensive and doesn't take long and the building rooms are exquisite. A step back in time.

Great tour in Prague. Great tour if you like art Nouveau. Informative guide, who incorporated some history of artists involved. Built as a cultural centre, the building was advanced for its time.(1912) . Now painstakingly restored. After the 60 minute tour you can have a 2 for 1 drink at the Americky (sic) bar downstairs, or have a tourist snack at the cafe and watch the world go by.

Wonderful building great concert. We really enjoyed our visit here. The music was played very professionally, but more importantly the building is wonderfully restored and a joy to sit in! We heard a Mozart performance, but there are many concerts scheduled during the year! Go!

A magical evening. This is an exquisite place. It is truly over the top with it's architecture and beautiful baroque design. My wife and I attended a concert here for her 50th birthday... and it was a truly wonderful experience. No one will be disappointed in Municipal House.
ok. Frequented by mostly locals, we only waited for about 2 minutes to have a quiet, none smoking table near the..

Gorgeous. One of the most beautifully restored buildings in Prague. Don't miss it. Coffee or lunch in the restaurant is a must just to see the decorations. Catch a concert in the concert hall or take a tour to see this beautiful place. It really is beautiful
great building. Art Nouvuae building. We saw a concert and then ate in the main restaurant. Very elegant setting and great food

wonderfull location. stunning place to sit and enjoy the hustle and bustle. The decor is quite exquisite. Food is good if a little pricey, however we thought it was still worth it giving the surroundings.

Best Bar. Met Philip the bar tender in the city's oldest bar in the basement of the Municipal House Hall. Fantastic trip back in time with the decor and ambiance. Philip is a sensational cocktail barman with personality. Give him the opportunity to make you a cocktail of his choice, you won't be disappointed.

An art nouveau masterpiece. If you like art nouveau, you need to make this place a priority. The front is suitably impressive, but go inside and walk around. Check out the lower level, enjoy a (slightly overpriced) drink in the evocative Bar Americaine, have a outdoor meal in the upstairs French place or the downstair beer hall. Soak up the classy ambiance. We attended a concert, but sadly it was not in the main hall. It was fun and the room was nice, but I would highly recommend taking a tour of the main hall. Check for details at the box office inside.

A very beautiful building.. It is well worth taking the tour. The rooms are beautiful, decorated in a variety of styles. The Alphonse Mucha room is fabulous. The cafe is a lovely place to have coffee and the cake is amazing.

Don't be mislead. My wife and I are regular concert-goers in NY and FL. We paid 2,000 Czk for 2 tickets expecting to see Vivaldi in the splendor of the concert hall. Instead, we were shuffled downstairs into the basement and then into a small room that held maybe 75 people in vinyl covered stackable chairs. The performers and the concert itself were OK (though the concert was slightly less than one hour long), but we felt VERY mislead. The photos depicted a magnificent auditorium, not our basement room. Before you make a purchase, make sure you know what you're getting into. I would highly recommend NOT wasting your money to go to Municipal House Hall if you're expecting a true concert-hall experience.

Café at Municipal House. We stopped for some coffee and sweets at the Municipal House café and were a bit disappointed. We found the cakes a bit too sweet and with too much whipped cream. Prices were reasonable and service was good. Indoor seating is a great choice because the interior of the café is so beautiful!
imposing building. worth seeing, really.the beautiful architecture, a lot of attention in the construction and durability for centuries.You really are the masters of this era were miracle workers
Municipal Hall. Beautiful frescos on the exterior of the building. Lots of restaurants in the vicinity. The Municipal hall holds regular art gallery exhibitions.

Experience let down by tacky tour guide. My wife was really keen on taking this tour. I have to admit I just went along with her but I believe my experience is an honest reflection. After buying the tickets we were left to wait in a gift shop, call me cynical but no surprise to me. The guide arrived late and was pretty rude and abrasive. She explained that if we wished to take photos we would need to pay an additional charge. Throughout the tour this lady seemed very vigilant in her policing of "unauthorised" photography, sometimes it seems at the expense of the tour. The tour itself was completed at a brisk pace, to be honest she didn't take a breath, talked relentlessly and even told one older couple to "be quiet and listen to me ".The tour finished in a cafe/restaurant which was overpriced, dingy and staffed by uninterested employees. On a positive note we met some nice Scottish people. It's an impressive building but unfortunately it's been turned into a rather unprofessionally run tourist trap.

Wonderful Tour. Had a wonderful tour of this beautiful building.
