Found this tour by mistake after wandering in off the street being nosy and finding a kiosk selling tickets for a tour starting in five minutes! I thoroughly recommend this tour, a history of this building, the architecture, the individual rooms and there uses etc. For an extra few pence you can take pictures. The bar in the basement was a lovely way to finish the morning and a welcome place to relax before carrying on our site seeing

Spectacular Venue with Pricey Food. This fully restored Municipal Hall, now home to a great theatre, several restaurants and a coffee shop, is spectacular to see, both inside and out. Centrally located, it is a great spot to stop at for a fine coffee and cake. But do eat larger meals elsewhere for more reasonable prices.Peter and GayeVictoria, B.C., Canada

Nice example of Art Nouveau. We went to a small concert in this building. It's very beautiful with Art Nouveau embellishments is throughout the concert hall. The acoustics very pretty good, not excellent. But it was worth being in this historic hall for the concert.
Beautiful place. Such a historical place and soooo beautiful. Full of Mucha arts and some other artist. Highly recommend to go there!

Nice building. In the very heartof the city you can see a nice historique building, well restored, with allegorical art, stucco and mosaic.
Obecni Dum is close to Powder Gate. You will take many pictures there, fascinated by the Art Nouveau example.
Nice building. A beautiful building worth seeing, and if you like history, you will be staring at the place where a country was created and splitted.

Beautiful Architecture; Entertaining Concerts; Diverse set of Restuarants & Bars. We did not take the tour. We just used and enjoyed all the great faclities. There is a concert every night (sometimes two). They are all just an hour long and provide a variety of choices. There are many fine selections of classical music, performed by talented musicians. We tried a few but also attended one that featured Hollywood Movie music. Its the performers and the outstanding acoustics that we came to see and hear.If you buy tickets at the facility, be aware that they also sell tickets to other venues and on one occasion we were steered to a "box office window" that was selling tickets for other performances. That day, tickets to the performance we chose, being performed at SMETANA Hall at this facility was being sold at a table next to the box office. As long as you know what you want, there won't be a problem getting the right tickets.The performances that we attended were never full - we always got our tickets the day of or day before. Its a hall, not a theater, so you will not find inclined seating and therefore may not be able to see the stage sometimes. You can easily just move to another seat. There is usually quite a few open seats on the sides.The restaurants were quite nice. A Café and a French restaurant are on the ground floor level. Downstairs you will find the America Bar (second oldest in Europe) and the Pilsen Restaurant. We stopped in the Pilsen after one of the concerts but unfortunately couldn't stay to hear the accordionist or enjoy the Czech food - looked like a fun group; a definite choice for next time.

Absolutely wonderful and not to be missed. Our 2nd visit and we were as blown away as we were the 1st time. If you are a fan of Art Nouveau and Alphonse Mucha especially, DO NOT MISS THIS! The Restaurants and Bar are brilliant too.

Fans of art nouveau, take the tour!. This is not your average government building. We did not partake of a meal in either the first floor restaurant or coffee shop, but chose instead to take the building tour. Perhaps the most beautifully executed design and architecture in our experience, and rivals some of the great basilicas, synagogues and cathedrals in Europe for its beauty and character. It's a wonder that it survived the years of Communism relatively intact. Not to be missed!

Good choice. I had the opportunity to try the breakfast set menu (fresh coffee, fress bread and delicous eggs) - excellent choice. Tasty food, beautiful interiors and friendly staff - a must see in Prague!
Outstanding Building. Prague is full of amazing architecture and this is a prime example of art nouveau style. Cafes and hall beautifully decorated and music insight and out.

Not for me. I went to an hour long concert of classical musical that featured opera and ballet. I had very mixed feelings for it. For the concert it was just okay. My favorite portion of it was the opera singer, who I thought that did a great job. Unfortunately, for the amount of money for a ticket it is not worth the time. The seats are VERY uncomfortable and the air-conditioning is lacking. It is a beautiful building but you do not need to waste your money on the classical concert to appreciate it. You will get more bang for your concert by simply looking at the exterior and walking inside. If you do go, do not waste your money on the more expensive tickets there is really no point.

Art Nouveau Lobby. You can get a sense of the grandeur of this Art Nouveau wonder by popping into the lobby and wandering around a few rooms until you get told to put your camera away. I was told the next tour was in a couple of days. Going by what other reviewers say it seems quite difficult to get on a tour. The municipal hall was built between 1905 & 1910. It was here that the newly independent state of Czechoslovakia was signed into existence just after WW1.

Do pop in for a look at a beautiful building. The Municipal House is a fantastic example of Art Nouveau architecture. We came across it by accident and wandered in for a quick look around. Even if you're not planning on a drink in the American bar downstairs or taking in a concert at the concert hall, it's worth popping in to see the ornate decoration.

The Greatest Art Nouveau Building in Europe?. That's what they claim and I don't doubt it. Restored after the Revolution, all of the rooms in this building, from the concert halls to the café to the American bar and even the beer hall and especially the gift shop are treasures in and of themselves. If you like Art Nouveau, you will get your fill in this big beautiful building.

Municipal house. We were not able to go inside. The tour we were with said not enough people signed up to go in. But would have been helpful to know you can to to the Municipal house yourself and sign up for a guided tour. They only have a set amount for the day so sign up early in the morning or a day ahead. We were unfortunately unable to go inside but the actual building with the architecture was amazing. Loved Prague!!!
Beautiful. I've never seen an Art Nouveau building in such wonderful order. Full of original features - very impressive for architecture or antiques lovers

Amazing building. The design and upkeep of this super building were excellent.It also contained a great concert hall but it could only be seen by paying. Art Nouveau restaurants were beatiful and not too pricey but no photos were allowed
Ok, but I would stay for a show. Very elegant building, we did the one hour English tour in order to see properly the place. I would recommend staying for a show though
Gorgeous. This is an absolutely stunning building. Never visited inside but it looked beautiful and I would imagine a concert or an opera would be amazing to see here.
Obecni Dum. Building par excellence. The kavarna on ther ground floor worth a visit, but unless you enjoy the mediocre do not eat in the basement restaurant.

Excellent food, great architecture, fun tour!. There are several restaurants in the Municipal House and we enjoyed a delicious lunch at the one on the main floor for a reasonable price and splurged on a decadent desert. We then took the tour of this building and learned so much more about it's history. After touring many palaces, castles, etc. in Europe, it was a treat to see a restored Art Deco/Art Nouveau building with so much original structures intact. Since I love that era, this was a special treat. Definitely worth the tour. We finished it up with a very well mixed drink in the American Bar downstairs.

6pm and 8pm classical music concerts - for tourists. Building is beautiful, we bought tickets for a concert in Smetana Hall. The 8-piece orchestra was professional, the acoustics excellent. But there was no special feeling of elation, no rapport with the audience and it felt like this was something the musicians did for summer money. The prices were definitely for tourists and the audience was indeed entirely tourists. The cheapest tickets were 750 CZK whereas Czech friends told me they would pay that kind of price for a full performance for the most expensive tickets. We were there in July when the Czech Philharmonic is on its break. What it was was 60 minutes exactly of well-known classical melodies. The hall in July was almost empty. If the charge had been half as much, the hall might have been full.The most expensive tickets are 1590 CZK and there is just no point. The seats are hardly any distance apart from each other, the seats are all very uncomfortable (wooden) so if you want to go, for an opportunity to see the hall and experience a pleasant concert, I'm happy to recommend the lowest price - we didn't do that but saw there was hardly any difference between the rows our seats were in and the lower prices. This was why I gave it an "average" score - the shortness of the performance and the price compared to Czech prices but again, I reiterate, not to retract from the beautiful hall and first-class musicians.
A must visit place in Prague. Take the tour of the building and see all of the restored rooms. Very stylish and oppulent and if you get the same guide as us very informative.

Passioned and technically great concerts in a stunishing building. We have assisted and enjoyed a Saturday 8am concert, a kindouf best of Mozart and Dvorak convcert, with a little Schubert as add on. Well, very nice atmomosphere in this prestigious building, good performance of 5 violins, 1 contrabass and 1 cello, passioned play... could be even better if they would play a little less pieces and explain the background of what they play, the time the piece was written, for whom... But anyhow to recommend if you like classical music or want to feel the passion that the musicians greatly let you feel.
You don't need to enter. Just visit this amazing building twice, once when it is illuminated at night. It is enough to remember it for ever. Restaurants are expensive.
Good but average value for money. Attended a concert on 24 June.Was told by several people in Prague that it has the best sound system, indeed it was very nice but value for money is not that great.
never lost his charm. the place i knew for at laest 30 years alwayes was a landmark/ acofee house for meeting and above all a concert house not expencive very popular

Amazing architecture!. This building was near our hotel and we passed it all the time. It was beautiful. Make sure you go inside to see all the beauty as well. There are two restaurants and a theatre inside this building. Restaurants are expensive for dinner, but they will let you go to the door and look in and take photos without flash! I couldn't stop admiring this building.

Exceeded my expectations. Loved its Baroque style. The upstairs reception rooms had murals depicting scenes of Czech history. There was a pub in the basement that offered great food. The Gift Shop in the basement is really worth a visit.

Go to a show. any show at this theatre. You will not be disappointed. An amazing building with acoustics to match. We attended a classical concert with some ballet dancing and opera singing. Forget about the more expense seats in the middle of the main floor. Go for cheaper ones up close or try for the first few balcony rows for the best views. The main floor seats are on a flat floor not a sloped theatre style floor you maybe used to.
Master piece architecture and deco. plus book tiickets for a classical program in this building, promise of an enchanting evening build around classical, lyrical and ballet arts

Attractive building. This building is definitely hard not to notice because very attractive from outside. Big Fresco at the top of the entrance makes it look like a museum not a civic building.Lots of concert takes place here.Right at the entrance there is a very fancy restaurant serving expensive food.

Beautiful building, DON'T GO TO THE CAFE. tl;dr: Go to the Municipal House, take the tour, and don't eat at the cafe because the service is TERRIBLE— I made an order, and it was NOT EVEN PLACED.The Municipal House itself is worth a visit— a fantastic example of the total work ideal of art nouveau. It would be well worth your time and money, too, to take the hour-long guided tour of the rooms. And after you explore and tour the rooms, DON'T EAT AT THE CAFE.I had one of the worst service experiences of my life at this cafe. Wanting to have a bite to eat before my tour, I went to the cafe. I took forever for a waiter to actually come to my table, when he explained (not apologetically) that he had other groups to serve. Okay. I ordered a coffee. He began to walk away, before I could order any food! I had to actually say "Wait!" to keep him from striding off.I explained— slowly, to be careful that my English was understood—that I had a tour in (by the time he got to me) half an hour. I wanted the vegetable dish. Could that be ready before my tour?He explained to me that this was an appetizer. I told him I understood, but that was what I wanted. Some time later, our coffees arrived. I asked if the dish was on its way. He said yes.With ten minutes before our tour and no food in sight, we stopped our waiter— a task, I assure you, as he totally avoided us— and asked where our food was. He explained that we had ordered an appetizer, and that would not be enough food. HE HAD NOT EVEN PLACED OUR ORDER. What-the-patronizing-f***. Seriously, you can go to so many wonderful restaurants and cafes in Prague. DON'T eat here.

It's a museum of itself. This building is a symbol of a perfect Art Nouveau style. Every room, staircases, doors, decorations, lamps, all of this is renovated and done exactly as it was built originally. The house contains one of the most famous music halls, two restaurants and a bevy of rooms where high-class exhibitions are open to public. Even its exterior is something to be admired a frequently photographed. For lovers of early 20th Century architecture is a must.

Opulent building shines with jewel-like extravagant details.. Bijoux, best describes its extravagant facade and lines..... sumptuous decoration,pale ochre coloration,glazed copper domes which contrasts with the sombre stone work of its neighbours. It has something for everyone,whether seated in the superb surroundings of its classic coffee house or dine in its gastronomic eatery or carouse to a symphonic concert. The spirit of the place is uplifting,the beauty of its fittings, staircases, elevators and the cutest of cloakroom. i am particularly touched by the filigree metalwork and jewel-like encrustations. Outside,the plaza buzzes with a lively ambiance.

An extraordinary venue for balls.. The main hall is breathtaking. I have always been there for classic balls and for that it is perfect. Lots of room, lots of different halls to see and dance in. All in all it's an incredible experience.

Full of Surprises. We did not visit this wonderful establishment until very recently. But the variety of the rooms, décor and furnishings were truly world class. Art Deco superb, vaulted cellars and original tiling. Great find.

Amazing Art Nouveau Municipal Hall. Wow! We love this hall - we've been to visit 3 times in our 2 visits to Prague. It was designed and decorated by a group of amazing Art Nouveau and Art Deco artists and architects, including Alphonse Mucha. Wandering the building is fun, but only gets you so far - sign up for a tour! The hall is still used for concerts and even athletic events; it would be great to see a concert here.

Incredible experience!. We were lucky enough to have a chance to explore this outstanding Art Nouveau building on our own before attending a concert there. Wow - beauty in every detail! The concert in Smetana Hall was truly memorable. The acoustics are outstanding and the venue is visually stunning. The program of Mozart and Dvorak works made for an experience we will never forget. There is a plethora of wonderful performances in Prague every night of the week, but if you go to just one concert while in the city, make sure to attend one here!!!!!

Fabulous Art Nouveau Building. If you are into Art Nouveau and Art Decco, this is a must! Both exterior and interior are breathtaking. There are multiple restaurants and bars beautifully preserved in their 1911-1920s livery. Exquisite motifs and design. You won't be disappointed!
Art Nouveau at its best!. This building is a jewel of Art Nouveau; unfortunately we did not have the time to go inside, but I have seen photos and it is definitively worth to explore it

Beautiful Experience. I was able to attend a concert in the Municipal House when I was in Prague in June. That gave me the opportunity to explore the building before and after the event. It is a visual treat. Take time to look around and make note of the way all of the design elements work together in this showstopper of a building. The concert featured the Prague Music Orchestra. If you get a chance to hear one of this group's performances, be sure that you do!

Beauty and art exist in every space. The art Nouveau stained glass, murals and architecture make this building a masterpiece. The acoustics is brilliant. No performer required a microphone that is so common today with our untrained singers. That is how pitch perfect this art hall is compared to newer building. Shows change daily and are affordable. Get your ticket the day of and don't worry about hearing or seeing the stage. I wish when I first arrived in country I had bought tickets for every night!
Beautiful. This building is so beautiful inside and out. The windows and lights are amazing. So much atmosphere here.
Stunnung. loved everything about this place, wnt to see la traviata and could not have asked for anything more amazing

Art Deco heaven. I have never been in a building like this in my entire 61 years. It can only be described as breathtaking. You can go to a concer, opera, performance or go downstairs for a meal or a drink. It's like stepping back to the 1920/30's. My husband assures me the beer is good - I don't drink. The food is also very varied and yummy!

Breakfast with Roman. This is a lovely restaurant with high ceilings, huge windows, wonderful decor and classic architecture. But what made it a memorable experience for us was our waiter, Roman. He has worked here for 17 years. He is a mix of professionalism, humor, and desire to serve. It was the first time I finished a breakfast with a strong drink, which may not be as unusual in Prague as it is in the states. Delicious food, excellent service, lovely setting and a great start to another magical day in this charming city.

The jewel of prague.. In my opinion the most beautiful building of prague,a chef d'oeuvre of art nouveau:it's guilt balconies,glass dome and the impressive mosaic on the front are a magnificent sign of what art can achieve for the pleasure of our eyes.the fact it is next to the powder tower gives it even an added value.

Highlight of our Prague Trip. We are big fans of the Art Nouveau style. We went to Europe for a month recently. We visited lots of cities, many of which with considerable Art Nouveau roots. By far, Prague was our favorite Art Nouveau city and the Municipal House was our favorite Art Nouveau destination in Prague. If you are a fan of Art Nouveau, make sure you budget to spend some time here. We would highly recommend the tour of the facility, which for a small fee you get a guided tour to see many of the rooms and grandure of the Municipal House ... including the Mucha room. I took so many pictures I thought I was going to max out our camera's memory card! Also, there are at least 4 restaurants inside the Municipal house that you can visit, have a bite, and take in the ambiance. If you are strapped for cash, a good amount of the Municipal House is available for free or the cost of a drink or bite in the restaurants. However, we loved the tour too.

Great performance in stunning Art Nouveau concert hall. At short notice I went to a performance by the Prague Chamber Orchestra in the Smetana Hall in the art nouveau Municipal House. It was a popular program aimed at tourists - Eine kleine nachtmusik and Vivaldi's Four Seasons. It was nice to hear this beuatiful music again, played with precision and vigor. The only oddity was the audience who applauded after every movement. Is this a Prague thing or an indication that the patrons were new to the concert hall? The Municipal House is brilliant. Next time I am in Prague I will go on a tour. The building was designed by Balsanek and Polivka and incorporates stained glass and mosaics by notable artists including Alphonse Mucha. There is a beautiful restaurant as well. It looks quite expensive but has lunchtime specials.

Art Nouveau paradise. From the exterior to the rooms you see on the 45-minute tour everything is gorgeous. The exterior, with its mosaic of Prague as a lady, is just a foretaste of what's inside. My friend and I spent several hours exploring the place, which is not a government office building but an architectural expression of Czech pride built at great cost in a nationalistic fervor against Austro-Hungarian occupation. You can be enthralled by the elevators, stairwells, tile work, etc. even if you do not spring for the tour. Make sure to go downstairs to the bars below to see the wall fountain and admire the architectural elements. I spent $25 US to go on the tour, go into the Art Nouveau special exhibit (two amazing rooms, from furniture and posters to dresses, including the painful undergarments required to squeeze into the dresses), and buy the photo pass necessary to take photos during the tour. And it was WORTH the cost. The tour takes you into the Smetana Hall (which you can see for free if you attend a concert there), the ladies' and men's salons featuring matching patterns in the lace draperies, furniture, and walls, a breathtaking room of Mucha murals of important moments in Czech history, and a large hall with really cool chandeliers. This feeble attempt to describe the glories of the Municipal Hall cannot come close to dong justice to it. There is also a nice gift shop, Modernista, which offers books on art nouveau and nice pieces by contemporary artists. The French restaurant just off the entrance looks wonderful from the outside, but seemed awful pricey to me.

We took 2 tours and we well worth it.. The building is magnificient, as is its history. Unfortunately, no photos were allowed. Our guide was particularly enthusiastic and proud of her Czech heritage. Her endlish needed some work though.
We were able to listen to the orchestra practising for the nights performance. I am returning, hopefully next year, for a concert.

Wonderful Nouveau concert venue. This is a great Art Nouveau concert hall in central Prague, a real jewel. We saw a concert here with the Scottish National Symphony Chorus, and the acoustics were superb. It also made me think of Charles Rennie Mackintosh (pretentious, moi?). One of the best places for catching a real concert in Prague.

Smetana hall is a jewel. Smetana hall is located in the municipal building and is easy to find. There are several good restaurants on the ground floor of the building which provide a good selection for dinner before the performance. The hall itself is located on the first floor and is the most beautiful performing venue in the city( in my humble opinion). Acoustics are perfect and it's a great way to spend the evening listening to classical music away from the madhouse of tourists just outside the building.
a must to see in praque. a must to see in praque with its youth style ( jungen stil) buiding. ..................................
Beautiful!. A wonderful example of Art Nouveau. The cafe is beautiful and worth a stop for a break. Could be crowded.

Wow. Gorgeous Art Nouveau Building!. This building is one of the most beautiful I have seen. The Art Nouveau aesthetic is magnificent throughout, including the light fixtures, metal work, ceramic wall tiles and breathtaking windows. Take the building tour in order to see the rooms that are not ordinarily open to the public. Try to go to see the Prague Symphony in the building's Smetana Hall for an outstanding experience for both your ears and eyes. A must see in Prague.

What a beauty . This place is really out of this world:)We are in the fine dining room with a very large party. The service was impeccable, food delicious and I really enjoyed the piano player:)The architecture itself is awe inspiring!Loved it:)-Genene & Jason

For Lovers of Art Deco. If you are a lover of art deco, be sure to visit the Municipal House when in Prague. Not having a lot of time to spend, we passed on paying the entry fee to view the exhibits on the upper floors but did take some pictures in the restaurant and of the lower floor... stained glass, architecture, etc... as well as of the exterior which is beautiful. The day we were there, many art students all around working on sketches.

Art Nouveau. only visited part of interior but exterior is wonderful also. We were not able to take the tour of building but the part we saw was beautiful. The entrance and stained glass are not to be missed. One of highlights of Prague.
Great exhibitions. Municipal House is a beautiful building. I visited 2 exhibitions there while in Prague and really enjoyed both.

Wonderful art deco theater. We attended a Prague Spring concert featuring the Bamberger Orchestra at Municipal House, preceded by dinner outside at the restaurant there. We were able to obtain the last 2 seats, which were in the last row of the balcony. At home, we attend the Cleveland Symphony at Severance Hall. The venue was beautiful art deco, and the concert was great, and we had no trouble seeing or hearing from our seats. Dinner at the restaurant was also delicious and lovely, with an exquisite strudel for dessert.

Great Art Nouveau exhibit. Beautiful building with a great Art Nouveau exhibit. We had tea and cake in the lovely cafe after visiting the exhibit. The cakes were just okay, and the woman pushing the cake cart around was incredibly rude. Still definitely worth a visit, especially if you're a fan of Art Deco and/or Art Nouveau.

Well worth it. Considering what the country has been through in the 20th century it is remarkable how well this glorious art nouveau building has survived. Designed and built as a statement of Czech pride in advance of the formation of the nation state each of a dozen or so (?) rooms included in the tour exhibit decorative art and design from around 1910 with a room designed and painted by Mucha for me the highlight. Largely ignored by the Nazis and communists all but fabrics survived in surprisingly good condition. If the work of Mackintosh speaks to you, you will love this.

I'd rather give six stars!!. This was my second visit to this wonderful art nouveau building, perhaps the best of its kind in the world if, like me, you are a fan of the architecture, painting and decorative arts around the turn of the 20th Century. The public areas are already stunning, including the Americky Bar, the magnificent French restaurant, the café and the eccentric jugendstil / folk pub. Take the one-hour tour and you will see additional rooms, each one more impressive than the last, finishing off in the truly superb mayor's hall, decorate with wall and ceiling paintings by Alfons Mucha. The building is dominated by the Smetana Hall, a wonderful concert hall which is the main venue for the Prague Spring series of concerts. We attended one of the concerts (Richard Strauss Lieder and Mahler's 1st Symphony), probably the top highlight of our four days in Prague.

Art Nouveau at its best. Did this one hour tour of this wonderful building and we both thoroughly enjoyed the many rooms you are shown on the tour.The main concert hall was stunning as were the many and unique other furnished rooms .Very well maintained and preserved this tour is well worthwhile.Gabrielle was our guide and she had outstanding knowledge of the building and made the tour very enjoyable.
Restaurant. Go to the restaurant. It's diner style but high end. Not in cost but in feel. They were amazing and I had to order twice because the food was that good.

Gorgeous art nouveau decor. Enjoyed a cocktail in the lower ground floor bar. Stunning decor and great service. While we didn't eat in the restaurant or cafe, but all areas had the same beautiful art nouveau decor, it really was a pleasure to visit this well preserved building with various options for a cocktail or dining experience.
Wonderful Arte Nouveau Building. Superb interiors and when we visited a fascinating exhibition on Arte Nouveau design, pottery and glass and, posters and costumes. Well worth a visit.

Don't miss the Kaverna. This is a must see on your visit but make sure you go inside the building. Follow the stairs into the basement to the Kaverna restaurant and have a coffee at least. The Art Deco decorations are well preserved.

Unbelievably beautiful. My husband and I Had a delightful lunch in the cafe. Great service. Then took the one hour tour. Since I bought the camera ticket I was allowed to take as many pictures as I liked. The place was amazing. I think I took more than 50 pictures while listening to a very informative guide. Excellent tour and facility. I highly recommend a visit.

Nice interior, but pricey concert tickets. It was an interesting experience to attend a concert amidst the art nouveau architecture and hearing the building's excellent acoustics. But at 30 euros a ticket (cheapest category), I do not think it is value for money. The hall also uses a flat seating configuration instead of tiered system, hence you may not be able to get a good view if you are blocked by someone in front. Will recommend to attend a guided tour instead if your aim is to see the building interior.

A lovely surprise for art nouveau fans. My husband and I did a guided tour and although he was not that keen to go, he enjoyed it as much as I did. It is a spectacular building and our guide made the tour interesting and humorous. The building features beautiful examples of the art nouveau style and there are lots of "wow" moments as you move from room to room. You can go inside the building for free and see what all the fuss is about, but the guided tour takes you into rooms that are locked off to the public. Well worth the price and a must for art nouveau fans.

Splendid. If Art Nouveau isn't your thing, don't visit. It is mine, and I thought it wonderful. We had a good look all around the ground and basement floors, and enjoyed coffee and cake in the cafe. For a more detailed visit you can join a tour.

Wonderful place. We had the pleasure of visiting the Municipal House for a classical concert as well as a guided tour. The Art Nouveau building will take your breath away. The concert tickets price was also much more reasonable than we expected.

Not up to my taste.. We went in only to have a look and we didn't like what we saw. Liberty stile is not for us, Art Deco neither, so, despite huge affluence this was one of the least liked places in Prague.

As Art Nouveau fans we loved this place. We booked the guided tour in English and ate lunch at the French restaurant. The best thing about the tour was seeing all the lovely Art Nouveau design touches throughout the building - especially by Alphons Mucha in the Mayor's Room. The big surprise was the "Business Lunch" at an affordable price that allowed us to enjoy the atmosphere of the restaurant. Mind you - the food was pretty good too. A nice extra was that the tour tickets allowed us to buy nice champagne at half price in the American Bar.

Spectacular building. We attended a concert that included the New World Symphony, and what a spectacular hall in which to hear it. We had to get past a very rude woman on the door, but by then had got used to rudeness in Prague, and the seats were grossly overpriced, and that is another thing one has to grow rapidly accustomed to when travelling in Europe

You should push the boat out for this visit.. This is not a cheap place to go to , but for value for money it is one of the top places to visit. The class of this place has to be seen , if you can get to see a performance great , but if not just a look inside is well worth it.

Gorgeous art nouveau building. We went here for the art nouveau exhibition upstairs, followed by a lovely Easter Monday lunch in the luxurious french restaurant, and it was definitely worth going. The restaurant was absolutely stunning, left exactly as it was in the early 1900, and the food was gorgeous too. Staff were polite and spoke good English. If you are going to Prague, you definately have to treat yourself to this unique place!

Wonderful experience!. We had the chance to find a concert and enjoyed a wonderful experience in a beautiful concert hall!The place also holds a top restaurant, a cafe and a beer tavern which is quite popular in town.

Another historic Prague music venue. Grand and beautiful as with most other Prague music venues. Ensure you get an allocated seat at booking off-site otherwise be prepared for a run-around at the venue. Walking distance to Wenceslas square, Palladium and Old Town Square. Directly opposite the Powder tower.

a masterpiece of Art Deco style. the place is fantastic, the brasserie is very good, the restaurant is a bit expansive but it`s worth it and the theatre is good to see, not as great as the rest but...just avoid the touristy concerts played by average artists who obviously do that without any interest except a bit of pocket money!

only if you have tickets for an event. Otherwise you unfortunately cannot see anything except the old cafe, which is just average. but if you can attend a music event in the Smetana hall - just go for it. it is an Art Deco hall, which is impressive. And the standard of classic music events is in Prague generally very high

Excellent alternative to a church concert. This is a beautiful venue with amazing acoustics. We attended a Mozart concert performed by a small ensemble of violinists and cellists. The cheapest seats are $35, more expensive than a church concert, which was $20-$25. However, I found the musicians to be of high quality. Inside the building is much warmer than inside of most churches (i.e. Church of St. Nick in Old Town), making the experience very pleasant with comfortable seating.

Fearsome. Loved the building and the tour and the 2 for 1 drink in the American bar at the end. Didn't like the way the guide treated a Japanese tourist who had an electronic translator to help him. She had said 'no mibile phones' and later claimed she'd also said 'no electronic devices' but she would not listen to him and was very rude. At the end of the tour she did listen to his explanation and apologise, but by then it was too late and he was feeling upset and humiliated.

Prague's Art Nouveau Highlight. The Municipal House is one of the symbols of Czech identity. Built in 1912, it was, together with the National Museum and the National Theatre, an expression of self awareness towards Vienna, then capital of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, which Bohemia was a part of. It is one of the most beautiful buildings in the city, housing a concert hall, several spaces for exhibitions, a French and a Pilsner restaurant, a beautiful cafe (Try the "Chocolate dream" cake!) and the stylish American Bar, the first one in Prague where women could go without male company. One can book guided tours (mainly in in English) to see the marvellously designed meeting rooms and conference halls on the first floor together with the main concert hall named after the famous composer Bedřich Smetana. The hall is home to the opening concert of the annual Prague Spring festival.

Non-smokers and allergic people alert!!. The cafe at Municipal House (Gemeindehaus) is a tourist trap. Always full, very poor air quality. Upstairs is supposed to be non-smoking, but all the smoke from downstairs drifts upstairs. There are at all times 5-20 people smoking downstairs so the air is really bad. This cafe is a NO GO for non-smokers and allergic people.

Breathtaking building. Learned the interior was decorated by Mucha. The exterior is worth 20 minutes of oooohing and aaahing alone. First floor contains a luxury restaurant with a nice menu and a café for more pedestrian fare. I did not attend a show but they have regular concerts. Lovely!
A real Art Noveau Gem. Fantastic house with a fantastic interior. Do not miss the American Bar downstairs. Oldest and finest bar in Prague.

Art deco masterpiece. Take the tour of this building. Although the restaurants and the outside are lovely, the tour takes you upstairs to the concert hall and the gathering rooms surrounding it. Many of the furnishings are original.

Gorgeous Architecture. Before my travels to Prague, I didn't even have this building on the list of things to do. Boy, was I wrong. This was one of my favorite structures in the entire city, and I highly recommend stopping by for some awe-inspiring photos.
Great find!. This is a beautiful art nouveau building with a great cafe and upmarket restaurant on the ground floor. We saw a brilliant art nouveau exhibition that was one of our highlight in Prague.

A BEAUTIFUL ART NOUVEAU BUILDING. The New Municipal House Hall of the city is an amazing Art Nouveau building, where Art Nouveau exhibitions and concerts take place. We visited only the cafe, having our breakfast, as we arrived at Praque very early in the morning.The inside of the cafe has great decoration and the breakfast we had was amazing. They serve three types of breakfast, the English, french and czech. The only thing we had to complain about, is the slow service.

Very interesting tours in a range of languages. We went on the English language tour. The guide was very clear, well informed, with a good sense of humour. The internal decoration, the woodwork, the paintings make this Hall a fascinating place to visit. At an extra cost one can go to a special Art Nouveau exhibition which is really marvellous. The only negative of the vsit was the expensive shop with disinterested staff.
Pure art nouveau. Epitome of A.N. externally and internally. A wow. Wandering around the building was a delight. Also saw the exhibition Art Nouveau on until 2015. Highly recommended.

Catch a concert if you can!. When going to Prague most will walk by and see the Municipal house but most missed out on actually admiring the true beauty that comes from its purpose in the inside, a concert hall. The symphony and other venues occupy this grand hall often throughout the year and tickets seem to be readily available for those interested. The detail inside is amazing and there no better way to absorb a countries culture than through the expression of its arts.

Nice Concert Venue. I enjoyed a wonderful concert here listening to my daughter's high school symphony perform, with another orchastra from Leipzeig. While this performance hall has ben restored, it is not a "gold-guilded, mosaic-tiled, glittery" space. The stage is backed by the hall's center-piece; it's huge organ pipes. The seating is simple rows of wooden folding chairs. I would not bother paying money to see this space via a guided tour…unless I've missed something special behind the curtain or under the stage.
Worth your time. The interior décor of this building is wonderful. There is room that was designed by Alfons Mucha, but the other rooms and main auditorium is beautiful.

The best place in Prague. The building is amazing, there was an exhibition of Art Nouveau and it couldn't get any better. I spent more than 3 hours enjoying all the beautiful artifacts. It felt like a dream
do not mis this!. Great building designed by Alphonse Mucha - really impressive!We walked around in the building for nearly an hour: no entrance-fee!
Informative and beautiful. It was a very informative tour and the halls are beautiful. Also got a lot of insight to the Czech history and arts.

This is not a review for building but for management!. Our time in Prague was limited, and we didn't want to miss this opportunity to visit here. So we got online tickets in advance. Yes, the building is beautiful and we highly recommend the tour to go inside. Everybody else got explanations in their own language. Asked our guide for English one but was told it's not available because tour would be in English. But there were times we couldn't hear at the back of other people. Asked specific question but the guide was very annoyed and rude. So no more questions and we all felt so uncomfortable for the rest of the tour. At the end we were told to go downstairs at the bar and show the tickets to get drinks for discount price. We went down with the rest of the people on the tour, and we were turned down by the again rude waiters for not having the righr tickets. We were the only ones turned down and basically they said this piece of paper is meaningless. Well, that's the online ticket for the tour we got in advance! We felt embarrassed when everyone else was going in to the bar. So went upstairs to complain but was told the same thing. Felt very discriminated. Would give five star for the beautiful historical building but one for the most unpleasant experience we ever had.

Wonderful Art Nouveau Exhibition. An amazing building. Grand, opulent, art nouveau. We visited especially for the Art Nouveau Exhibition (which was excellent and shockingly empty of visitors. Had it been at the V&A there would be queues). The orchestra was rehearsing in the beautiful main hall. The cafe/brasserie: a lovely interior but smelled of school dinners, and having planned to eat in the elegant main restaurant were 'greeted' by an incredibly rude man (no wonder they only had four diners), so returned to our favourite Cafe Slavia. The cocktail bar in the basement also worth a visit. The vast empty cloakroom awaiting 500 coats is a wonderful image and quite as interesting an interior as any of the art nouveau flourishes throughout the building.

hidden gem. We found this after visiting the Mucha Museum (which is also brilliant by the way). There we found that Mucha had been involved in the external and internal design features of the municipal House/ palace. When we found it near Namessi Republicki we ventured inside and downstairs found a gem of a bar called the bar Americki which is straight out of the late 19th century. We had two cappuccinos for 120Ck total as it was too early for the rather lovely sounding cocktails. Will definitely be going back.This is one for Gatsby fans.

Guided tour the best. This building is an amazing art nouveau master piece, doing the guided tour (with the additional photo pass, which costs extra) is the best way to see this building, the interiors are worth the tour fee, with designs by the Czech art nouveau masters including Alphonse Mucha
Amazing castle. Amazing castle .. excellent for tourists .. loads to see and do .. and very safe day and night .. and lots of food and drink .. very clean

1 Hour of Beauty. We went to the smaller hall where appr 13 musicians preformed.We are not classical music buffs but really enjoyed ourselves and were disappointed when it ended. good value (if over 60 ask about senior rates. (also got to tour the grand Hall quite spectacular.)

Coffee and cake. Wonderful building we had coffee and cake here and the cake trolley had to be seen spoiled for choice yes a little more expensive but on a par with Betty's in harrogate, the service was good would recommend
stunning. This is an architectural gem that has been beautifully restored and is worth a half day visit with one of the guided tours.

Coffee and cakes overpriced. The cafe is a great room in this art deco building but if you just want to view the room you can see in from outside. Tea, coffee and cakes (very average) very pricey. Go to Paul down the road at half the price.

For Music lovers. Worth paying for a ticket to watch a concert.
Mainly classical music. We unfortunately missed a concert with the San Francisco Symphony but they have daily concerts by local orchestras.

Beautiful building. The interior of this art deco building is truly stunning. We attended a late afternoon concert on the second floor and the ceiling had the most beautiful stained glass. The concert was inexpensive (around $35 for 2) and really beautiful music (Joseph Suk) with very talented musicians. We also ate lunch in the French restaurant off to the right of the lobby; but the food was really good and delicate - I think it was worth it although it was the most expensive meal we had in Prague. The service was exceptional and the restaurant itself if simply gorgeous. I was really pleasantly surprised by the interior and exterior beauty of the architecture all over the City of Prague; there is nothing like it NYC or even Paris...

Worth the time and expense. You really do have to see the inside of this building to appreciate it. Only by tour, or catching a concert, but the tour was well done and ended in the Mucha room which is worth the price of admission. Haunting artist.

Beautiful exterior and interior. I did a city tour and the guide informed us that the Municipal house has beautiful interior and we must go visit . The Municipal house usually has Opera and other concerts .In addition to that it has couple of restaurants and a bar at the -1 level .I went to the -1 level restaurant and the bar. It was beautiful with live jazz music . The bar was good and the bartender made some good cocktails . Good place to have dinner and some drinks .

A pleasant surprise!. We called in here for lunch on our first day in Prague (were tired after v early flight from UK) but a club sandwich and beer revived us. 'Grand' restaurant space and staff were efficient and friendly. Food was not particularly memorable but enjoyed being in such a lovely 'art deco' environment.

Music of feelings. Perfect place anyway! More expensive than Vienna Opera house . Reception service was not enough friendly. Any signs for the visitors (how to reach to the balcony and etc.) was absent.

let down by service. we have visited the municipal house before so were looking forward to our trip. the waitress was in a couldnt be bothered mood and 30 mins after entering and asking for the dessert trolley several times we give up.their loss as we took our business elsewhere
Great Pancakes!!. popped in here on my birthday and had some great pancakes!! the most decadent place I've ever eaten and it didn't matter that we were wearing jeans and trainers!!

Art deco highlight of Prague. If you don't treat yourself to a coffee or tea and cakes in this gorgeous setting whilst in Prague you will regret it forever!!! It's a bit pricey (only by Prague standards) but so elegant with old fashioned service. The restaurant is equally glamorous for splashing out in the evening. A beautiful building!!

Breakfast at the Ritz. We walked over a mile to enjoy breakfast here and it was well worth the trek. Good selection of breakfast items, and at 210kr a pop, very good value and a very pleasant way to start the day.

Lovely building. We first had lunch in the basement restaurant next to the American bar and then tea and cakes in the cafe on the ground level. Downstairs they tried a bit to hard to sell aperitifs, but the food was good. The cafe was slightly more expensive than other places around Prague, but what a wonderful place. It is worth a visit.
beautiful place. We had coffee and cake at the Municipal House, It was delicious. And you can enjoy and appreciate the beautiful arquiteture
Art Noveau Cafe. An excellent example of a Prague Art Noveau cafe. We had the Cafe latte and really enjoyed it.....the place just reverberates with culture.

Fabulous Art Noveau building and restaurant. We ate in the most beautiful restaurant and listened to a fantastic concert in the main hall. It's like sitting in an immaculately maintained piece of History. Avoid the pudding trolley and go for the pancakes!

Coffee and cake. We had coffee and a piece of cake at the Municipal House. We also had that some years ago and remembered how nice it was to have coffee and select exactly the piece of cake you want while you could listen to the piano. The coffee and lovely cake was still there, but unfortunately we didn't hit the pianoman this time although we came at around 15:00.

So many highlights. We found so much to enjoy here; not only did we get to a concert in the Smetana Hall, where we listened to Dvorak (Dvorak in Prague - what could be better?) but we found that there are no less than three restauarci, from a huge 500 seater to a classy posh place. We ate in the less expensive of the two smaller restaurants (the one on the left as you go in) and were blown away by the fabulous room, the live music and the great Czech food. And, of course, the friendliest of staff. So pleased were we that we returned the following day.
Beautiful building. This yellow building is next to republic Square. Nearby is Powder Tower and shopping mall. Comparing to other places, there is no that crowded here.

stunning!. We just wandered by on valentines day and then went back three more times. If you love art nouveau, this is THE place to go. Firstly we visited the French restaurant, where the interiors and food were spectacular. There is another richly decorated restaurant on the ground floor and a wonderful bar and Czech restaurant in the basement. We went back for a tour of the concert hall, majors room (decorated by Mucha no less) and other exquisite ladies and men's meeting rooms . Then we went back again for an art nouveau exhibition. The whole place is spectacular!
Wow. So I haven't seen a concert in years of this caliber. This is a MUST-DO! Listenig to Mozart and Dvorak put my mind in a different era! This is def a must see!!!

Go inside for a look if nothing else. A very interesting building - we enjoyed a typical Czech meal in the beer hall in the basement. If nothing else go in the building and wander around to admire the building and cafe/restaurants.You can also book concert tickets for the hall here - they have a seat plan so you can see exactly where you will sit.

Fantastic. A really fantastic example of Art Nouveau, the best in Prague for sure and probably one of the finest in Europe. There is a wonderful cafe serving a 3 course tourist menu for 10 euros or simply enjoy something from the cake trolley ( chocolate cheese cake was divine ) with a warming Irish coffee. There is also a huge bar downstairs which is very jolly and an upmarket American bar for a quick martini in Art Deco glam. HOWEVER, ON NO ACCOUNT GO TO A MUSIC CONCERT HERE!!! THE TICKETS ARE EXORBITANTLY EXPENSIVE, I PAID 1300 CZK AND THE CONCERT ONLY LASTED AN HOUR AND WAS A VERY AVERAGE PERFORMANCE. TO PUT THAT INTO PERSPECTIVE I SAW THE SAME PIECE IN VENICE FOR A THIRD OF THE PRICE.

If you like Art Nouveau....... One of the finest examples of Art Nouveau. Be sure to have time to eat in one of the restaurant or have a drink in one of the cafes to be able to fully appreciate the internal decorations, especially the light fittings in the ground floor cafe.Be sure to nose around, including downstairs to see the brilliant tiling. You can tour the Smetana Hall (in winter there are two tours a day, the first being at 1pm) or book to go to one of the performances.

Listened to Mozart. Well worth a visit to see the Art Nouveau cafe. We were lucky enough to attend a Mozart concert within Smetana Hall. Truly worth it and the organ is huge and really a fantastic experience to get to hear it in concert. Worth a visit.

GOOD ATMOSPHERE. Good atmosphere and good first night choice to book to get the feel of Prague. Music provided by guy playing piano accordion. Best bit was (even though I don't smoke and love the non smoking rules here) husband lit up cigarette after the meal!! Restaurant is big enough not to notice it though.

Art nouveau building, a bit variable service in restaurant. A beautiful building with stylish restaurant and café (and restaurant) on ground floor. We visited those two - the first for an evening meal and the second to try the hot chocolate on a cold, windy day. The restaurant had exellent food and a knowledgeable wine waiter who found the perfect Czech wine for our meal. I subtract one point for a somewhat familiar approach on his part - that sits ill with the style of the place! Also, as in the cafeteria, service may feel a bit slow at times. The cafeteria (on the left as you enter through the main doors) is likewise period perfect and classy. The chocolate excellent. Service has a touch of old-style communist times in being slow - however, that almost feels like positive nostalgia in this place... as long as the quality is so good otherwise. One feels one should wear a suit and tie here, and the ladies should attempt being pre-raphaelitic, pale and world-weary.

koncert. Visited the place for the first time in 4 years.It is a beautyful Building and the accustic is very very goodin the Smetana Hall.Prices for koncerts are resonobel.Try it and You will not forget or regretYou visited this place..
Municipal House. Municipal House is a stunning excellent of Art Nouveau architecture. It is worth paying for a tour to look at all the concert halls and rooms inside.
Beautiful. Loved the building! Although we only saw the main performance hall, it was a beautiful building. We saw the chamber orchestra perform, lovely sound!

beautiful building. we went through the main doors and went downstairs into the restaurant next to the American bar . we enjoyed some typical Czech food and beer at it was reasonably priced . The restaurant very clean and was typical of what I imagined a Czech restaurant would be . would recommend it to any visitors to prague 2nd January 2014
Afternoon tea - a must. Afternoon tea can be a set menu for £6 per person or you can vary your choice for slightly more - the film Triple X was shot here - fantastic art deco interior

Have to visit this building. The art nouveau architecture have a special perfume and you have to visit this beautiful place in Prague. Yuu can find a good and large restaurant in the basement of the building.
Take a tour!

Beautiful Music, Great Venue.. We listened to the Prague Music Orchestra playing a selection from Dvorak and Mozart in the beautiful Smetana Hall one winters evening. Although we both like classical music it was the first time we had listened to it live and 'up close and personal' and it was certainly no disappointment,Whilst there were only 8 musicians playing their music easily filled the hall and the acoustics meant that you could pick out the individual instruments which added to the experience for the pair of us.The hall itself is beautifully decorated and it must be quite a sight when all the seats are full and listening to a full orchestra.
What a fabulous place. Brilliant art nouveau architecture, inside and out. Take the tour! The art nouveau cafe serves wonderful snacks/meals. The larger restaurant in the basement has so-so food.

Go to a Prague Symphony concert. We went to the New Year's concert here. After the neck craning to see the hall, you'll enjoy a spectacular musical event. Ours was Dvorak' Slavonian Dances. And it was truly fabulous.

Lovely concert, highly recommended. Fantastic performance of Dvorak, Strauss, Mozart. Beautiful building, central location. Mostly tourists visiting, dressed the same way as they were dressed all day sightseeing, so no real point of stressing about black dress (unfortunately).

Prague’s signature Art Nouveau landmark. Anyone interested in modern art styles and architecture, particularly that of the late 19th and early 20th century, will be amazed by the exuberant Municipal House, one of the most iconic landmarks of the Czech capital and indeed one of the finest buildings in all of Europe. Located on Republic Square (public transport: Namesti Republiky metro station, line B), it is situated on the former grounds of King’s Court, of which the adjacent late gothic Powder Gate is the only remnant. It was built between 1905-1911 and celebrated its centennial anniversary in November 2012. I thoroughly enjoyed visiting this architectural jewel earlier this year. The building is a grand example of Art Nouveau, harmoniously blending other styles en vogue during that very creative period, especially Neo­Baroque, Neo­Renaissance and even elements of Art Deco.I took a guided tour in English which was very informative and well worth the admission fee. The highlights were the magnificent Smetana Hall, Prague’s largest concert hall, and the sumptuous Mayor’s Hall, decorated by Art Nouveau designer and key figure Alfons Mucha. I regret not having attended a concert, as the acoustics of the concert hall are superb. There are many strong historical connections, most notably the proclamation of an independent Czechoslovak Republic in the Smetana Hall in October 1918. Access to the lobby and the ground floor areas is free of charge. There is a stylish French restaurant on the right (Francouszka Restaurace) and an equally impressive Municipal House Café on the left, buzzing with tourists and locals, attracted by its atmospheric décor, delicious breakfasts and decadent cakes. Both the Café and the French restaurant are a feast of Art Nouveau, boasting high ceilings, large windows and mirrors and elaborate period chandeliers with lots of crystal and gold.From the lobby you can go down a large staircase – with beautiful ceramic tiles on the walls- leading to the swanky American Bar –claiming to be Prague’s oldest bar- and to the “Pilsen Restaurant” (Plzenska Restaurace) decorated like a German beer hall, serving an outstanding Pilsen beer. The elegant ground floor restaurant offers refined French dining (fine seafood, escargots and foie gras among other delicacies), while the more popular Pilsen restaurant downstairs is a hearty, traditional Czech food affair, often with live music. I had lunch in the latter and can confirm that the food was excellent and the waiters were prompt and friendly. Apart from a permanent exhibition displaying a copy of St Wenceslas crown (the original being kept at Prague Castle), the Municipal House is host to various temporary exhibitions, currently the most notable being “Vital Art Nouveau 1900”, showcasing a selection of the most remarkable masterpieces of European and Czech Art Nouveau (open daily 10 am – 7 pm, admission 150 CZK, discounts for children, students and seniors).There are daily concerts, mostly classical music performed by the Prague Philharmonic and Classic Orchestra, but also Opera with Ballet and even Jazz. Guided tours in English and Czech (90 min) are scheduled on a regular basis in the afternoon, costing CZK 290 (£ 8.80 / $ 14.50 / € 10.60), with a 15% discount for Prague Card holders (www.prague.fm/12488/prague-discount-card). Please check the official website for the latest schedule (www.obecnidum.cz/en/). The admission price included a token exchangeable for a drink in the American Bar downstairs. You certainly won't be disappointed visiting the Municipal House (on your next stay) in Prague, but please plan enough time to attend a concert ! Marius C. Berger, MDLondon, UK

A Haven. We traipsed the streets of Prague for three days site seeing, never using public transport and this stunning building with its Art Nouveau interior was very close to our hotel and became our haven. Whether it was just for a coffee after our dinner or a late meal after a concert it was perfect. It is obviously a tourist attraction but we always found the staff friendly and welcoming ( possibly due to several visits and generous tipping)

Art Nouveau at its best!. It's hard to believe that during the communist era, this beautiful building was locked up for 41 years and no one was allowed to use it. What is it with those communists? Anyway, the building is now back in full swing and has concerts at very reasonable prices, compared to the prices for concerts in Australia. There are a number of rooms (or parlours) that can be hired for private events although our guide said the rooms were expensive. You do have to pay a fee to take photographs in the Hall, but there are some stunning examples of art work and decoration. Well worth the visit. The Cafe downstairs has the most fabulous cakes and coffee and is certainly good value.

Municipal House Cafe. Sadly, the interior was the best part. The staff is so used to hating tourists that the unsmiling and rude waiter didn't add to our visit. The cafe was average that you can get anywhere, the cake was just a cake, wine was OK. I suggest people avoid this place that is aimed at clueless tourists.

A beautiful building with interesting features. What was to have been just one short visit, turned into a bit of a marathon over 3 days. We first went into the Prague Municipal House to book tickets for an early evening concert, then decided to indulge with coffee and cream cakes in the Kavarna, which were dellghtful, as were the surroundings, which included a jazz group playing. The next day we went to the concert in the small concert hall and enjoyed a concert of chamber music. After the concert, we decided to splash out on a meal in the Francouzska restaurant in the building. The meal was superb with a really good Czech wine recommended by the wine waiter. On the third day we reurned to the Kaverna for the set lunch before leaving Prague. The price of the meals in the Kaverna were modest and those in the Francouska were expensive, but it was a very enjoyable experience to go to such an iconic Czech institution. The building with it's Art Nouveau features, was truly magnificent.
Beautiful building at city cross roads. Well cleaned and restored,this beautiful building has a restaurant on ground floor and hosts art exhibitions and classic music concerts throughout year,

Stunning building with beautiful art. The Municipal House Hall is beautiful inside and out, and visiting there is a must for Art Nouveau fans. We took a guided tour which focused more on the art presented in the building, which is absolutely beautiful and meaningful and made us want to get know more about Alfons Mucha, who drew many of the pictures. Many of the people visiting didn't speak English and were walking with the group reading the material in their native language, which can make the tour a bit "dead", but I guess it depends on the specific group. I also think the tour could relate more to the history of the building. Yet again- highly recommended for art and/or architecture enthusiasts.

Brilliant!. The design is incredible. I love all the details, the tile, the ironwork, the script of the signs. We attended a concert in Smetana Hall and it was lovely in there. I will say that the seats could have been more comfortable, however. And, whether you dine there or not, check out the interior of the restaurants, particularly the French one. Encroyable.

Boring. If you're not intending to go in for a concert/opera/symphony, don't waste your time!! The building is nice, but so are all the other beautiful buildings around Prague. Opposite the house is a major shopping complex. It just killed the whole 2 seconds of wow that we first got looking across.

Art Deco Dining. Wonderful dining room where we had delicious coffee and mouthwatering cakes. The following evening following a concert we sampled their "Delicious Menu" which was a set three course meal at a reasonable price. There was a choice of starters and mains and all four of us had a great meal. The waiters were attentive and courteous. A great dining experience in a beautiful setting.

Concert. Visited the Municipal House for a concert, which was excellent and followed it with dinner in the magnificent dining room. The three course meal deal gave us a good choice, the starter (pate) very tasty, main course ( medallions of pork) and the pudding (strawberries, kiwi and ice cream ) really good. Our food was cooked to perfection, service of a very high quality. Wine good value and very drinkable. All if this meal was accompanied by a young man playing pleasantly in a grand piano. Altogether a superb evening out for not a lot of money. Do go - you will enjoy

Prague Symphony performance. I saw a performance by the Prague Symphony at this hall. I was very impressed by the symphony. I have to admit I was expecting a thrown-together performance targeting tourists. That was not the case at all. This was a high-caliber symphony and performance. I've performed in symphonies as well as attended performances by some of the world's premier symphonies, and the Prague symphony holds up well in comparison. Make the time to catch a performance. The tympani player is quite the showman, and the audience obviously liked this based on the applause, but all the musicians were outstanding. Well done.The hall itself has nice acoustics, and is beautifully designed.

beautiful surroundings and the cakes are ok too.. magnificent building and furnishings. Good cakes and coffee if a little expensive. Service very efficient. No pictures allowed unless you pay a 5000k fee - most people had there iphones out snapping away happily ignoring the glares of the staff. Be aware this is a smoking venue, so avoid if you can't take your coffee and cake with a cloud of cigarette smoke. Overall definitly worth visiting.

Beautiful Art Deco Concert Hall. We saw a classical concert in the Hall that was thoroughly enjoyable. The concert was maybe 15% full, but the musicians were wonderful. The building itself is gorgeous. We wanted to go into the cafe in the front of the building. It's beautiful, but allowed smoking (as unfortunately many restaurants do) and smoke seemed to permeate the room.
Intersection. I found very interesting that on 20m distance you have Black Madonna house in cubist style, Municipal House in secession and Powder tower in between.

Multi-faceted jewel. I have been to Obceni Dum several time over the years but keep on discovering new features - this time we were invited to the Mayor's Ball in the Smetena Hall, a beautifully decorated space where an orchestra played Vienese waltzes. In a nearby room, the group Patrola played the songs of Old Prague, including songs by my father, Karel Hasler. Another time we met friends in the basement in a vast room resembling a beer hall where an accordian provided the music.

Wonderful art nouveau building. Magnificent art nouveau cafe and wonderful exhibition on the second floor of Art Nouveau paintings posters furniture , clothes and textiles. Buy the tickets to the exhibition first and get 20% off in the tea room. I didn't manage to be there to have a guided tour but you still get a very good idea of the magnificence of the building on your way up to the exhibition. And you can peek through the windows to the Mucha decorated ceiling of the main auditorium Don't forget to go downstairs to the American bar and the world,s most spectacular looking beer Keller!

Splendid Art Nouveau sample. The Jugendstil house hosts several attractions such as a beer hall in the basement, a french restaurant and a bistro at the ground floor. Further, it contains the beautiful Smetana concert hall. The entire building has perfectly preserved its Art Nouveau features and acts as a splendid example of the style. The halls, the elevator, the rooms are all gems and a guided tour or a visit at one of ist facilities is a must while in Prague.
Beautiful!. It is the place I personally liked most in Prague. Gives you the sensation of a glorious capital where great men created history. Very beautiful at night!

clickity click. another great building worthy of a visit.Some of the buildings can only be viewed from the outside of course as not all are open on certain days, nevertheless still worth going if only for the architectural construction of some of the sights.

The hidden bar . . .. Try a trip down the spiral stairs and find the American Bar. Created in 1912 this is a wonderfully decorated Art Nouveau circular bar.Check out the centre piece coffee urn - stunning conversation piece.This is a great place to relax and catch your breath whilst enjoying the sights of this fabulous city but also being constantly reminded of a splendid era in art and architecture. If you search you will even find a Mucha or 2. Comfy leather seating, table service, small intimate and splendidly decorated sum up the American bar. Don't forget to look up and examine the Chandelier, supplied by Frantisek Krizik.Not the cheapest place to drink but this is a little more than a drinking experience - great cocktails and great service in a great example of Art Nouveau!

Spectacular. This building is spectacular during day time and at night. They have special event in this hall all the times. Mostly concert. I didn't go to see the concert inside but the exterior of this building is very spectacular that can make you stunned. You can arrive the place via tram or subway. The station is Namesti Republiky. Next to the building is luxury restaurant and not too far (on the opposite side) is the big famous mall named Palladium. You can find foods and do some shopping in this big mall.

Join the guided tour. The tour of the municipal house was very interesting. Not only did we learn about the building, but we learned about the history of Prague. Informative and relatively inexpensive. If you have the time, take the tour!
Unbelievably beautiful piece of Art Nouveau. I was fortunate in having a guided tour through the building. Nearly every room offered more incredible murals and architecture.
Art nouveau decadence. The most beautiful art nouveau interior I've ever seen, take the tour so as not to miss anything and finish in the American Bar below stairs, not to be missed.
Stunning Deco opulence. Take tea in the cafe here and just wallow in the gold and lighting of the decor! Its just fabulous..
Old World Grandeur. The old world ambiancesomewhat cancelled out the the somewhat pricey wienerschnitzl, cappucino & pastry. Was worth seeing the Cafe & its clients.

Building looks nice - Astronomical Clock is Weak. Very picturesque building on the Square. Astronomical Clock on the side of the building isn't worth the half an hour jockeying for position for the 20 second show.

Like and old Bavarian beer hall!. One could almost imagine what this restaurant would be like on a holiday like the German Octoberfest. The food was served quickly and was delicious. The servers had a great sense of humor and were always pleased to help choose dishes as well as going out of their way to help with photos (ours hopped on a table to take our photo). Great for a family. Go to the basement which has the large seating area. If you are lucky, the seating is in groups and you may enjoy the company of people from other countries. Great atmosphere.

Art Deco at its best. An amazing building and the art deco features are memorable. We particularly enjoyed eating in the beer keller which is situated in the basement as the decor was quite awe-inspiring. We had a real 'taste' of Prague as the food, architecture and ambiance showed Prague at its best. Next time we will plan to do a concert!

Beautiful building, enjoyable concert. Close to our hotel, I wish I had taken the tour of the building. But did enjoy a concert one evening. There is a fee depending on where you sit. The night we were there, lots of seats were empty. But in previous visits the audience was full. Also tried to dine at one of the restaurants, but they were booked that night with private parties. We had visited the Mucha Museum earlier and found it interesting to see the work done by this wonderful Art Deco Czech artist, as it appears in the Municipal House. It is a good follow up to the museum.

Tour this building if you like Art Nouveau. There are one or two tours of this building daily, and if you like Art Nouveau then it is well worth visiting. The cost is about 280kr per person, but you get access to rooms that you wouldn't get to see even if you came to see a concert, and each room is full of differing design features of the era.

Superb. Even if you aren't interested in Art Deco, do take a tour of the Municipal House. It is a truly beautiful building. The attention to detail and the design and decoration are amazing. Have drink in the American Bar at the end of your tour to soak up the atmosphere a little more.

Beautiful building, especially with some original furniture. Whilst the history of this building is not as extensive as other buildings in Prague, it is still rather beautiful and impressive. Especially given its 'modern' history, you can still see the original furniture, wall paper paintings etc and not just replicas as you see in a lot of other places.We joined a guided tour for a fee which I understand is the only way you can get in to have a look. They also have concerts there but just be mindful that it may not be in the main hall, which is the impressive one.You also need to buy a 'photo' pass in order to take photos during the tour. I think it was 300czk for the tour + 100 for the photo. As it is still a fully functional hall, tour availability may be limited and changes a lot. I think they try to have 1-2 tours/day if there is nothing booked. The tour last for 1 hour and is done in English. Other languages I saw people holding a manuscript instead.This place is literally adjoining the powder gates so you cannot miss it. To get there you catch the subway:A or B (Můstek) A (Staroměstská)CoryK
The Best Restaurant. The french Restaurant is incredible. Its very good value for exceptional fine dining, its almost michelin just with out the Star and the price tag!

impressive. we went to a concert here in the smetana hall. we paid 32 euros per person for the row at the very back however the concert was very empty and we managed to watch from front row. it was a small orchestra, we had a good time there. the hall is an impressive one. i would suggest to spare the time to see inside but a concert is not very necessary unless its a really good orchestra.

Art Nouveau for Art Lovers. I have visited this beautiful building many times before, last time in August 2013 to see the exhibition of Alfons Mucha posters and paintings from Ivan Lendl collection. Since I love art nouveau, it's always a treat since this is art nouveau inside and out, including it's cafe and restaurant. Very worthy to go on a guided tour as well because one can see also the rooms not open to the public otherwise. And if you get a chance, go to a concert in it's Smetanova síň (Smetana Hall), home to the Prague Symphony Orchestra. It was in this house (Obecní dům in Czech) that the independent Czechoslovak Republic was declared on 28 October 1918 - it is now Czech national holiday, I am writing this email on it's anniversary and will Skype with my daughter who lives in the Czech Republic where I am from :-)
one of the most impressive sites in prague. Inspiring sight. Beautiful building, with incredible artwork on outside. Inside there are chandeliers which are awe inspiring and they do a coffee special.

Wonderfull Art-Noveau!!. If you like Art-Noveau you must see this. In every detail this is a very fine example of this style. If you want to see the whole building a tour is required. But you can have luch (until 16:00) in the restaurant.

Fantastic Art Noveau. This building is a must for art noveau fans and also for the casual tourist. Nowhere else can you see this style in all it's expressions, from plaster work, to iron work, frescoes, lighting, painting, wood work and tile. The tilework is particularly significant. Produced by the "Rako" company out of Rakovnik, it covers floors and walls in the entrance and basement floor of the building. Go to the basement and for a sublime experience of art noveau tile murals, go into the Plzenska Restaurace. You can see a virtual tour online at http://www.virtualtravel.cz/praha/stare-mesto/obecni-dum/plzenska-restaurace.html. Smetana Hall is also worth a visit, although for architectural buffs, it is a bit of a hash of styles, overdone with nationalistic fervor. But what an exuberant, fantastical building, testament to an exuberant period in Prague's history.

Beautiful Building. The municipal house is the most spectacular Art Nouveau building in Prague. Its construction dates back to the beginning of the 20th century (1906-1912). Since then it has been the host of many concerts and exhibitions and has been admired by millions of tourists and visitors. The interior is decorated with the works of the best Czech artist from the first decade of the 20th century. We had a pharmacy convention dinner for the group of 225 people, unfortunately the cocktail and dinner food wasnt very good. The service wasn't great either....but the building was beautiful and a must see
A must see if you like art nouveau. Fantastic.. The tour is fantastic. An absolute must. Mucha designs at their best. If you can, catch a concert in the main hall. Wonderful

A beautiful spot for music. We went to Municipal Hall for a concert. Not to be missed, Smetana Hall within was gorgeous! We heard the Prague National Symphony play Dvorak, Mozart, and Smetana, whose "Moldau" is named for the city's river. Just an hour, the concert left tIme for a snack at one of the many cafés just outside, and then an easy trolley ride back across the river to our hotel.

Wonderful mini-concert. Rather than sit in our hotel room for a couple of hours, we decided to attend a string concert at the Municipal House. We were staying at the Hotel Kings Court, so the Municipal House was around the corner. The concert was perfect - in execution, works presented and timing. Highlighting, Brahms, Vivaldi, Dvorak and more. Composers and music most would recognize. Lasted one hour and ten minutes. Perfect!!! So glad I attended. Check their schedule and enjoy!

An art nouveau wonder. For anyone interested in the Art Nouveau style from the turn of the century, this building is heaven. Absolutely superb. Even if you dont plan to dine there make sure you pop your head in each of the restaurants, as each is different but splendid in its own way. Must be the best art nouveau building in the world?

Delightful Art Nouveau. We loved the design of the building and the interior was adorned with lovely Art Nouveau tile & iron work. We unfortunately did not have time for the tour of the upstairs Smetana Concert Hall and the Lord Mayor's Hall, designed by famed Czech artist Alfons Mucha. Downstairs is a lovely museum store with many beautiful offerings. Don't miss visiting it.
A beautiful historic building just off the Square. A truly lovely old town building housing a fabulous restaurant (especially brunch - we went twice) and shops. A classic part of Prague history.
True surprise. Interesting beautiful buildingoutside but get down into the lower levels and appreciate the "Art Nouveau" tile

Must see!. Wow, this place is amazing! Mucha is one of my favorite artists.
