Go inside, walked around and check out the place...the tiles, elevators, light fixtures, murals, everything is so beautiful. We saw a concert here-highly recommended. Go see the Prague Symphony Orchestra or the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra, the real deal. Don't go to one of the "tourist" concerts, they cost twice as much and the quality is not a good.

Go inside!. The House is there for more than 100 years now! Beautiful interior, with decoration. There are interesting exhibitions and concerts. You can visit the restaurant and the coffee enjoying the atmosphere of the beginning of 20th century.
Lovely Art Nouveau Building. Quick and free. The exterior is lovely. If you have time, walk around the hallways. The tiles, windows, and metalwork are splendid.

Must Do. Built in 1905 at the high point of Prague’s Art Nouveau Period, this collection of concert halls, restaurants and meeting rooms is breathtaking. The major artists of this period took various rooms as their personal canvas and the result is absolutely wonderful. My personal favorite is the Alfons Mucha room. This lovely spot also houses two of my favorite restaurants and it is in the center of everything to boot.

A building well worth visiting - and a great "taster" concert!. My guide book had recommended looking in this building - and it is certainly worth a wander round. It is right next to the Powder Tower. You can also book a concert there. There are different concert spaces including the Smetena hall that takes 1200 people. We went for an early evening classical concert by the Bohemian Symphony orchestra in the Gregre Hall. This isn't a huge concert hall and massive orchestra - it was an all string ensemble in a smallish, artistically embellished room but they did a great job with tailored arrangements of popular classics - Dvorak, Mozart and Gershwin. It started at 18.00 - and was only about an hour in length. Cost 800CSZ. Not cheap but worth the money for the whole experience. I might have been upset if I had paid the higher price of 1000 CSZ - as the acoustics and seating and size of room did not justify this differentiation. You might want to take a cushion as they were rows of hard wooden chairs. It depends on your degree of personal built in padding! Overall it was a delightful musical taster of Prague in an appropriate setting.

Amazing exterior, less amazing interior. It's amazing to look at from the outside, and some interior elements are lovely (elevators, tiles, lights, special rooms), but some of the interior is pretty blase. The restaurant with street tables has really bad service...waiters who don't wait on you.
Beautiful Art Nouveau Style. Although we did not go to a concert in this building, we did enjoy the art nouveau design. Definitely worth finding on your Prague walk about.

Magnificent. This is the one building to see in New Town. We did not take a tour inside but wish we had. We were with our own tour guide who walked us around. The outside and the inside of the building was beautiful. I am sure it is magical to attend a performance in this venue. We had hoped to return to have coffee in the beautiful, I mean beautiful with chandeliers, coffee shop but did not make it back with all there is to see and do in Prague.

The most beautiful building. You must pay an expensive ticket for the tour and additional ticket if you want to take and photographs but worth all the money. If you have the opportunity to watch a performance of classical music is magic.

Great venue for concerts. Attended a concert of Dvorak, Mozart and Gershwin performed by members of theBohemian Symphony Orchestra . Wonderful venue. Comfortable. One hour in length. A little pricey but quality musicians and a solid perfotmance. Since the Hall is close to our hotel may try to catch another concert before we leave. Would recommend

unexpected to find out how beautiful it really was. First day in Prague our map had this in the wrong spot. Day two, got a new map and found it. Booked a tour early for the afternoon to ensure we could see it. Each room we were taken into was beautiful in its own right, from the floor, to walls, and definitely the murals on the ceiling. I wish I had lived back in the early 1900's to have truly experienced this place when it was not just mainly a tourist attraction. If you don't want to pay for a tour, go downstairs to the restaurant and you'll at least see one style of the art-deco rooms.

Art nouveau heaven but avoid beer hall food. If you tour nothing else in Prague, you must see the interior of this altar to art nouveau. The city burghers knew what they were doing when they employed the pre-eminent Czech architects and artists of the day to design and decorate their town hall. Outside it is impressive but the inside - the best bits only seen if you take a guided tour - are stunning. Buy a ticket in advance on the day to avoid disappointment as numbers are restricted because some of the once official rooms are quite small. It is, however, licensed for weddings if you want an unusual venue! You have to buy a permit to take photos on the tour.A tour ticket gets you a 2-4-1 deal on drinks in the American Bar downstairs - well worth drinking up the atmosphere, especially in the little curtained booths either side of the bar. What secrets could they tell?Ten years ago I ate wonderful traditional Czech food with good service in the Beer Hall beside the bar. Not so in 2013. We tried to book a table but were told this could only be done via hotel or travel agent and that we would have no problem getting a table even though we were eating on a Saturday. Sure enough, no tables available at 7pm. We complained to the same waiter that we'd tried to book and he reluctantly sat us down opposite the main entrance - happily with a good view of the lovely original tiled picture walls.I was a bit suspicious of the food when I saw the menu where dishes were pictured - a trick supposedly to appeal to tourists - rather than simply in text. The range was much less than I recalled and, having had dumplings eariier in the day, chose smoked pork with potato pancake and plum sauce rather than the roast duck I'd had my heart on. The pork turned out to be three fatty slices and the pancake looked like a cowpat. I cut out the lean meat, doused it in plum sauce and left the rest. No response from the waitress who asked how the food had been when I said mine was very greasy.Go in and take pictures but eat elsewhere.
What an ambience. we went to the municipal hall for a classical concert and loved both the concert and the interiors of this building. Spacious auditorium, wide staircases and very old world.
Beautiful!. I love this style and thought this was one of the most beautiful places I've ever visited. There is lots to see on all floors.

Beautiful architecture. This building is beautiful inside and out. I recommend doing more than just taking photos from across the street. They do offer tours at specific times- see website for schedule. You can also access the public areas on your own if you do not have time for the whole tour. There are a few restaurants inside as well, in addition to wifi and bathrooms. I did not hear very good things about the food in the cafe but the room looks beautiful. They offer concerts as well, but I was told that these performances are more about the experience of being in Smetana Hall rather than the music. Prices are also much higher than what is charged for seeing the Czech Philharmonic, Opera, etc...The Smetana hall seats so many people, that it seems you can get tickets the day of the performance at the box office.
beautiful w art nouveau cafe. Loved this little cafe in the municipal bldg. First stop in Prague and while food wasn't great, atmosphere worth it.

just astonishing.. Beautiful building in art-nouveau style. One of many buildings in this style in Prague but the municipal house tops them all. Do not just take pictures of the outside but step inside, take a look at the different publicly accessible places, go downstairs to see the bar and the great lighting fixtures as well as the beautiful details in the staircase and elevator shaft.

Go Inside, not just look at the Outside. Some people don't realize that you can go IN the Municipal House during the day, even without a ticket. It is the finest example of Art Nouveau architecture in the city and a real treat to see. The shop in the lower floor has some upscale souvenirs and worth a walk through.

My favourite building in Prague. It's magical inside. Try a late evening coffee in the American bar downstairs....
You don't need to book a tour to still get a real feel for the place, just stroll in.

an impresive bilding and a good exhibition. The bilding is a magnificent example of the Art-novo style, inside and out. It's recommended to see the exhibition of Mocha's posters. I can say that after that day, i really know what Art-novo means.

great concert!. This is a most beautiful Art Noveau building and we availed of an opportunity to go to a concert one evening. "The Best of Classics" with The Chamber Orchestra. Very enjoyable event. I would recommend it.
Take a tour. We took a tour today and were blown away by the beauty of the concert hall and the various rooms. Exquisite restoration work done. For lovers of art nouveau especially

Wonderful building, pity about the concert. Our friends booked a concert several weeks earlier. We were very impressed by the splendour of the hall, itself, the Smetna Hall. Great acoustics, and plenty to admire.There are also a variety of restaurants linked. We ate in a cafe, art nouveau, food average, but fun to be there. Real atmosphere.I say pity about the concert, surprisingly small audience for such a large venue. We have learnt to research who is performing. Not bad but did not rise to the full potential of the place.
Municipal Hall. Art Nouveau building with cafes,concert halls ,a gift shop and most importantly-FREE loos!A rarity in Prague!

Art Deco plus. What do you call a mashup of Baroque and Art Deco? Hmmmm.... Might be the Municipal House that doubles as the home of the Czech Symphany. While the latter is surely sublime, the house is unusual. From the outside It is Baroquish while the inside is Mucha inspired Art Deco. The lighting in the restaurant and bar is a brilliant precursor to 20s decadence. Did this lighting survive me thirties and forties or is it repro?

Not as magnificent as the National Theater. My family and I attended a Thursday night concert at the Municipal House's Smetana Hall. We bought tickets for the cheapest seats at 300 Kc (about $15 each) and could see and hear well. The program was:Antonine Dvorak: Slavonic Rhapsody No. 2 in G minorSergei Rachmaninov: Rhapsody on a Paganini ThemeEdward Elgar: Variations on a Original Theme 'Enigma'Featuring:Olga Kern on pianoThe concert was fine, but it didn't grip us the way the opera had. The seats were like seats in a high school auditorium. One of my friends fell asleep at the concert, but at the opera, at the National Theater, everyone was wide awake and entirely engrossed in the opera. If you only have time for one performance, skip the Municipal House and see the opera at the National Theater instead.

The Municiple House. A lovely well kept building with beautifull interiors, the guided tour is very informative and lots of information about history and nice views from of the surrounding area from the toop windows would love to see a musical concert here.

Stunning Art Nouveau architecture. What a beautiful building! It's a stunning example of Art Nouveau decor - the foyer area and staircase down to the American bar are well worth looking at. We went to a concert in the main hall, but be aware that there are several concert venues within the building. This can be quite confusing when you're trying to book tickets. There are three different ticket booths, serving three different halls. It took us a while to work out where to buy the correct tickets for the Prague philamonic orchestra as ticket sellers outside the entrance were trying to sell tickets for much smaller concerts. That aside, the building and main concert hall is amazing. The cafe itself is a little pricey, more than the American bar, but the cakes were gorgeous! A definite must see when visiting Prague.

Stunning. Just from the outside this building takes your breath away. The interiors are full of art work. I didn't take the tour but regret not doing it. Just from the little that I saw while viewing a Mucha exhibit was gorgeous.
Great dinner and concert. Attended a wonderful concert and had dinner in the restaurant below. Amazing venue for classical concert. Dinner was good and entertainment was a nice addition.

great decor for the Lendl-Mucha expo. beautiful building. we were lucky enough to be in Prague on the last day of the Mucha-Lendl exposition. The building and the artwork where a nice compliment to each other.

great place for weddings. I attended a wedding of a friend of mine in sep 2013. I was positively surprised by the beauty of the rooms and the sound of the pipe organ. Organization was perfect as well as the courtesy of the local staff.

Decorator's Dream.... This is a gorgeous example of Art Nouveau architecture and decor. Hire a tour guide to show you the concert hall and the anterooms that are off-limits to the general public. Each room is different and amazing in its own way. Our guide kept saying " this room is over-decorated". HA! She was right- they were all over the top fabulous. Of particular beauty is one room designed and painted by Alfons Mucha.The celing has a beautiful work titled "Slavic Concord " that you should see.Of course, the American Bar, the restaurants, and the Wine Bar were fun too.

off to prague. had a chance to see a concert here last week. the acoustics are nice. the ambience even nicer.if you have a chance, check and see if there any concerts and go. i think the cost is less than 100 for each seat. i would go and enjoy. but check to see who is playing. i have gone now twice. once i didnt really enjoy it. the other time, it was much better. take a look. if nothing else, go around the building and enjoy the architecture.

Beautiful building. This is a stunningly beautiful building in "art nouveau" style. We took a guided tour which was easily the best way to appreciate all of the building. The tour takes you into all of the lavish ante rooms as well as the splendid concert hall. We attended a concert by the Prague Symphony Orchestra a couple of days later which was a first rate experience in such a wonderful location. We also ate before the concert in the cafe restaurant, which is also a beautiful room. The food and service were very good and at reasonable prices. A word of caution- we tried to reserve a table during our earlier visit and was told this was not necessary. In the event it was very busy and we were put up on the balcony area which was nowhere near as good for appreciating the special ambience. So my advice is to book.This building is one of the Prague "must sees" and is probably one of the finest examples of "art nouveau" architecture in Europe.

Fantastic architectural features everywhere - but the cafe lacks atmosphere. I've rated this building as 'very good' because it is so beautiful, and you can visit much of the building without paying. You can go into the entrance hall, see the café and restaurant, walk downstairs to see the American Bar and restaurant too, and there are so many fabulous features to see it took my breath away. It's a must see for Art Nouveau fans.Where it falls down for me is that you have to pay to see a performance to go into the main auditorium, and that the café lacks atmosphere. This was my second visit to the café - the first for an evening meal, this time for breakfast. Outside on the terrace was more interesting than inside - it seems that they have a lot of space to fill and not enough customers to make it inviting. Both visits were in September - maybe it fills up in the winter?The breakfast menu was uninspiring - fine but not very interesting. I have to say the service was very good, but you paid for the environment. We had much better - and cheaper - breakfasts at Café Louvre.
Great building. It is nicely placed and well renovated, I just wished that my camera could capture the entire building in it's beauty.
A 'must visit' when in Prague. This wonderful building is a delight to see round. We had hoped to go to a concert in the building but time did not allow. Food was superb. Went there on two occasions.
Loved it. Climb the stairs. close to the medieval clock. We loved climbing the stairs to the top and looking out over the city of Prague. We worth the small admission fee.

Great building, but short, over-priced performance. Went to the Municipal House to see 'best of the classics' , first stop the American Bar, meant to be the oldest in Prague. Poor bar tender - one concert finishes, one due to start, and he is on his own making cocktails ! He is falling behind..... So on to the concert - the building is impressive on the outside and the inside too. Unfortunately, the rows of seats were incredibly uncomfortable ( I think it was so that you were happy to leave without noticing how short the performance was ). The ensemble consisted of 6 violinists, one double bass, and a cello. The sound and quality of playing was excellent, covering all those tunes from advertisements that we know and love! Some where very brief , and so was the whole performance - 55 minutes , which at prices from £28 to £36 can only be seen as expensive ( being charitable) or a rip off ( being cynical), you choose. I cannot recommend that you spend your hard earned money on such a performance and you may be better going to see a complete rendition.
Stunning Building!. We got to see this building and check out the Mucha exhibit. Very interesting! We also had a drink downstairs after which was fun as well.
Fabulous. We had dinner at the French Restaurant in the Municipal House. It was absolutely delicious and the service was excellent.

Make sure to visit this beautiful building as it is not recommended as it should be, it is beside Powder Tower city gate. I didn;t even see this building recommended in my travel info or research. but I stumbled onto it beside Powder Tower city gate (the big gothic gate just east of Old Town Square). This building is beautiful both inside and out. It is the site where the declaration for Independence was signed.

Beautiful building inside. You need to buy a ticket to an exhibit or a concert to be able to catch a glimpse of the amazing inside of the building. A ticket will give you a 20% discount at the bars and restaurants. But even with the discount the prices are rather high. It is so beautiful that it is worth it anyway.
Worthwhile Tour. This is a beautiful building that is the Prague cultural center. We took a very interesting guided tour with an entertaining, charming guide.

Beautiful building and concert hall. We passed this building on the way to our hotel and could not have been happier to find it was only a few blocks from our hotel (Boscolo). Our first night in Prague we attended a Vivaldi concert in Smetana Hall. Beautiful surroundings and acoustics. So convenient to stop for 'coffee and' afterwards.

Worth a visit. It is very nice Art Deco building with great history. We saw Mucha exibitionthere and we enjoyed both - inner architecture and exposition itself. If youare exhausted after long walking, go to the Cafe, which is placed in theground floor. We got very nice cake there.

Take the Tour. This is another place in Prague to enjoy the art of Mucha and the exuberance of the Art Noiveau period. Recently restored to its original grandeur, the Municipal is also a venue for concerts and a delightful place to grab a drink or coffee.

Must see - take the tour!. What a gorgeous building! The tour is well worth it, with private access to lush and intricately decorated concert halls and rooms, with a great guide. Make sure to stop at the Americky Bar downstairs for a drink after (even the ginger all was fab) it has such a cool vibe!

Must see in Prague. Along with the castle/cathedral and Charles Bridge this is a must see if you're in Prague. Make sure you do the guided tour (in English) the highlight of which is Mucha's beautiful Mayor's Parlour. At the time of writing there is also an exhibition of Ivan Lendl's personal collection of Mucha posters.
Pearl Anniversary. Wow, an art deco/neuvo masterpiece of mosaic and ceramic tiles, with the very swish cafe at the front serving excellent cakes

Stunning. This building is an excellent example of the Art Nouveau style of architecture. It oozes elegance and conjures images of a bygone age of sophistication.
I would have loved to dress up in an elegant evening gown to sit down to dinner here to do the setting its full justice.
Please visit to admire the stained glass and wonderful furnishings
Great venue for lunch. Went to see the Mucha exhibition and decided to have lunch in the restaurant. Very good food and surprisingly reasonably priced.

Great venue for enjoying a classical music concert. This gem was only steps from my hotel, but it is easily accessible from all over the city of Prague by the subway, as it sits on Republic Square next to the subway station. The concert I attended was excellent and the acoustics are outstanding in Smetana Hall. The art nouveau interior is intriguing and beautiful. There are two restaurants in the building. Concerts are available to be attended most every night, at least in the summer months. Highly recommended.
The outside is terrific. The building is next to the Powder Tower so is a must. Also, the place have a huge sidewalk so you can take your pictures peacefully.

Stunning architecture. Went to the Obecni Dum for a Mucha exhibition, and the setting was perfect, the building is a stunning example of fin de siecle architecture executed with a seeming disregard for cost and maintained in a similar fashion, the Czechs are rightly porud of it.
Stunning!!. I could spend all day in here, the mayors chamber is where part of the first Mission Impossible film was shot.

Art Deco gem with great cakes!!. Stunning building - takes your breath away! If you need one place to capture the essence of Prague, this is a major contender! Just a pity we were unable to stay for a concert....but next time!

Beautiful building - not suitable for disabled people. The outside of this building is truly beautiful, though somewhat marred by the posters of current events. The inside is good, but not spectacular. We saw the exhibit of Alfons Mucha's posters contributed by Ivan Lendl. It was a very interesting and well put together exhibit. My main complaint was that the exhibit was up three flights of stairs and I have trouble with stairs. So I asked for an elevator. The only elevator has an attendant who refused to let me ride up in it since my disability was not obvious. So I painfully made my way up the stairs. At the top, the two ticket takers saw how painful it was for me and indicated that I could have taken the elevator..... Enough said.

Beautiful inside!. I went here twice. Once for a Mucha exhibit, and then for a concert. It is a beautiful building, and if you check out the schedule, you should be able to arrange for something to go to inside. I have eaten in the basement restaurant on a previous visit, and it was OK. The restaurant on the ground floor is gorgeous, but I have not eaten there.

Must visit. A guide is mandatory with the tour which is great because it does make the tour really informative. It is quite ridiculous that 2 euro is charged for photo taking. The interior is beautiful for pictures but I rather tip the guide than pay for the photo taking which is just another rip off tourist opportunity. The tour is an hour long but feels much way shorter. If you can, a concert here must be really great, we couldn't with a 14month baby and 6 year old in tow. The Smetana hall is simply breath-taking. The is a room with amazing acoustics which the guide will explain. Do make sure you try it. Tickets are sold for the day of visit but do buy your tickets at the time after a tour has started for the next ones to avoid unnecessary long queues, i.e there is a tour at 11am, buy your ticket after this time for 1pm or 4pm tours. The office opens at 10am and the queue in the morning is very long. Sundays tours are in different timing, do check. If you have kids, make sure that they can be kept quiet (or not overtired) as any sound is amplified in those rooms making it very hard for the crowd to hear the guide. But of course if you step away to the next room it would be fine but you'll miss the tour yourself. We also attended the Mucha exhibit within the same building. Interesting but I'm really not a fan of Mucha.
Enjoyable concert. Reasonable concert but not in a large hall, the music was fantastic though but would have had more ambience in one of the larger concert halls

Great concert. This is a lovely building housing a theatre, an American cocktail bar and two restaurants, one of which serves authentic Czech cuisine. It has a great atmosphere. We attended one of the evening concerts (a selection of opera, ballet and orchestral works) and were not disappointed. Lovely soprano and delightful dancing.

Beautiful Civic Landmark. The Municipal House (Obecní dům) is a major civic landmark and concert hall in Prague, and an important building in architectural and political history in the Czech Republic. It stands on the Náměstí Republiky. The Art Nouveau structure is an artifact of the Czech nationalism of the time and carries a wealth of ornament by some of the leading Czech artists of its day.

See a concert and take the tour. Beautiful Art Nouveau building. We saw a concert in Smetena Hall, worth the price just to sit in the beautiful hall and absorb the wonderful decorations.Later in the week we returned for the building tour. We had a great guide who took us on an hour trip through the building and explained a lot of the history, architecture and decoration of the building. There is a nice coffee / lunch place just inside the building with very nice cakes and desserts, and very attentive service.This building was a highlight of our stay in Prague

Beautiful rooms, nice tour. . We had a nice tour, from a nice guy. He tells good historical things, shows you some great rooms, concert rooms, great mucha wallpaintings and a funny acoustic in one of the last rooms. Take a look!

See the awesome Mucha exhibition!. We were going to go to the Mucha Museum in Prague, but after we asked our hotel clerk where it was, she recommended that we go to the Mucha exhibition being held in the Municipal House instead. Alphons Mucha was an early 1900s Art Nouveau artist. The hotel clerk felt that the exhibition was better than the museum and we were glad we went. The exhibition has over 100 Mucha prints and is very interesting. The price was 180 Crowns per person, which was pretty reasonable for Prague. The art was very interesting to look at and the descriptions helped. Also there was an interesting 20 minute movie. it runs through early September. We highly recommend you go!

Attend a concert here. The Municipal House doesn't seem all that great from the outside, but the coffee shop and concert hall are both wonderful examples of Art Nouveau. When we visited in July we were able to buy concert tickets the same day, and the hall was far from full, presumably because the major orchestras are taking their summer break. But the 12-13 piece chamber orchestra that played for us was very good and the violin soloist was excellent. You forget how great it is to be able to hear and see the performers live. The hall itself is very very beautiful. We were in Prague on a tour and many of our group went to see the Czech Black Light Theatre "because it is only found in the Czech Republic". There is a reason for that. Go to a concert in the Municipal House instead.

Beautiful concert hall. I had been fortunate enough to get a ticket on the day to the season closing concert (Beethoven No. 9) performed by the Prague Symphony Orchestra. The Municipal House was definitely worth the visit, there are often temporary exhibitions in there also. But better yet, buy a concert ticket so you can fully absorb in the atmosphere and engage completely in the experience.

wonderful building!. totally worth a visit! you will see the best of Art Nouveau. Go the one of the restaurants for a complete experience.we took the guided tour which was very well worth. One needs to pay a bit extra to take pictures. Take this when paying for your ticket to avoid queuing twice.We were very lucky to be there at the time when the Lindl/Mucha exhibition was on. excellent! we bought a few gorgeous posters, printed on the spot.

a central building. This is one of the places that amongst other things, concerts are held there. The concert I attended was worthed though it was hot inside. I expected to listen to the concert in a bigger hall, but the hall was small and not elaborated. But the musicians and singer were great.

Municipal Building in Prague. What a magnificent building! Now used as a concert venue, it contains both a formal restaurant on the main floor as well as a more casual Czech restaurant downstairs adjoining the Ameriky bar, said to be the first American Bar in Europe. Be sure to go inside and walk around to enjoy the amazing art nouveau windows, tile, and decor.
beautiful hall. beautiful building with great acoustics. Small orchestra performing the best of Hollywood movies-lovely. Lots of street entertainment just outside of municipal hall.

Interesting. Beautiful building inside. Went to the (Ivan Lendl) Mucha Poster exhibition housed in two rooms. It was a very hot day and there was no air conditioning at all. The humidity spoiled the exhibition.

Art nouveau building and coffee shop well worth a visit. The outside of the building was enchanting if we had had more time we would have taken the tour. We had the strudel and coffee special that included a small glass of egg cognac. The food and drink were excellent and the atmosphere of the coffee shop was very pleasant.

The castle. Great views over the city, free to visit the gardens (lovely) and the courtyards in the castle including the changing of he Guards - best at noon. interesting walk down from the castle to Charles Bridge.

Smetana classical feast for ears and eyes.. If you are hot, have tired feet and want some soulfood with a visual feast, walk into the gloriously decorated 'Art Nouveau' Municipal House near Republik Square and book tickets for the 1-hour long concert at 6pm in Smetana Hall. Can do just before the concert.Range of ticket prices available and on my evening fewer than 100 people in audience-less than 10% capacity. Acoustics are brilliant so doesn't matter where you sit. ( On internal wide staircase, watch out for curled carpet edge on landing mid- way)Professional playing of well known top of the pop classics. So easy! Then have a drink or dinner at the choice of three restaurants leading off the lobby. All makes for a relaxed and elegant evening in the Old Town.

Guided tour of the Municipal house hall. Tour in English worth the time and money as its very interesting and beautiful.
We were in a hot day and it was too hot inside some of the rooms,

Fantastic!. Take a tour to see this properly, then try and visit a concert in the Smetana room. The concert itself might be a humdrum version of Mozart but it doesn't matter. The atmosphere is tremendous.

A beautiful building, shame about the ticket prices.. The building is a stunning piece of architecture and interior design. Well worth a look. Just a shame about the concert tickets, which were overpriced considering we only got a 1/4 of an orchestra, that couldn't do justice to the acoustics of the amazing, high domed central hall.

wanted to visited but were ushered out. The building from the front is impressive. We thought we go for the tour and visit the building. (There was no performance planned and it was during the day) and for some strange reason we were not allowed in. They closed the tour. Treatment was very unfriendly, a pity cause I think it is worth the while

a must for art nouveau lovers. This a fantastic building from the outside as well as the inside. Get a ticket and walk through the rooms decorated in art nouveau style. After have a coffee in the restaurant downstairs. It is not cheap but its worth it.

Magnificent from the outside at night, and worth the tour inside by day. We truly loved passing by this great building (near the Powder Tower) the way it was lit up so brightly up each night. Unfortunately, the concert schedule didn't work for us, but we were very pleased by the many fabulous Art Noveau rooms we were able to see on the tour (very enthusiastic, in heavily accented but understandable English), including the concert hall, Smetana Auditorium. Highly recommended, and attending a concert there would be even better.

Stravinsky in Smetana Hall. We were lucky to hear a performance of Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring" (at its one hundredth anniversary) by the spirited and remarkably youthful Prague Symphony in its superb historic hall in Municipal House.
Good tour lots of information. Beautiful building, tour guide was excellent but I disliked the fact that you had to pay to take pictures but this is normal in Prague

We had a tour... The tour took us through beautiful rooms which have been restored since Communist times. Alfonso Mucha's work is everywhere. We ate in the basement restaurant and bar and were entertained with traditional bohemian music in the evening.

Art Nouveau Beauty. Stunning place to go to a concert, actually stunning just to visit and see all the rooms, exhibitions. Or go for a classy but a bit more expensive supper. Plus in the main hall the have that awesome architrectonic effect that you can whisper on one side of the room and person on the other side of the hall can hear you perfectly. A bit creepy and really cool :)

Municipal House Hall - Nicely decorated building in Art Nouveau architecture style. The Municipal House is a historic building, located next to the Powder Tower on Náměstí Republiky that is handsomely decorated in Art Nouveau architectural style. The building facade features a very nice Homage to Prague mosaic and there is quite a bit more to see and experience inside. Within the Municipal House complex, you can find much more Art Nouveau decor, a couple of classy restaurants, an atmospheric cafe, historical Americky Bar and a beautiful Smetana Hall. During our recent visit to Prague we visited the Municipal House to watch a short concert in one of the minor halls, located next to Americky Bar in the basement area of the building. The performance was decent, the acoustics not great but the entire experience made better simply by the architecture and decor of the building. Overall, not sure we'd return for a minor concert performance or not but would certainly be interested in attending a performance in the major Smetana Hall and would be delighted to attend a tour of this building, which we found to be a real treat for fans of Art Nouveau architectural style.

A Art Deco gem (and good food too!). This is a must see / experience place. Designed by Mucha, the Municipal House is worth a visit. The pub section is reasonably prices and the service excellent. The food is fine but nothing to write home about.

Art nouveau. The whole building has been restored . Some parts are original. It is used for concerts that you can attend. It has beautiful paintings by the most famous Czech artists including Mucha. It can only be visited with a guided tour. Our guide explained everything both in Czech and English. We also saw an exhibition of Mucha's art collected by the tennis player Ivan Lendl.

Pretty Art nouveau building. From outside, it is beautiful with its semicircular facade. There's a large balcony with a nice mosaic on top of it. Inside there are small halls for performances as well as a beautiful theatre for concerts , operas. There are concerts every day. It's quite cheap.
Beutifull building!. We went to a concert and really enjoyed.the building insiht is really nice. You listen well almost anywhere inside.
Not to be missed. This is one of the most beautiful buildings on the planet. An art nouveau palace where every detail is amazing. They offer tours that are highly recommended.

Absolutely Fantastic. An amazing Art Deco experience. The fully tiled bar down stairs is the most complete you will find anywhere. The prices in both the bar and the restaurant are reasonable for the city centre. The Marble staircase and decorated ceilings are fantastic. There are some great musical performances here as well.

Hurry up, you MUST see it. Maybe you are not a fan of architecture or of painting. Possible you do not pay attention to styles and trends. 'But I am sure you are able to see that things match together. The Municipal House in Prague houses now the collection of Ivan Lendl focused on Alfons Mucha works, mainly posters. Visit it and you will never regret, do not tell my mother I have bought the very last big silk scarf for her - it should be a surprise. I was pleased there is also a quiz for kids and a very interesting film telling you the whole story about returning home. This exhibition closes on July 31, so hurry up.

Go see the Hall and see a show too!. The Municipal House is an art deco haven and amazing to see from the inside. There is a little-known, hidden gift shop inside to the left and downstairs. There are always people outside the hall advertising for musical performances in the Hall for that day and the next several days. You can go inside and buy tickets for the same day or some time during your visit. Vivaldi is a common theme. We returned that evening for an octet of violins and strings, accompanied by one of Prague's opera stars. It was a great performance, and you get to hear how good the Hall is for music and opera. The show was 70 minutes and was not at all expensive, less than $100 for 2 for great seats.

Wedding stay. Visited for a coffee and pancake, possibly the best pancakes in Prague and in a great setting. With the concert hall and the art deco decor, this is a place you must visit and don't forget your camera.

Stunning architecture, also offers music & art. This is my favorite building in the world. Gorgeous art deco details throughout, so beautifully crafted, attention to every detail down to the doorknobs and air vents. Don't miss the guided tour (usually offered 3x per day in English, handouts available in other languages) - you can see so much of the building. Our guide Pavla was so friendly and enthusiastic (and very kindly gave an abbreviated German translation of the tour to a small group that was on the tour). You could tell that she genuinely loved the building, and with good reason. A real monument to the pride and artistry of the Czech people during the pre-WWI boom time. The Ivan Lendl:Alfons Mucha exhibit was on display while we were there, and was also amazing. A huge collection of one of the most important Czech artists, beautiful art deco posters, well-curated with an informative video - also not to be missed if it's still on! We also attended an evening concert in the downstairs smaller concert hall - a five-piece string chamber orchestra who played Mozart and Dvorak with passion, precision, and artistry, very enjoyable.

Beautiful Music (and space). We attended a concert by Slovak Philharmonic Orchestra in the Smetana Hall. It was part of Prague Music Festival. This is a very beautiful music venue, with wonderful acoustics and architecture. The orchestra provided a wonderful concert. Found myself listening to orchestra while discovering with my eyes new aspects of the Hall. Highly recommend you attend a musical event in the Smetana and then explore the art in the rest of the building.

Don't hesitate... just do it!. Ticket sales is to the right just before you go up the stairs. Bought Best of Classics, splurged for green tickets near the front. Started promptly at 5:30. The acoustics were awesome and sounds "huge". The players were great as well with lots of individual characteristics... not the typical "cold" disconnected musicians of bigger orchestras. They looked at each other, and worked together. The 1.5 hrs was great for little kids (free by the way)The Hungarian Dance by Brahms was wonderful.

Art Nouveau Masterpiece!. One of the most beautiful buildings in Prague (which has no short supply of them!), with gorgeous Art Nouveau details inside and out. We stopped by to see the Mucha exhibit, which we very much enjoyed, and stopped by the cafe twice. The service, food, and atmosphere were excellent at the cafe and it made for the perfect mid-afternoon break.
Beautiful building and very interesting exhibition. We visited the Moocha Poster exhibition, which was excellent. The building itself is also very beautiful in the Art Nouveau style.

favorite building in the world. I love art deco and this building is an amazing example. we were lucky enough to hit it when Ivan Lendl's Mucha collection was there so it was a double pleasure. Be sure to get into the hall as it is a gorgeous example of Mucha at his best.

Smetana Hall has amazing acoustics. We bought same day tickets for a classical string performance in Smetana Hall of the Municipal House. It was amazing. All of the musicians are from various professional orchestras. Vivaldis Four Seasons in this space evoked tears and amazing emotion. This is a lovely venue. If you can not see the full philharmonic orchestra, try to see something here. There is a small classical music store off the square called, Via Misica. They can sell tickets to most shows.
Must see. This is one of the outstanding buildings in Prague. Go in and have a coffee or a drink in the American bar downstairs. We revisted several times.

The Concert was bad. The Opera House is very impressive inside .The classical music concert was not very good .I think the concert is a some kind of Tourist trap .You should visit there only to see the architecture orwhen a good and known symphonic orchestra performs there.

Great Mucha exhibition, lovely Art Nouveau decor.. Went to the Mucha exhibition here this week; it was a good selection of his work, of which I've only seen a glimpse before. Well worth a look. The whole building is a stunning Art Nouveau extravaganza; the Mucha is on the top floor so you get to see the whole building on the way up. The cafe and restaurant are also well worth a look if you like the style. A definite recommendation.
Art deco gem. A massive building with beautiful art deco restaurants, concert halls etc. Even if you don't have time for the official tour, it's worth having a wander around, it's beautiful.

Art Nouvelle lives on. A grand tourist concert in a magnificent hall drew us there for starters, then the American bar whetted the appetite for more, then some excellent restaurant food at reasonable prices, notforgetting the 1 hour tour of the fantastic building. An easy place to use as a walking base around Prague knowing there was a reasonable resting place in magnificent surroundings

Eye Candy. We didn't pay for the complete tour, but wandered in and walked everywhere you could for free--up the stairs until we were mildly motioned to go down, to the bathrooms below, the American bar and the restaurant on the ground floor. The mosaic tilings were beautiful as well as the architectural structure. Loved the bar and had we had more time would have stopped and enjoyed. Definitely worth a walk through at least. I can imagine the tour would have been good.

Excellent tour. The building is a must see in Prague. I strongly recommend taking the tour. Each room was designed by a Czec artisit. Everything has been maintained to the highest of standards. We also got to see the exposition of original Alfons Mucha posters!!!
Restaurants, bars and music. We thoroughly enjoyed the Muncipal House. We had drinks at the American Bar and a delicious dinner in the French Restaurant. Also attended a lovely concert.

Stunning. If you like Art Deco/Nouveau this is a must see building. Take the tour and have a drink in the American bar downstairs. A wonderful couple of hours topped of sipping champagne.Shame they did not have any guide books in English!
Nice building, come for an symphony concert if you like. Come to experience a concert, the building itself is very beautiful from the inside as well as the outside.

Wander around!. We ate dinner in a restaurant in the basement of this wonderful building. Do not miss this basement! The metal work on the stair rails is gorgeous. But was I really loved was the tile work murals on the walls. And the food in the restaurant was great too!

Art Deco Wonder. This building should be one of the wonders of the world. It was built at a time of unequaled opulence, when money was no object. The sound quality in the concert room is terrible but use it as an excuse to visit this building and see it at night. Every room was designed from the ground up by a different artist, including lights, accessories, murals, floors, etc. Make sure that your camera battery is fully charged. You will want to take a lot of pictures. Truly exceptional!

Wonderful Building and Mucha Exhibit. The building itself is well worth a visit, it is awesome. We saw the special Mucha exhibition...these are works owned by tennis great Ivan Lendl. It was absolutely fantastic. Could have spent more than the 2 hours we were there for.

Nice looking building especially at night. Visited the place at night. With the lights on, the building is magnificent. There is a restaurant inside and it serves a good variety of food. Also there is a concert hall inside but I did not get in as we did not book tickets for the performance.
Beautiful. Visit and see the detail that went into this building and all the areas it includes. Take in a concert if possible. Great accoustics

Art Nouveau for music and food. This magnificent art nouveau building combines exquisite dining and superb music under the same roof. Expensive, especially by Prague standards, but worth it. The seats in the Smetena Hall are not as comfortable as one would wish.

How lucky were we?. When we were in Prague, the Hall sported a world-first exhibition of Ivan Lendl's (yes, the tennisplayer) private Mucha collection. It was very interesting and huge! Prepare to spend quite some time there if you're lucky to go when it's on. The building is very nice, and outside is beautiful in the evening with all the lights on.
Charming..... Very charming building. There's a Mucha exhibition there right now. If you are a fan, you should go. Also try to catch a concert, play, opera at the Smetana Hall.

A must for art nouveau fans. A beautifully restored art nouveau building with lots to explore. We had a very memorable dinner in the lavishly decorated restaurant and the very atmospheric American bar serves a wide range of cocktails. Well worth a visit!
nothing much to see here. There was many positive reviews about this place but I don't get why. It's a nice looking building but not much to see.
Grand. Really nice in here, other than the smoke. Very grand and plush and ornate. Recommend getting an alcove seat with views across the room.

Beautiful art nouveau setting. We explored this on the ground floor and basement where there is a restaurant and the oldest bar in Prague.We followed this with tea, coffee and cake (Sachertorte) in the cafe. service and drinks/cake were excellent and such a lovely environment to sit and while away some time.

Absolutely gorgeous building. This building is an art nouveau masterpiece. It has a concert hall, exhibition rooms, a couple of restaurants and a bar. If you are in Prague before July 2013, do not miss the Alfons Mucha posters exhibition.
Get thee to the Kavarna!. This building is beautiful, but the best part is the kavarna, a beautiful coffeehouse, where one can order coffee, but also wonderful desserts, beer and wine.

prague symphony orchestra. 75 minutes of brilliant music in at superb Art Nouveau auditorium
The only downside was the room was quite warm and the seats were very uncomfortable so I would take a cushion next time.

Mucha, Mozart & The Davis Cup. We visited the Obecni Dum on Monday 29 April 2013 quite unplanned.We had a very pleasant coffee in the magnificant surroundings of the art-noveau cafe. The prices are steep but the surrounding glamour makes it all worthwhile. We then bought tickets for the Ivan Lendl:Alfons Mucha exhibition which was superb. As we had not joined a tour of the building it also gave us an opportunity to see some of the interior of the building.An added & fortunate bonus for us tennis fans was the fact that the Davis cup was on exhibition for that day only with the Mucha works.While we we there we then decided to buy tickets for a Prague Royal Orchestra performance that evening in the Smetana Hall. One tip here.. we bought seats in Area B & were told that the seating was first come first served & that we could not book any specific seats. We were there early & choose seats at the front of this section only to be moved later by an usher who was persuaded by other clients that they were allocated specific seats (ours) in this section.This was very disappointing. The hall was less than one sixth full in any event.The hall itself is splendid & well worth a visit.
Stunning building. Absolutely beautiful building , inside and out. We didn't eat here but the restaurant and cafe were both stunning

Interesting Art Noveau building. The price of admission is steep but we enjoyed the tour which takes you through quite a few rooms on the second floor. Since its Art Noveau its a bit different than most historical European buildings.

Excellent French food in one most beautiful Art decaux restaurant in centre of Prague. Jacques Auffrays is today the chef in the French restaurant in Obecní dům. I’ll recommend the visit of this place also if you are there not in lunch other the dinner time. Take a just cup of champagne and look around, the place is of such a beauty, that you’ll probably change your schedule and you’ll wait till dinner.

A trip back in time. We went to a symphony here followed by desert at the cafe-a great experience-it was like traveling back in time to a more civilized time before the world wars. A must see/visit in Prague.
Art Nouveau treasure. Just loved the ambience - came to an concert here one night with the Prague Symphony Orchestra - excellent and also saw Alfons Mucha exibition the following day.
Prague concert. I went to the orchestra concert! It's awesome!!! You can feel a very good Energy! The price is among 700 to 1300 kc (1kz = 18 US$) depends on the place you'd like to seat!

Wheelchair accessible.. Enthusiastic and lively performers. Bring a copy of your internet tickets because you are required to leave one set at the entry and have one set to be seated, or you will find yourself in a situation. Quaint elevator for wheelchair access. Uncomfortable chairs. Acoustics average. Food smells from restaurant thoughout the performance.

Beautiful!. Prague's municipal house is a brilliant example of an Art Nouveau building, built in the early 1900's.While the building's exteriors are beautiful, it's what goes inside that is truly amazing – especially in the Smetana hall, where you simply HAVE to listen to a classical concert (mind you – make reservations several days in advance in case you want good seats).

Much ado about Mucha. There couldn't be a better setting for the Lendl Mucha exhibition - which was excellent in its own right, but we also enjoyed admiring the Art Deco features of the Municipal House itself. If you're a fan of the style, be sure to visit all the hidden corners: the gift shop (ground floor), the American ba (downstairs), and the two café/restaurants at street level - all of which are wonderful examples. You don't have to eat/drink anything to enjoy them - though I can recommend the cakes in the café!

You must visit here. When my friends heard I was going to Prague they said with my love of Art Nouveau " You must visit here before you die" well die I did and went to Municipal House Hall heaven.We first went for a quick look and had afternoon tea in the most gorgeous cafe in existence.We went back the next day and did the full guided tour with a brilliant enthusiastic young guide. We went back the next evening and went to dinner with our tour buddies and had a delicious meal in the up-market on site Art Nouveau restaurant. It is a true masterpiece of European design. You must have piece of Czech honey cake from the cart.

Art nouveau-tastic!. We stayed just around the corner from the Municipal House Hall and I so enjoyed walking passed its curved lines every day. Well worth going in and looking around the rooms that are open to the public and enjoying the art nouveau detail - tiles, light fittings etc.

Classical Music Concert. We took advantage of a chance to hear a short recital in the Municipal House. This is a truly extraordinary art nouveau building. Even if you have no interest in music come and see the architecture and beautiful features of the Smetana Hall, the restaurant and Ameriky Bar in the basement. We enjoyed the concert however were disappointed by the amount of noise created by people attending the exhibition in another part of the building. Not only was it annoying for us, it must have been extremely irritating for the musicians. The music was lovely and they deserved better.

How to get on a tour!. Unfortunately we didn't manage to get on a tour for this attraction. If you wish to book a tour you need to get there when the booking office opens at 10.00am. We didn't and all the places were booked up when we arrived. You cannot book in advance- only on the day and spaces are very limited. The house sounds amazing only gave a poor rating since we didn't see it.
art nouveau. beautiful architecture of style art nouveau&art deco. I had tea and pastry in the restaurant at lower level. Really enjoyed the czech atmosphere, away from mass tourists.

Art Nouveau sandwiched between Gothic and Baroque. You need to buy a ticket for a concert there to have a look at the concert hall, but it's well worth it. The two ground level restaurants are just amazing to look at but I urge you to go downstairs too and have a look at the "American Bar" and the traditional pub like restaurant. It's a bit pricey to eat and drink there but you don't need to to enjoy the amazing architecture.
Memorable Night at the Theatre. Highlight of my visit to Prague was a concert at the Obecni Dum.The orchestra was amazing and this wonderful theatre must be experienced.
Took photos.... Didn't go inside, but took pictures of outside balcony-very decorative and beautiful artwork. INXS video filmed on balcony.

Still A Nostalgic Place. This cafe and also separate restaurant are in the Art Nouveau Style. The wonderful ambiance of the whole building with over the top ceiling lights and décor sells delicious cakes and coffee as well as meals. It is like a trip to another era. A short walk from the main town square it is a very popular place staging concerts in it Smetana Hall. Well worth a visit
BEAUTIFUL. Wow, what beautiful Art Deco architecture, inside and out !! We loved it. You can see / hear classical concerts there. We didn't get time to do this, but I wish we did !!

Art Nouveau blown up.. It is a very classic example of Art Nouveau on a large scale: it is nothing spectacular per se, but the size of it makes it interesting. Just walk by quickly and take a couple of pictures.

Go early to book your tour. Our local guide recommended a visit to this building. I really like Art Nouveau, so I went there next morning at 9:45 to queue up to get tickets. They sell a limited number of tickets from 10 am and the tour starts at 11 am. For me it was really worth it, as the guided tour is the only way to see some of the rooms inside. If you are buying tickets for a concert, you can of course see the Smetana Hall during the concert.The tour last an hour and the guide was very informative, although she was quite abrupt and seemed very stressed. The cost is 280CK per person ( about 10GBP)

Fantastic Art Nouveau. This building is the best example of art nouveau I have ever seen. Book the visit that takes you to areas not normally available to the public. There appear to be two a day (35 people per tour) so get there early to buy your ticket.

Outstanding. This hall was the perfect spot to take in a Classical Concert. Gorgeous building, very unique. The sounds from the symphony was amazing. It sounded better than any stereo or headphones money could buy. Well worth a visit, get your tickets early.

The best of classical music in Prague. Municipal House is a magnificent Art Nouveau building on Náměstí Republiky. The main concert hall of this complex, the Smetana Hall, was the place of the proclamation of the independence of Czechoslovakia. It is a wonderful room, with adorned walls, decorative stained glass ceiling and many golden lamps. There are beautiful classical music concerts almost everyday. The Municipal House Café is also impressive and it is worth a visit before the concert.
go inside!. different restaurant and price also music and excellent building even a shop and fountain art deco building the best maintein in prague

Very decorative. This hall has 2 Resturants a Concert Hall and the oldest pub in Prague. I ate in one resturant to the left when you enter the hall. the desert trolley is beautiful and can recommend the pub food to. the building has some beautiful features inside and out.

Municipal House Hall. For me this is the most spectacular building in Prague and believe me there are some stupendous buildings. Fully restored to its Baroque finest it is truly breathtaking. They should be proud of it. As well as a concert hall it has a bar area and restaurant.

Gorgeous theatre!. This is a really striking building. Can buy tickets at the desk for evening classical music performances. It was quite expensive but as it was a once-off while in Prague and the music was incredible as is the theatre, we thought it was worth it!!

Must See. As you stroll through Old Town make sure to see the Municipal House. It's truely one of the most beautiful buildings I've ever seen. The details and architecture are amazing. If you have time get an afternoon coffe or beer in the cafe.

Obecni Dum. My wife and I had dinner on our last night in Prague. Lovely service, beautiful surroundings and a fantastic night. The food (Goulash) was amazing, and to sit in such a wonderful building and pay such a reasonable amount was fantastic. Go there for dinner or lunch and suck in the atmosphere

A remarkable building with a fascinating history.. We took the guided tour which - at first glance- seemed somewhat pricey at approximately £10 per person. However, it was such an interesting tour and such a beautiful building that we both felt it was money well-spent. The guide not only filled us in on the history of the Municipal Building itself, but also the history of Prague, its inhabitants and - indeed - the Czech Republic. Something different for your trip to Prague.

Good food!. This dinner was in the Czech restaurant.there is also a French restuarant in the Municipal House.I had pasta with mushrooms which was delicious.The European pasta noodles are very broad and tasty ! European style of cooking is also superior! The hall was magnificent and i believe is about one hundred years old.There was also some traditional Czech music and entertainment.It is worth a dining here ! My husband loved his beef and mushroom stroganoff on a hot bed of steaming rice!
A old municipial centre. This place has a lot of interesting rooms and species, for concerts and festivities. The is also the famous Francouska Restaurant within it walls
Stop for some refreshment. Very nice coffee house and the restaurant looked nice but we didn't have time to eat there - but would if we return to Prague in the future

Great art nouveau building. we went here to see a performance of Czech composers by the Royal Czech Orchestra. The building is an absolutlely stunning piece of archtecture. The orchestra performed flawlessly

Beautiful on the outside, and inside restaurants. Outside, the Municipal House is amazing with its gold dome and painted facade. Inside, you will not be able to see the stunning inner rooms unless you purchase a ticket for a concert, or visit one of the restaurants inside, which are ornate, gilded and elegant.

A step back on time with everything you would expect from a high class establishment.. We ate in the cafe restaurant and went on to watch a concert in one of the incredible halls. The quality of the refurbishment that they have done in this building is incredible. Combined with the excellent service from the friendly staff this is a great place to eat, dine or enjoy a concert. Highly recommended.Don't pay for the high price seats for a concert. The view and sound is just as good from the cheapest seats.

Don't miss it. This spectacular Art Nouveau building houses a great cafe (very reasonably priced for lunch), an amazing fine dining French restaurant (not Prague cheap, but have a meal like this anywhere else in Europe and you'll pay twice as much), a couple of other bars and eateries and a beautiful concert hall. I had dinner at Francouzska's (French reataurant), then went to a chamber music concert. The hall was really empty which detracted from the experience, however the performance was great, and I had an all round enjoyable evening.Recommended, but plan a major concert to really experience the place I suspect.

Con artists. The absolute pits.. We booked to spend our final night here after being so impressed by the Prague Philharmonic Orchestra a few nights previous. The concert was advertised as 'Prague Orchestra' and we were told by two separate Municipal House workers that this was a very important and special event for Prague. Foolishly paid 25 pounds each a ticket (the cheapest on offer, double what we'd paid for the Philharmonic) to find 8 messily displayed stands on stage and only 100 guests, all of whom were tourists like ourselves. On top of the hugely inflated ticket price, we were then also forced to pay to have our coats hung in storage. A group of ten violinists and a keyboard player appeared and played songs on their practice instruments and it was very clear (I am a musician myself) that none of the members of this 'orchestra' had in fact played together before. After an hour of rushed and slightly botched performance, the musicians meekly exited the stage, only for the lead violinist to re-enter, take a second bow and then hush the audience to tell us that he would be selling his CDs at the back of the hall! An audible groan rose from the audience. All left looking as annoyed and unimpressed as us. Naturally, no member of staff could be found anywhere on exit. A complete and utter waste of money, time and a final night in Prague. An absolute and outrageous tourist scam like none I have seen before.

Splendid. Another aesthetic delight mixed with great sadness : this is the country and the culture Western democracies abandoned to the nazi beasts. This is what the Czechs could achieve artistically. Don't miss the cafe on the left as you walk in. Not only is the room so grand and so refined you cannot believe your eyes but the hot chocolate is literally out of this world--the cakes are not bad either (very reasonably priced too).
great party. Went to a reception for 1200 people - it's a great place, good caterers, memorable decor, most enjoyable. And very atmospheric.
beautiful. The Municipal house hall is very beautiful and wel conservated. How can a place that was included on an INXS video not be cool?

Not Bad!. It is a nice hall and acoustics are very good. I went there for a concert which was performed by only 8 musicians. The quality was good but I felt cheated because I paid a total of 98 sterling pounds for two tickets with booking fees for a show of one hour while they performed for just 40 minutes and only 8 musicians!!! I wouldn't recommend it for a tour. If there are good shows then it would be nice to visit. The restaurant is expensive!
Awesome building. This building has been refurbished and is absolutely beautiful. If only all municipal buildings looked like this! It looks from the outside like a grand old Opera house,

Great place for dinner and a show. loved this place. had the most amazing Moravian wine there for a very reasonable price and the food was excellent. stayed on for a quintet concert with a soprano. The musicians were excellent. overall definitely worth the small amount of money that was paid for the experience. would highly recommend it.
clock tower. LOVED!!! you must go to the top and see the view. I am normally one to hate such things but, this was beautiful and one of the moments I most loved when visiting prague!

Magestic concert hall and cafe. The Municipal House is one of the best example of art-nouveau style which is quite common in Prague. We went to the concert in the evening, a small string ensemble doing a gig that lasts for one hour and is obviously a tourist-targeted performance. That being said, it's not a bad performance and what's more interesting is the concert hall itself. Simply beautiful! It's worthwhile of buying a cheap ticket (we bought the cheapest one at 730 krons) just to see the hall! The cafe on the ground floor to the left of the main entrance is also very nice. It has become a bit snobbish, unfortunately, but it still has this turn-of-the-century, grandiose, noble feeling.

Problem seating. My husband and I went to a 1 hour concert in the evening. The concert was very good BUT if it had been any more than 1 hour long, we would have walked out based on the fact that the seating was too painful! It was like sitting on a brick and the worst seating I have ever experienced in a Concert Hall. One hour on these seats was about 45 minutes too long!

classical music concert, opera and ballet. Throughout Prague there was ample opportunity to attend concerts of every style and era, both for free and with reserved tickets. We attended a two hour performance for what amounted to 25 Euro a person. The theatre had possibly 100 patrons and could house a thousand if not more. We were entertained with a mix of live Classical Orchestra music by Beethovan, Chopin, Mozart to name a few. Ballet Dancers and Opera singers perfomed with the Orchestra in full costume. Each piece introduced either a pair of dancers or singers. The event was magnificent the venue was beautiful and afterward, we enjoyed dinner in the dining hall.

A very nice surprise. Not mentioned in our guide, but what a nice surprise when we stumbled into it. What wonderful architecture! Have a look at the stunning cafes and restaurants and definitely have a heavenly hot chocolate at the cafe upstairs.

Beautiful Prague. The Municipal House is definitely a must see. It is absolutely beautiful. We took the tour that happens every 2 hours and you visit the beautiful rooms on the upper floors. The silk wall coverings and the plastered ceilings are magnificent. If you are an "Art Deco" fan this place cannot be beat. Also, the sidewalk cafe serves terrific food and there is also 2 restaurants inside that are all preserved Art Deco decor.

The Municipal Cafe. This has got to be the most decidant afternooon tea I have had since I went for a treat at The Waldorf in London. The place is beautiful, the art deco look and the grand room just breathtaking. The service was perfect so special. The food beautiful and served with panache. But the most amazing thing is the cake trolley! I have not seen so many beautiful cakes on one trolley, the choice was immense. The price was very reasonable too. As I said a real treat and one I will have to repeat for sure.

Do not buy ticket for concert!!!
Rip-off. Lovely building!We booked tickets to one of the concerts, so disappointing. 800cz for 2 people, it was 70 minutes of 5 people in a side room with no charisma playing there instruments, bored after 10minutes!

Concert in the Smetana hall. The municipal house is a stunning art nouveau building. The outside is impressive and the 'cafe' is beautiful- well worth a look. We went to a concert in the Smetana hall which at 700 crowns (the cheaper seats) was enthusiastically priced for an hour with what was really an ensemble rather than an orchestra. (Prague Royal Orchestra). There was only a scattering of people in the large hall which detracted from the concert atmosphere but the acoustics are great.

A must see Cafe/Restuarant. The Municipal House on Republic Square, next to the Powder Gate is a magnificent Art Nouveu building containing cafes, restaurants and beer cellar. It was the location of the declaration of Czech independance. It serves the best coffee/cake in town at reasonable prices and the level of detail and service is something to behold. It might look a bit forbidding at first glance in an old fashioned and elegant way but it is well worth a visit or two.

Art Nouveau at its Best.. Central Europe is one of the best places to see Art Nouveau architecture at its best and the Municipal House, Prague has to be one of the great examples. There are two restaurants on the ground floor, both a bit pricey but worth it just to see the building. The auditorium is home to the Prague Symphony Orchestra They do give all sorts of concerts here, some I have been told are tourist traps so if you want to go try and get a Prague S.O. concert. Prague is an incredibly beautiful city, this is just one of many places to marvel at. It is extremely touristy in the high season which totally spoils the atmosphere, I go there between New Year and Easter when it is quieter and much, much more enjoyable. Last visit March 2009

LOVELY BUILDING WITH NICE LOCAL FOOD DOWNSTAIRS. This is a wonderful art deco building well worth a visit. You can buy concert and theatre tickets in the lobby here. there is a great local cuisine restaurant downstairs at affordable prices. there is a 25 local table charge per person but it includes lots of bread and a schnapps to finish. It has live folk music in the evenings.The menu is good but if you order the duck or the pork knee we suggest you share between two as it is quite large. They do accept payment by credit cards.Waiters are not over talkative but do not hang around for tips etc.The restaurant by the lobby is nice but very expensive.
Beautiful. Fabulous food and service in the restaurant - great for special occasions - expensive but worth it for a special occasion
Amazing building. Didnt get to eat here but looked round the building which was beautiful. It looked as if the food would be lovely and the concerts there would be special

Orchestra concert was actually an octet, still enjoyable if a bit overpriced. I went to a "The best of Mozart and Dvorak" concert in Smetlana Hall at Municipal House by the "Prague Music Orchestra". I turned up to the hall 90min before the performance and got the cheapest student ticket for 500czk. I feel this is a bit of a tourist trap... The "orchestra" was actually an octet and the hall was very empty when the concert began so we all moved to the front couple of rows. The hall is very lovely to look at, the musicians talented and I did enjoy the repertoire. Not sure if I might have got cheaper tickets if I had bought then 5 minutes before the performance...
what better place for music. Art nouveau setting for the Prague Symphony Orchestra. Also works well for smaller musical orchestrations
best place for an afternoon coffee. at the Kavarna We went there and they had also live band ,with jazz of course ,and it was perfect .My girls loved it .

A great place to get a very good b-fast. Before you walk in take a good look - the front was painted by Alfons Mucha - a great Czech painter (you will encounter his work all over Prague). Suggest you get yourself a nice table close to the windows - a good people watching place with a bonus of a good breakfast.
Not your usual municipal building. This building represents the epitome of art nouveau architecture and decoration. The most beautiful performance venue I have ever visited.
Impressive !. Been there for a piano concert in the Smetana hall, great acoustics, the hall is impressive as the rest of the building . I think combining the visit with a concert is great value.
Stunning Building. A really stunning building - we went to a concert in the Smetana Hall which had great acoustics. At night the exterior is lit up beautifully.
So wonderful building. Both, interior and exterior of this building are amazing, I think tourists who visit Prague should not miss this
MUST See and dine.... One of the most important buildings in Prague, the chef is Michelin and Jaques is a wonderful person to chat with. The Mucha's, the ambiance .... fantastic !

Gorgeous Building - go to a show. Went to the Prague Symphony Orchestra for US$30 between two people. Stunning acoustics. Gorgeous building. Don't let the sitting in the back few rows bother you - you'll be first out for intermission and hey, where else can you hear a world class performance for $15 a head. Movies cost more than that. Just went in on the day of the performance and still had cheap seats left.

Watch closely where your show will be, so you don't get dispapointed. They run several shows per day, and you may end attending to one at the smaller rooms in the basement of the hall. Still, the sound, particularly for music, is quite good even on the smaller/basement rooms

Fabulous & not expensive. By far the best tour we've done in Prague. Outstanding decor in the rooms and a very interesting and knowledgeable guide. Ticket cost 250 czk, didnt include a photo pass but this was very cheap and well worth it, be warned the guide will stop you from taking pics if you dont have a pass. At the end of the tour you get a complimentary drink in the American bar which is in the basement. The most annoying thing with the Municipal House is that the web site for visits/tours in only in Czech. Considering the number of foreign visitors I'm really surprised they've not updated their web site. Tickets can only be bought on the day, ample cloakroom space for coats and toilet facilities are fine.

Beautiful building staff disappointing. We hoped to experience a concert and went into the ticket office to book. Sadly we were sold a ticket for e wrong night. The nest day we called to exchange the ticket but the lady at the ticket office was counting money so told us to find someone else, we tried to do so but were sent back to this lady who was very impolite and turned her back on us and refused to help. We lost 1100 kc and didn't get to see a concert. We had tried to email but the site directs you to an external booking site who say they have no contact with municipal house. I'm sure the concert would have been lovely it is a beatifful building with nice looking restaurants within

Try to attend a concert in this lovely hall. We spent our last night in Prague attending a concert with a full orchestra in the Municipal Hall. The lavish Smetana Hall is the perfect venue for a concert with its stunning décor and fine acoustics.After the concert we dined in the equally stunning French Restaurant within the building. (We had coffee one morning in the café opposite the restaurant one morning, also beautiful.)This building is worth exploring both inside and out, and definitely worth a stop for a meal or simply a warm cup of coffee.

Magnificent. The Municipal House its well worth an hour of anyone's time. The tour is relatively expensive by Czech standards (290CZK) but the splendour on offer is unsurpassed, the height of Art Nouveau / Deco. I've never seen anything like it. Tora are irregular and you can only book for that day's tour so get there early, buy your tickets and come back for your tour later. Having a cake in the cafe is pleasant but absolutely no substitution. Go.
Art nouveau gem. Cafes, restaurants, concert hall, all in fantastic art nouveau settings. It's no longer as cheap as it was, but it's still central to Prague life, even if now full of tourists.

An amazing afternoon!. Since we were on a tour, our group was only scheduled for a lunch stop. The art deco style was mesmerizing all through the stairway, dining area, restrooms, etc. It was a perfect spot for our group to have a meal and discuss the good times of our tour of Prague and the food was tasty! I would like to go back to spend more time to see the rest of the building.

Atmospheric. This is a beautiful building and well worth the visit.We ate an excellent lunch at the cafe on the ground floor and there is another good restaurant downstairs. On the opposite corner of the street you will find A super cafe for coffee,cakes etc.and the best cup of tea in Prague.
Go for the guided tour!. I would recommend to go for the guided tour as you can go to parts of the Opera that is not open to the general public/when you attend any concerts in the Smetana Hall.
Good lunch. We had a lovely lunch here, but was disappointed that we couldn't see the concert room, as there was a private function. The decoration is wonderful - beautiful tiling.

A must see in Prague. The building is beautiful on the exterior and interior, a good representation of art nouveau style.The cafe is nice, a little more expensive than other restaurants, but a nice atmosphere.We saw a concert in the Smettana hall and I found it a little overpriced. The sound and the general acoustic of the room were not excellent, as I would have expected. The concert seemed to be made for tourists without too much attention to details.
Everything under one roof !. I like it here and I can remember it before it was "properly" done up.There's a good cafe, a good restaurant and any concert in the Smetana Sal will delight you !

Wow!. The most beautiful building I have seen yet. I love Art Nouveau and this is just treat upon treat. Different in each room. Great place for a concert - but try and book a 2 hour one. Food really good too.
Amazing beautiful building. Steeped in history, houses the oldest pub in prague. Concerts held regularly in such splendid surroundings. Another must if you go to Prague!

Art Nouveau Delight. I was not able to book a tour of this building, but thoroughly enjoyed roaming the open areas with beautiful art nouveau design. The American bar was a quiet and lovely sanctuary from crowds and the cold.
superb Art Nouveau!. superb Art Nouveau exterior and interior of cafe. Go only for the loveliness of the design, the live music is charming, but the service is very so-so,

Very nice place to be seen, dreadful restaurant. As an architectural monument, it is just very nice, most of the decoration was created by Mucha, so it has to be seen. Eating their in the "outside" restaurant .... terrible.

Good food and service. The large dining hall downstairs offers very good local cuisine. Take a camera to photograph all the art deco scenes. Book a performance at inside street level window. Excellent classical performances are downstairs.

Mecca for Art Nouveau lovers. The details in this building are amazing. So impressive to see creativity carried out to the most minute detail.
