The tour will allow you to see several of the public rooms with stunning works of art, lamps, woodwork, murals, tiles, etc. So amazing. There are tours, but not every day, so plan ahead. Space is limited so you must buy tickets early - they are available at the cash desk only on the day of the tour, starting at 10 AM. For Kcs 55 extra you should also buy a camera permit to take photos. You can finish in the lower level by having a drink at the bar (you get a token for one as part of the tour). You can also eat in the lovely Plzenska restaurant, also in the lower level. A nice atmosphere and the food is quite OK.

This is a gem worth visiting. This is such a beautiful building. Check out all the details from stained glass to beautiful tiles. We ate in the basement and had a lovely lunch. Then I came back later and had coffee and cake in the cafe. Both places were atmospheric and lovely.

Ate downstairs in the beer hall. We ate here 4 years ago and decided to try it again, we popped in on the Saturday but the restaurant was so busy we left, we hadnt booked, I think booking is advisable at weekends, so we went back on Sunday evening, the place was much quieter & we easily got a table. The food is very good Czech fair. Beware of the 5K cover charge

An art nouveau lover's delight.. This is probably the most flamboyant of the many, many art nouveau buildings in Prague. Have coffee in the over-priced cafe, just to soak up the beauty. Be sure to visit the beer-hall downstairs to see the mosaics (don't know anything about the food). And use the cafe's restrooms upstairs so you can get a different view of the room. Everywhere you look there is something beautiful. Tours of the building are available for a fee.

Art Nouveau at its best. Lovely building with restaurants, cafe bar, cocktail bars and concert hall.Take time to have a break in the coffee shop on the ground floor- real 1930's decadence, lovely space and a cake trolley to drool over- and only 100 Krona each(about £3 each all handmade fresh everyday) Expected to pay over the top but only paid what I would in a Costa back home but the experience was much better.

Lovely music hall. The hall contains a major concert venue and a smaller music room downstairs. Downstairs is less expensive shorter concerts, but provides a more intimate experience. The American bar offers refreshment, convenient for before or after the concert. Upstairs are 2 restaurants- a white table cloth French restaurant and a coffee shop across the hall providing Czech food and a ice pastry cart.

Bohemian Art Nouveau. Obecni Dum is the perfect example of the unique Bohemian Art Nouveau architectural style. There is a restaurant on the ground floor where while dining there you will be transported to the beginning of the 20th Century. Even the wait staff dresses accordingly.

Music, music. The main reason to visit the Municipal House Hall is to listen to music, but the building itself is interesting. My advice, go for a concert that takes place in the main theatre, the Smetana Hall, and try to find a programme that includes Smetana and/or Dvorjak, the two main Czech composers. The Smetana Hall has nice frescoes and an interesting architecture. Chairs are hard enough to avoid anyone sleeping or snoring...

Art Noveau heaven. Obecni Dum / Municipal House is centrally located and hard to miss, but if you like art noveau, take an extra look! There is a lovely cafe on the ground floor. Downstairs is a Czech restaurant with ok food - but with outstanding decor, really lovely. There is also a shop at the lower level. If you don't have time for a guided tour of the house, do have a look at the magnificent staircases. The big concert hall, Smetana hall, is also very nice.
Lunch in the Art Deco cafe!. One of my best memories was having lunch here! The waiters and the dessert trolley were well worth stepping back in time for - fabulous!
Beautiful Art Nouveau building & interior.. We enjoyed a symphony concert in this building and the captivating decor. This historic building is a visual delight!

Concert and restaurant. Check with the concert schedule. Different concerts daily. Good acoustic for music lovers. Way better than those organ concert at the churches.There are two restaurants in Obecni Dum: one is of higher end while another relatively lower. I tried the cheaper one, and yet, it's very delicious. Ordered braised beef with Czech "dumplings" and salmon fillet. Portion is right on for me but may be a little bit small for big eaters. Two main courses plus two drinks, only cost me Kc600. Decent price~!

Great concert venue. On our first night in Prague, we attended a classical concert here. Ticket price was a bit expensive but we loved the Art Nouveau architecture - anyway, a memorable 1st night in Prague.

Beautiful Art Deco style buidling. If you like Art Deco, this buidling is a must. I was blown away by the designs inside and the beauty of the buidlings interior. Only wished I had seen a concert there.

The Municipal House. Rebuilt after a fire in the 1800s, this beautiful concert hall always has programs of some sort offered (we went to and classical music symphony of Mozart, Strauss and others) and the hall is magnificent for sound. Take an evening to enjoy a concert!

magnificent. The Municipal House is a magnificent building that is all Art Deco. Smetana Hall, inside, has fabulous art work. The lift I took to the balcony was made of glass with brass fittings and a green velvet seat. Even the decor in the hallways of the basement, where there is a restaurant, is fabulous.

Amazing Building. The term "Municipal House" does not do justice to this impressive art nouveau building. It was really a cultural centre for the Czech people to assert their culture within the germanic Habsburg empire. No expense was spared to create a very spectacular building. Be sure to take a tour to get full information on how the rooms were decorated and the materials used. After the tour, you end up at the bar in the basement for a drink as part of your ticket.

Amazing art deco building. This does not appear as one of the top sites of Prague but it is truely beautiful and well worth the time. It would however not come before the Castle square and the old town sqaure. Stop in the office to see when tours are scheduled as they are not the same time every day. They have a monthly schedule posted at the desk. The tour includes a free drink in the American Bar downstairs also beautiful art deco. The building has amazing rooms and the tour guide that we had really knew her history. She explained about the choice of colors and the fabric in the various rooms. Well worth the time if you have more than a day in Prague.

Art nouveau masterpiece. Went to a concert (Beethoven & Mozart) and thoroughly enjoyed the surroundings as well as the music. The artwork /lighting /architecture are literally beautiful and worth a look round even if you are not having a meal or attending a concert.
Breathtaking. Well worth a visit to see this spectacular example of Art Nouveau. Both the cafe and restaurant were busy so be prepared to wait; but there is much to appreciate.
Beautiful. It is a beautiful example of Art Nouveau architecture. Like any center in Prague is well preserved. The outside mosaics are beautiful
Fabulous concert. Well worth a visit if only to look round this interesting Art Deco building. Really enjoyed the concert.

take the tour. We visited the municipal house and took the guided tour - the tour guide was excellent. The interior is beautiful and we enjoyed visiting the different rooms. We also visited the beer hall and the cafe. We definitely preferred the cafe.

Prague Symphony Orchestra Smetana Hall. We attended a concert of the Prague Symphony Orchestra directed by Heiko M. Foerster, with Chloe Hanslip playing the violine, supported by around 50 musicians or so. Excellent performance in the very impressive Smetana Hall. Where on earth can you find a better example of Art Deco at its best. Performance were pieces of Brahms, Beethoven and Janacek, including the concert break playing over two hours at a price of 460 CZK per person. It was money well spend. Different tickets can be purchased. Be careful of the cheaters in the same location of Municipal House (Oebcni Dum) selling tickets for various performances of the Prague Royal Orchestra, playing very famous music pieces. But we heard the orchestra consists only of 12 musicians or so, playing 65 minutes in a much smaller hall, with tickets around 800 CZK? Go check the information inside the Municipal House to find out more what is on, prices and so on.

IF YOU WANT TO SEE ART DECO. Since we like art Deco we where stunned the Dining Room was spectacular. Although we ate in the casual dining room whichwas also very beautiful. Service not as great but you just go with the flow.

Book a concert and its a great way to see the hall. Enjoyed the music, wonderful surroundings, but the hall not equal to the beautiful Rudolfinum hall. A good cup of coffee in the cafe on the ground floor and good clean loos too!

A real gem. What a surprise this building is We took the organised tour with a guide and were amazed by this Art Nouveau building. there is a reasonable priced restaraunt with a real wow facor in the premisis. A must do in Prague

old world elegance. From the outside, both day and night, the building is so beautiful. The first floor dining room is reminiscent of old world elegance and movies of by gone eras. We ate on the second level. The food was fair but the waiter was impossible. He was angry even that he had to bring us the necessary silverware and water. Spoiled the evening.

Brilliant art nouveau building. Next to the Powder tower. Go inside and take a look or even a cup of coffee in the art nouveau cafe. Or even book a concert. The mosaic outside is under repair (October 2012)

Favorite Building in Prague. If you are seeking the Art Nouveau heritage in Prague, this is not to be missed. Its performance hall and restaurants are absolutely worth a visit. You will need to take the tour to see most of it.

Book the Tour. The Municipal House in Prague makes for an enjoyable 1-2 hour tour followed by a nice beer and a meal. It’s located in Revolution Square next to the Powder Tower (which can also be viewed from inside, but we didn’t venture in). As it’s a concert hall you can also attend one of the many concerts that are staged there, but again despite being tempted we never went. To book a tour go inside and quite a way back (signposted). There are only a few tours per day, and the numbers are limited so it’s better to book in advance. You pay a small extra charge for your photography pass, and it is worth it. The tour takes you into the concert hall, and then on to the many art deco/nouveau rooms and halls within. They each have their own character, and your guide will fill you in the relevant bits of history. All of the rooms are very attractive. Do make sure you take the chance to clap in the centre of the circular conference room. It’s quite fun (you’ll understand when you get there). You finish with a free beer in The American Bar – apparently Prague’s oldest. I can recommend a meal in the restaurant next to the American Bar. It serves Czech food as opposed to the French in the street-level restaurant, and very good Czech food at that. It’s a little more expensive than many restaurants (although by no means exorbitant), but you are sitting in an art deco hall and the food is definitely better than average. The duck is excellent, the quantities ample, the staff friendly, and you get a nice aquavit digestive to finish. It’s a large hall, so getting a table shouldn’t be a problem. They also serve a dark beer to go with the standard Pilsner Urquell just for a change.

YOU CAN ONLY GO AT 1PM and 4PM. You can only go around in guided tours which leave at 1pm and 4pm. We got there shortly after 4pm and couldn't go. I couldn't comment on the quality of the exhibits or guides, just make sure you show up at the right time.

Beautiful setting. We were a group of 20 with reservations. The place was packed, with very few servers! It took one hour to get our meal and it was served lukewarm. Not a way to win customers! All of us agreed we made a mistake in going there. The food would not give me any reason to return or recommend to friends. The saving race was the accordion player. An older man with white hair and a smile. He made our evening! While we were drinking our beers and waiting for food, we sang along with his playing in our own languages!

Oozing with Atmosphere. This Art Nouveau structure includes a lovely cafe (great lunch spot) and the gorgeous Smetana Hall, where I enjoyed a wonderful concert by the Prague Dvorak Symphony Orchestra.

Do a concert. We booked a classical concert in this magnificent hall. The interior and the orchestra exceeded our expectations. Better than the two overpriced concerts we unfortunately attended in Vienna. We will return to Prague. Its charming.
Welcome stop. On a tour of the city and before a concert in the Municipal Hall why not stop here for a snack and coffee. Beautifully ornate restaurant with helpful and friendly staff,

Can't Miss This One!. The Municipal House sounds boring... it's not.This magnificent building provides a window into Prague's extraordinary past, its social scene over the centuries and the artists and architects that contributed to the creation of this structure.Take a tour guide. THe history is fascinating but complex and needs interpretation. Music, art, and for the final act, stop in at the cafe near the entrance for an unbeatable desert and expresso.

Tourist Concerts at the Municipal House. Prague is a city filled with ample opportunities to enjoy beautiful classical music, performed by some of the city's best musicians. But there is a difference between these nightly little mini-concerts performed for the constant flow of tourists, and the main events. I've heard wonderful things about concerts in The Municipal House, mainly because of the venue. So last April when my husband and I were in Prague, we booked tickets for a concert there. Buyer beware! The concert's venue was actually in a long, narrow room in the basement, and the musicians seemed that they'd performed the pieces a few too many times - it was a rather heartless performance.So, this past month when I returned to Prague, I was determined to attend another concert, only to make sure that it was in The Municipal House's main auditorium, Smetana Hall. The tickets were not cheap - about 75 Euros each. I was surprised that the seating area was just a flat floor with a lot of chairs. The musicians gave a good performance. However, there was an adjoining hall where one of Prague's other numerous tourist concerts was taking place. Not only could the music from the other hall be heard, it was quite distracting. It wasn't fair to our musicians, and it certainly was not a concert worth the amount we'd paid. And then after only an hour, the concert ended. Disappointing to say the least.
nice building awful coffee. 6 euros for two burned coffees and waiters that make you feel like they are sparing your life are just not worth the otherwise great interiors

Splendid Art Nouveau building. We took a guided tour of the building, tockets from the information centre inside. (Tours are at varying times, best to check on the day) Our tour was in English with a knowledgeable and enthusiastic guide. The tour visited several of the rooms, each designed in a different theme within the Art Nouveau style, including the Smetana Hall and the splendid Lord Mayors Hall with murals by Mucha. The information centre has a rather good museum shop, and sells tickets for the concerts and other events held in the Hall nearly every day. Also in the building and open to the public are the Restaurant (very expensive), and Cafe (reasonably priced for coffee and cakes) on the ground floor, both splendidly decorated in Art Nouveau style, and in the basement are a traditional restaurant and a bar.

Great exprience and beautiful site. We had a cofee and a a cake at the restaurant and that was magnificent. Nicely decorated with art deco lamps and stuf. The next evening we went to a concert in the Smetana hall and that is a fine experience. Dinner, expencive but nice, in the restaurant befor. A good avening out.

Art Nouveau in abundance.. Absolutely amazing building. The external architecture is a clue to the interior, but nothing could prepare you for the breathtaking beauty and abundance of Alfonse Mucha's designs.
Don't miss it!
Free visit, must see. Please go inside and just look the decoratives! If you like art deco you have to see this and if you do not know art deco so well after visit I guess you like to learn more.

Just the outside is enought to make you gasp. The outside is amazing, the inside is incredible! There's a cafe where you can have some coffee, cake, or small sandwiches. Everything is in Art Nouveau and Art Deco. Outside the building is filled with statues and paintings. You can go to concerts on the upper floor at night, and on the -1 floor there is an amazingly delicious czech cuisine restaurant. The food is really good and the way the decoration is made, it looks like it's daytime all through the night. Everyone should go just to see the building, but I would recommend also going to a concert and to dinner there!
Beautiful. Saw a chamber music concert in the Art Nouveau Hall. Outstanding performance. Stunning place! The stain glass windows are beautiful and there is a hidden gem of a restaurant downstairs
Like the tour!. We took a tour on Obecni Dum & like it-the tour guide spoke good English & was very informative. We went downstairs to Pilzenska Restorace for a hearty lunch.
Fabulous Building. The highlight of our visit to Prague. The most fabulous art deco interior rooms, also packed with history. Must be seen!
Beautiful building. A magnificent building with restaurants and concert venues. We had lunch and attended an evening jazz concert there. Well worth a visit just to see the art and sculptures.
Excellent afternoon tea with live band. Had a delightful tea in AMAZING art deco setting listening to jazz. You really can't beat it. Dessert trolley could easily be a girls undoing!

house fine, restaurant BAH!. The sidewalk restaurant at the Municipal House serves ,at best mediocre food, service is lousy. what the food lacks in flavor it makes up for by being small portions. really would not want a large helping of that.

Grand Setting for Mozart & Strauss!. A concert in the Smetana Hall of Mozart & Johann Strauss mesmerised us one evening & introduced us to this stunning Obecni Dum! What a grand setting for a lovely memorable evening of music & ballet!

A liberty style dinner. Sit there and look around.
You'll feel part of the past.
It's a wonderful place and you can eat something (better beer than wine.....). I love liberty style and I love this place

Excellent for concerts and special private events!. If you are in Prague on a short break, a concert from the famous Czech orchestras is a must to see. The first floor is very much used for large special private catering and music events/awards. On the front of the building there are some restaurants, I have visited Francouska - something to forget about, possibly the worst meal and service I have had in my life.
must see. incredible art nouveau building, you MUST take the guided tour to see the insides. Fantastically beautiful and rare.

Good music. Obviously the music varies from night to night, but it was good to take in a classical music concert in Prague. The only problem was that the seats were very uncomfortable -- hard. But the music was good.

Lovely. The municipal house can only be viewed via a guided tour by a municipality official. This would not be a problem, but I felt that the tour could have been longer and more comprehensive. That said, the rooms which we saw are gorgeous and well preserved examples of art-nouveau style and the tour guide explained some pretty interesting things about the place. I also heard a concert in the smaller concert hall here and it was great!

A must see for art deco fans. An impressive display of art deco. Informative tours are offered, but get your tickets early in the day. The ticket office opens at 10 am and you should get there a few minutes early to assure the tour of your choice.

Really nice time at classical concert with kids. We took our kids -- ages 9 and 7 -- to an evening performance of Vivaldi, Pachelbel and Brahms. The performance was very nice and a good choice for the kids, as the pieces were all very accessible and the performance not too long. The building is gorgeous. The staff friendly and helpful. The cafe out front had a very rude waitress but was otherwise a nice place to sit outside and eat.

Impressive building. A very interesting tour of some beautiful rooms. Admission price seemed a little expensive but it included a drink in the American Bar. You have to pay extra to take photos.There are only two or three tours per day so go in advance to get tickets.The tour group was quite large, which meant we spent a lot of time moving between rooms.Bizarrely, the family ticket (2 adults + up to 2 children) is cheaper than 2 adult tickets, but you can't buy it unless you actually have children. So if you can borrow a child to take with you, you can save some money! :o)

Outstanding Art Deco. The hall has concerts from time to time which are worth going to listen. Though the real attraction to the Municipal House is the outstanding art deco designs that are on display in the cafe and restaurants. Truly amazing.
Beautiful concert hall. A concert in the beautiful Smetana Hall was a wonderful experience. We enjoyed a glass of wine at the cafe outside beforehand.

Municipal House. Definitely worth a visit! We went to a concert there and it was wonderful. The musicians are professionals and the program was varied. The performing space is stunning! We bought the "A" tickets for the "B" price. Negotiate with the lady selling the tickets at the ticket window. There were not many in attendance. You could buy the "C" ticket and sit in the balcony and still have a good view and for less money.

wow!. Probably the finest example of Art Nouveau in the world. No expense spared in bringing this building up to scratch. Worth visiting just for the architecture and design. Mind blowing building and something of a MUSt when visiting Prague

Building beautiful, skip the "tourist" performances. Enough said with the other reviews of the building which I agree with. I went to experience the sounds of the Smetana Hall with the "Virtuosi Prangenses Orchestra" performing at 8PM a set of Famous Classical Masterpieces. Well the program sounded good with Mozart, Smetana, and Dvorak highlighting the bill BUT the actual performances were second rate at best. I should have opted for a full concert somewhere else to experience Prague at it's musical core but August is not concert season time. At the night I went, the theater was about 5% full. I also not knowing I purchased a VIP ticket (1300 Kc) which gave me a private box for an "orchestra" of about 20 people which was way too small to really test out the hall's acoustics. To be honest, any seat in the place would have been fine for this. The program lasted for about 75 minutes with no encores and classics like Mozart's "Eine Kleine Nachtmusik" were severely truncated. Also the concertos seemed like practice sessions for the key performers with noticeable mistakes. I would definitely hit this again during "real" concert season.

Art Nouveau creme de la creme. If you like art nouveau, then it's worth travelling any amount of miles to spend time in this gem of a building in Prague. Opened in 1912, it is where Czechoslovakia's independence was signed, and it's features celebrate Czech nationality with some of the nation's most gifted artists, sculptors and craftsmen of the time, involved in creating a unique building. There is a cafe for those who like coffee and cakes or a light snack, a Bohemian eatery for good local cuisine and a very swanky French restaurant with full waiter service in a sumptuous room. Also in the centre of the building is the Smetana Hall where there are symphony concerts and balls. There are also numerous rooms (all of which can be hired) where a variety of exhibitions are held. Throughout, the golden fittings, stained glass, tiled panels and murals take away your breath. I have visited Prague 9 times in the last 17 years and this place is always the first place I go to, and usually where I have my final meal. Don't just make use of the eating facilties, though; book on to a guided tour to see the rooms not open to the public to fully appreciate the splendours of this amazing architectural wonder.

The concert hall has really good acoustics. You can go just to see the building. It's a wonderful example of Art Nouveau. And there's a great beer hall in the basement which had good food and included traditional, live, beer hall music. I had read several reviews which said the waitstaff could be disinterested or rude, but that was certainly not the case when we ate there last week. It was all very professionalThe concert hall is beautiful and it has really good acoustics. We heard a very good performance by the Moravian Symphony Orchestra. They were obviously very well rehearsed (extraordinary precisions in the string sections). I especially enjoyed their performance of Dvorak's New World Symphony, and the Mozart Oboe concerto in C major. The oboist was very good and the conductor, Jesus Medina had one of the best interpretations of Mozart I've ever heard. (I spent several years in a music conservatory in my younger days.Also, we paid for the better seats and we got them - -center seats in the fourth row. Couldn't have asked for better.

Art Nouveau Paradise. This theater with its two restaurants will blow your mind if you know anything about the Art Nouveau period of art and architecture. The decorated facades and interiors are masterful works of art. Its a must by all means.
one of most beautiful buidings in Prague. Absolutely beautiful- would have loved to try the tea and cake but never there when hungry!!! Don't miss it.

For a concert, or for a good meal. The Municipal House was high class upgraded and renovated some 10 (or more) years ago, spending billions...Housing today a multi-number of halls and possible meeting rooms, and the fantastic "Smetana Hall".Besides that; a historical nice cafe, - an upgraded French Restaurant, and on the basement a very good "value for money" beer hall. for a light lunch try their war fried Hermelin cheese with Frenc fries and a good glass of their house wine (preferable white), and a small ice cold galls of their national drink; the Becherovka

Awesome concert hall. The exterior beauty invites us to feel and feel the interior. We got concert ticket for The Four Season. They are talented high scale violinists..with a beautiful hall and very good musician it's just not to be missed. As tourist we were exempted of formal dressing but we were polite and with our best casual it was an experience for more. We went to the hall 30 min earlier to wonder of the oldest bar of prague located on the lowest floor..it's ok.as time for concert neared we registered and was impressed by the sculptors and decoration of the Hall. The lighting, ceiling and interior deco of old nominate it's right as Unesco World Heritage. Don't just wonder outside have an experience of the concert

Unbelievable building. Prague has some of the most beautiful architecture ever seen. This building is the icing on the cake. It is beautifully preserved & every little detail is seen to with great care. Just a stunning architectural gem.

One of the highlights from our stay in Prague. My boyfriend and I went here to see 'The Four Seasons' from Vivaldi concert and it was truly amazing from beginning till the end. Though the entrance was quite expensive for us as students, it was worth every penny of it. The building is Art Nouveau pur sang. Marble, gold, glass in lead, fresco's and ornaments were all over the place that bathed in a warm, dimmed light. We were walking around and enjoying the music with a big smile on our faces that lasted till we fell asleep in our hotel hours later. We believe this was the best spent money while in Prague. Very romantic as well. Tip: Share a desert afterwards in the coffeehouse, which is build in the same style.

A real concert hall. Impressive looking venue for concerts. Soak in the great atmosphere and relax to inspiring music played by talented musicians. In the summer the concerts seem to be designed especially for tourists, but is seems to be worth it for the experience you get and the quality of the sound you will listen to.
Sigh at the beautifulness. I first saw this building in 2000 and was excited to go back and explore the interior. The municipal house is a magnificent architectural feat and well preserved!

Artdeco Evening in Prague. Really once you re finished with all the sighseeing in Prague, then that is the time to relax and yet be part of the great city. Have a coffe or a drink on Old time square and than a little pleasant walk will take you to the munincipal house, buy tickets enjoy the concert and finish your evening and dine in ArtDeco Imperial
Disappointed. Have seen more grand Opera Theaters. Not too grand. A bit severe (austere?). The concert was also very good but not outstanding - competent without having a soul

Just amazing. I love Art Nouveau and was blown away by this building. I didn't do the tour, but ate in the amazing restaurant, had coffee in the cafe and went to a concert in the main hall, to fully enjoy the splendor. Very well worth seeing if you like fin de siecle architecture.
Don't miss a visit to the tower!. It was really worth it to go up in the tower and get a magnificant view over Prague!! Try to be there "on the hour" and see what happens...

Prague's most beautiful Art Nouveau building. I was born and grew up in Prague and returned for visits several times over the years, yet the very first time I toured this beautiful building was at age 62! I was surprised to learn that there is no demand for tours in Czech, only foreign tourists seem to be interested in touring this building. However, the relatively high admission fee is probably the reason why Czechs do not visit. Tour fee is 290Kc/adult. There are few buildings in Prague that rival the Municipal House's history and influence. It was built on the site of what once was the Royal Court in Prague (seat of Bohemia's kings from 1383 to 1483). Completed in 1912, it was from its balcony that Czechoslovak independence was proclaimed on October 28, 1918. Its interior is lavishly decorated. The 90min (or so) tour was definitely worthwhile and I enjoyed it greatly. If you wish to take photos, you have to purchase a photo pass which costs an additional 55Kc. There are several fancy restaurants and the oldest American Bar in Central Europe. When you purchase an admission ticket for 290Kc, you get a coin worth 90Kc at the American Bar.

Good, but not the best available. We had a very good dinner meal here. Casual atmosphere, good service. Goulash ok, Prague Ham plate great. Excellent price. Building is beautiful, and it was close to the Hilton for our first night.
Interesting tour. The one hour tour, including the Smetana Hall and all the function rooms attached to it are beautiful and well-explained on the guided tour.

Concert at Obecni Dum. I was fortunate to get a ticket for a concert at the Obecni Dum (Municipal House Hall) with a friend one evening. The symphony orchestra was excellent and played a great concert of classical music. While you're there, be sure to visit the hallways and coffee shop decorated in the Art Nuveau style. Well worth a visit for the decor, pastries and the music.

Art Nouveau Heaven. If you are at all interested in Art Nouveau you must do the tour. This building is a source of great national pride as it contains examples of Art Nouveau craftmanship by artists and craftsmen from al over the world who were the best in their field. There is a room created by Munch. Even the elevator is like stepping back in time.

Review of the Cafe..... Everyone should take the time to order a dessert and coffee at this wonderful cafe. I also had a greek salad which was excellent. This is a beautiful place and is considered one of the finest art nouveau interiors anywhere.

Don't miss it. For Art Nouveau fans this is beyond amazing. Look around, eat in one of the restaurants, attend a concert. This is an alive place, not a museum. Skip a few cathedrals and spend a few hours here.

Classical Concert in Art Deco Municipal House. First of all we admired this building from the outside by day and by night. We took a tour of the many interior rooms and were impressed by the art decor work of Alphonse Mucha. We purchased tickets for an evening classical concert that took place in the lower level performance hall. The musicians played for one hour starting at 8:30 PM. The nine Czech musicians were from premier orchestras and were magnificent. If you buy tickets the day before the performance you can save about 200 K per 1000 K ticket. The outdoor cafe attached to this building is great for dinner or dessert and coffee.
beautiful halls to take in a short concert. lovely place to take in a short concert, hear some beautiful music played in stunning surrounds and a bit of tranquility in an otherwise busy day
Gorgeous interior. Wow, what a sumptuous interior. Simply beautiful. We took in a concert there and thoroughly enjoyed it. The place is simply drop dead gorgeous.
Beautiful decorations inside. We were very impressed with the wonderful decorations of the different rooms of this building and enjoyed one hour guided tour in English with a very nice guide

art Nouveau...love it. Great house, beautiful art nouveau place, ruff, glass, the floor everything makes a art nouveau lovers smile...cheap restaurant in the basement, also great art nouveau there. theres a popular cafe on the1st floor
A must visit for coffee and cake !. Best in town ! be sure to order the expresso and chocolate cake...it's better than in Vienna at Cafe Demel !
Amazing Tower Bell view.. Go there at full hours: you'll see the trumpeter play to the crowds in the square. priceless. Also good for kids and oldies: there's a good elevator.

WOW!!. A beautiful Art Nuveau building! Check out what concert is playing during your visit and you won't be disappointed. The accoustics are good and the concert we attended was absolutely fantastic!

Beautiful!. This was a delightful treat. We not only enjoyed sitting outdoors at the cafe, we dined inside at the Plzenska Restaurace, enjoyed visiting the other restaurants and went to a classical music performance in the Smetana Concert Hall. It is must visit for everyone.

Very beautiful building. This building is amazing! All rooms are decorated in different styles and is really interesting to imagine thier life in that time. nearby is also Prašna brana (Powder Tower) which is amazing, too.

Wow. Well worth a visit. Take an organized tour and you won't be disappointed. Modern history. Stunning artworks and a beautiful art nouveau building. Wish we'd had time to indulge at the restaurant or bar.

Breathtaking interior. If you appreciate art nouveau at all, this is unmissable. So many details to take in. Wish we'd tried a concert or one of the restaurants, but we were travelling with a group and sadly only had 20 minutes there.

A treat for the eyes, the ears, the stomach and so much more..... On one day we visited the Obecni Dum for coffee and cakes in the wonderfully decorated cafe, visited the American Bar in the basement, wondered at the fabulous Art Nouveau decoration, and came back for the traditional Czech food and music in the restaurant in the cellar. The whole building is one continuous hymn to beautiful design, magnificent craftsmanship, lavish care and national pride.The coffee in the cafe is good, the cakes typically Czech (beautiful to look at but only mildly satisfying), but the decor and atmosphere are fabulous.The walk down stairs is a treat to the eyes, where even the lift shaft is a stunning work of art and the tiled walls are a symphony in themselves. And, then, there's the American Bar - a masterpiece.But our purpose was not to admire the bar alone, but to eat in the basement restaurant with its rustic tables and chairs, fabulous decoration and vibrant atmosphere. The food reflected the old image of Czech cuisine, with lots of meat, gravy, bread and dumplings, picked fish and pickled cabbage washed down with fine Pils - what a treat! And, to add to the atmosphere, singing led (on the night we were there) by accordionist Josef Jehlik and double-bass player Alena Penzenstadlerova - they were a real treat. Doesn't sound like your idea of a good night? Give it a try, especially if you can take a party of friends with you and occupy one of the booths or tables for eight!

Exceptional place and service. A bit expensive. Marvellous room with art nouveau decoration. Nice service, with very good relationship. But main course around 600 kc id 25 e .Bill for two around 2000 id 80 with water and 2 glass of wine. So nice place but once time.... We like vision and cooking. We didnt like the bill. But perhaps normal in such place. Anyway no needs to book before, there is place free....

Oozing Art Nouveu. This is a beautiful building and example of Art Nouveau architecture from the early 20th century. We didn't attend a concert here, but did go in and wander around the building a bit. Would recommend that you visit the Mucha Museum and then enjoy wandering around New Town to appreciate the Art Nouveau architecture.
Proms Prague. We enjoyed a concert here, the Hollywood night of Prague Proms. Beautiful music and a spectacular venue.

Art Nouveau Gem. Book a tour around this wonderful hall and experience some fantastic art nouveau design including a room designed by Mucha. The price includes a 'free' drink in the American Bar afterwards.
Municipal House. Beautiful architecture, a few steps away from the Powder Tower. Didnt go inside but you can go to concerts etc there.
Wonderful building. I would recommend taking one of the tours of the building, it is simply beautiful inside. Try the cafe for lunch.

Amazing Building. Our tour of this building was presented by a lovely local lady who was so enthusiastic about this building that we learnt so much duringnour visit there. I was taken back by the concern of detail and the fact that each room was individually designed with its intended group audience taken into account. The art deco deco designs are fabulous and the crystal chandeliers in each room are stunning. As this building was always intended to be a meeting complex it is fascinating that after almost a hundre years it works as well today as the day it was first opened. We also enjoyed the free beer in the American bar at the end of the tour!

Beautiful Building - Great Music. We went there yesterday for the Proms Prague and it was great. The building is stunning (inside and outside), and the music was just beautiful. I had been there many years ago, but I didn't see the orchestra, I am so glad I did it this time. It was great!
a palace. this place is like going back in time to a more genteel era,all art deco and luxurious settings.very good for prices as well.

Beautiful building - must see!. From the outside this building is SO unique and beautiful. Did not take a tour and sort of wish we did the interior (art deco) is so interesting and beautiful. Restaurants here look so very lovely!!!

you need to see this. This is a very interesting place. We had lunch in the basement restaurant. They have outdoor dinning, a cafe, a formal dinning and not so formal in the basement. But the decor in all is something to see. We ordered soup, the waiter warned us we were ordering to lightly so then had a cheese fruit plate to go along. It was a very light lunch but the atomosphere was what it was all about. It is so European.
OMG. I love Art Nouveau. I love to find glimpses of it in Brussels, Barcelona, Paris, Helsinki...but the Obecni Dum is drop-dead, over-the-top, I'm-gonna-faint Art Nouveau at its zenith. Who knew?

A must-see in Prague!. Beautifully-restored. Inspiring interiors that you can enjoy if you take the tour. Hosts concerts too. Delightful restaurant in the basement that serves a succulent duck confit (called Roast Duck served with red cabbage and potato dumplings) and ice-cold Pilsner Urquell.

Great place to have a coffee and dessert. This building has many features from restaurants to concerts.The gourmet restaurant was extremely expensive and served very average food.Stick to the other features of this building. Walk across the street and take in the beauty of this building.

Classical Concert. My husband and I listened to a classical concert (string instruments) downstairs in a small intimate side room during the music festival and it was just wonderful. Would thoroughly recommend the experience and not vastly expensive. The only sad thing was that when we visited the upper rooms were closed to the public for another event and, as the building is supposed to be stunningly decorated, it would have been interesting to look around.

Art Nouveau splendour!. I always include the Municipal House on my Orientation Tours as it is a totally authentic 1900's Art Nouveau wonder. Enjoy a drink in the cafe with outdoor terrace or go for an evening traditional Czech meal in the wonderful basement brewery. The restaurant upstairs is wonderfully decorated but over rated and expensive. Also enjoy a concert in the Smetana Hall or a daily guided tour that usually includes the marvelous Mucha room upstairs. I also recommend staying in the nearby 5 star PARIS Hotel which was built a few years before the Municipal House and is another Art Nouveau treasure. If you cannot afford to stay (I can get good local rates) enjoy a drink in the cafe and soak up the authentic atmosphere. Owned by the same Czech family for 100+ years!
AMAZING!. Take the tour. Maybe the most incredible example of Art Nouveau in the world, and all in PERFECT condition! This was the most amazing thing we saw in Prague!

Outside impression. We didn't manage to get inside on our May 12 visit as there were lots of police and black cars milling around, lots of local dignitaries, must have been some big event taking place. However the building's architecture at the front was beautiful. The Municipal House lies a bit in the opposite direction from old Prague's other sights, but the Powder gate is nearby, so it's worth going to see both.

Make this your number one visit. The amazing Art Nouveau/Deco architecture of a great Prague building (they declared independence from the balcony after World War One) has to be seen to be believed. Go to a concert here! Look at the basement and the lift! Just sit in the cafe (the restaurant is too pricey) and have anything from a beer or coffee and cake through to a light meal. Watch the world go by.

Best art deco interior in Prague. Well worth the fee to take the inside tour. The concert hall is beautiful, but the side rooms and lounges are even more spectacular. The details are amazing, down to the door handles. The Mucha decorated room is worth the admission alone.

An Art Noveau Paradise. For art noveau lovers this place is not to be missed. You can wander for free in some areas of the building where you will see fabulous ceramics, brass and glass art noveau decoration. The bar and restaurant in the basement look unreal. Like you are on a movie set. The cafe has delicious treats and is a great place to people watch. I didn't eat at the fancier restaurant but it looks like a lovely place for a special dinner. I didn't get a chance to see a show there so I can only comment on the incredible architecture.

Beautiful, but careful about the acoustic in Smetana Hall. This arts nouveau palace is worth the price of admission just for the art work, including pieces by the master - Alphons Mucha. If you go for a concert in Smetana Hall be careful not to sit underneath the balcony, where the sound at the end of the hall sounds distant and muffled with strange echoes. Nearer the front the acoustic is fine.
Do not miss. A brilliant, beautiful building, with exceptional interiors. A must. A highlight for me.

Your best choice for performing arts in Prague. Yes, you could go to a tourist concert at the Spanish Synagogue or one of the stunning cathedrals in Prague...these are wonderful choices. However, consider seeing those sites during the day and attend an evening concert at the Municipal House. Arrive early, buy your tickets at the "door", visit the gift shop and have a drink or dinner in one of the beautiful dining areas. You will feel like you have been transported back to the early 1900's. This Art Nouveau building has been exceptionally maintained and will make you want to learn more about this amazing era in Prague.

Art Nouveau masterpiece. The Obecni Dum was built between 1906 and 1912 to showcase Czech architecture, arts and crafts at the time of the National Revival. The result is this beautiful and colourful municipal hall full of wonderful detail. As a Glaswegian I love Charles-Rennie Mackintosh, and this really helps my art nouveau cravings.The main cafe is spectacular and a great place to spend time with a coffee. Also, if you walk in the main entrance feel free to go downstairs to the small but perfectly formed American Bar. Great spot for a cocktail. To see the full glory of Obecni Dum, there is a guided tour of the main apartments. Did this a few years ago and it was very worthwhile, as there are some beautiful works by Alfons Mucha.

Beautiful building, interesting gift shop. This is a striking building with a most interesting gift shop. I last visited some 11 years ago and wasn't sure what I'd find now, but it was just as I remembered it!

More Mucha!. This is a lovely building that should not be missed! Go downstairs to the restaurant to take some unique pics of art deco and art nouveau decor and... eat the duck. It's amazing. The little shop outside the elevator on the right has some really affordable antique jewelry pieces and home decor for sale.

Go to a concert. You can get a ticket from the box office on the night of the show. We were able to watch an excellent classical concert. We got the tickets an hour before the show and had a cocktail by the cafe next to the lobby. They had a live jazz trio that was quite entertaining.

Maginificent Art Nouveau building - must be one of the world's finest. An absolutely stunning example of Art Nouveau, with tremendous workmanship on the outside of the building, in the restaurant, in the tea rooms, in the theatre itself, on the stairs... We had tea twice in the tea rooms: I have to say that the service wasn't great but the tea was unusually good and was reasonably priced.

This is a big winner. If you are an art nouveau fan, you could not do better. It compares very favorably with Macintosh's work in Glascow. I missed the opportunity to take the tour, so my view was limited to the basement area. But what I saw there was outstanding.

Cultural and social center of Prague. It contains a Smetena concert hall and exhibition hall and restaurant and cafe. This complex serve various functions. It is situated on Repulic Square and Old Town is just a few minutes walk away. It stands next to the Powder Gate.
Don't miss Municipal House!. A lovely concert venue with great music, art nouveau designs, and great restaurants. Be sure to take a guided tour and enjoy a concert in Smetana Hall.

Take the building tour & avoid the "tourist" concerts. As other reviewers have said "the building itself is absolutely stunning and definitely merits a visit". We paid 1100 CZ Crowns for a "Gala Performance of the Best of Bizet's Carmen and Ravel's Bolero" in the impressive Smetana Hall. We should have paid more attention to that "Best of" wording. The concert included "ballet" and 3 soloist singers (who were, to be fair, very good). The small orchestra was (as another reviewer has said) "obviously very skilled, but they played like automatons, without expression.". also you were left with the impression that they simply couldn't wait to get through this aria and onto the next as they had somewhere else to get to (probably true).On one occasion they started the next "best bit" whilst the audience was still applauding the efforts of the soloists so keen were they to get on - no wonder they brought it in "to land" exactly on 70 minutes as programmed! But the best bit was the "ballet" part - the three men were simply dreadful (fabulously out of time with each other and in one case rather overweight) - the children from a ballet school were quite sweet - but we had such fun (as did others in our row) at what was unintentionally so funny. inally, the Bolero, thankfully, was the full work and the dance which accompanied it was very accomplished - a very expressive leading ballerina. So go for a giggle and aview of the main hall but buy the cheapest seats!
Beautiful Art Nouveau building. We attended a concert there and looked in on the two restaurants, one traditional Czech and one French.
Beautiful architecture. Stunning building - we went into the lobby but were unfortunately not able to make it into the inside for a concert.
Magnificent building. Visited the coffee lounge twice during our stay in Prague. Real sense of 1920's with lots of wood, chandeliers and good range of drinks, meals and cakes in a beutiful setting.

See a concert here to fully appreciate it. The building exterior is lovely, and a must-see for Art Nouveau enthusiasts. It's right off the Namesti Republiky square so it's easy to get to. Try to see a concert here to appreciate its inner beauty. Smetana Hall has beautiful stained glass panels and the ceiling glass is amazing.

Wow! What an Art Nouveau treat!. We spent a long time admiring the decoration, tiles, mosaics, gilt work in the public spaces. We didn't get to see the concert hall which was a shame but if there'd been a concert on that evening that we were interested in hearing, we would have gone.We ate in the large cafe which is beautiful. The food is good and the staff were very friendly. It's a lovely setting. It's not non-smoking but fortunately there was only one smoker and he was quite a way off.

Always excellent. Very good affordable menu, any time of day. All prices shown, no surprises. Great service. Many of the waiters and waitresses have been there for years and maintain a consistent level of excellent service. Beautiful dining room .... with jazz on many nights. Nice outdoor seating.

May 2012. Went to a concert which was reasonablty priced and excellent. The building iteself is magnificent and the concert hall is very well maintained. The most spectacular part of the complex is the restaurant whichc is abosolutely beautiful. It is expensive but not overpriced for the quulity of food and the stunning decor in the dining room.

Just another "tourist" concert. The building itself is absolutely stunning and definitely merits a visit. Wish we had paid for the tour rather than the very mediocre concert we attended the evening of May 12. The event was held in one of the downstairs spaces rather than Smetana hall, which was a disappointment, though the acoustics were good. The music itself was typical pop favorites, with a few nice surprises, which normally would have been fine. The seven players were obviously very skilled, but they played like automatons, without expression. Not one word was said to the audience, and there was no program, not even a xeroxed sheet, with which to follow along. A few of the pieces were needlessly abbreviated, and the tempos taken so fast that it was obvious they just wanted to get done as quickly as possible, We ended up paying 800 Kc for 60 minutes worth of music (and it was almost exactly 60 minutes--they were spot on about that), so we were glad that we'd chosen the cheaper seats. This has so far been the only disappointment of our trip to Prague.
Amazing. Would recommend a look at the outside of the building, it is beautiful. The interior is a must for people who like architecture

Beautiful building with an equally stunning cafe. Although we didn't fully explore the building we did stop at the cafe for cake. An absolutely stunning art nouveau room with beautiful chandeliers. Service was efficient but not over friendly, as is much the case in Prague. We had to pay for our cakes from the cake trolley immediately. The black forest gateau was lovely. A great place to take a break and take in the design of a stunning building.

Don't miss Municipal House. Municipal House sounds as if it should be some sort of town hall or storage rooms for official paperwork, but in fact it is a very grand museum for the beautiful city of Prague. It is full of glorious items from the city's past - everything from pottery to jewels and furniture. The building itself is gorgeous. There are guided tours and we were definitely kept together by a slightly aggressive guide. Tours are in Czech and English; if another language is spoken, written accounts are handed out. Our tour group inclouded Japanese, German, French and others, so they had to keep up as best they could.
Reception. I attended our conference's reception at the Municipal House. It was lovely. I enjoyed walking through this building and seeing all the history.

Concert by Prague Symphony orchestra. Super acoustics...the guide book was a bit misleading here. Wonderful concert..Brahms, Dvorzak, Smetana. Loved the tympanist .... he so enjoyed the usic he added enormously to my personal enjoyment.

Gorgeous building. A great place to stop for a beer or wine when feet are complaining. Nice terrace w heaters. We ordered a cheese plate - she said the cheeses were only Czech and we said fine. They were very good.
Great for a concert. We paid for cheap seats in this concert hall and ended up in a circle box! Great music and location.

Another must visit in Prague. Class, class, class, though the nearby shopping mall the Palladium somwhat pulls the area down with it's tacky burger bars and chain stores. This gem still has it all in spades. If you only visit one of the famous old cafe's of Prague, then this has to be the one.

Beautiful place for a musical experience.. Loved the venue and the concert. The hall is spectacular and the only way to see it is to attend an event in the space. We saw a wonderful concert that lasted a little over an hour.

Walk through.... ...if nothing else. Beautiful Art Nouveau. Beer hall and American Bar downstairs. concert Hall with concerts almost every night we didn't get to. You can only do so much, and we saw one of the best concerts of our lives at the Rudolfinum. Decent cafe at the Municipal Hall to sit outside and people watch.
The delights of Municipal House.. This has not only attractive restaurants but is a place with a number of halls presenting top class music.

String Quintet. Went to a concert by string quintet in the Municipal House Hall. Had a lovely evening and the music was a selection of mainly well known pieces by Czech and other famous composers. The Municipal House cafe is a fabulous large art deco hall serving coffee and the most fabulous range of cakes which are brought to the table on a trolley by a special cake waiter. A must stop off only a stones throw from the old town centre.
don't miss. Glorious art deco building - super acoustics (check out the string group that plays there) and three good restaurants in the building

Beautiful venue. We came here for afternoon tea whilst on an Easter weekend break to Prague. It doesn't do traditional afternoon tea in the English sense but it does do some amazing coffees... the cakes were average, but the atmosphere and music made up for the not so great cakes. The service was abrupt and a little on the rude side, but perhaps this was just due to language differences. I would recommend this place just to sit and people watch and for the lovely ambience.

Beautiful!. We went to hear a string orchestra play some Vivaldi, Mozart and Pachelbel. The music was wonderful, just as the building! It's is an amazing piece of architecture, both inside and from across the street.

Stunning Art Nouveau edifice.. Home to concert halls, restaurants and bars, this is arguably the most stunning art nouveau building in Prague. Outside, enjoy the gold trimmings, intricate stonework, frescos and stained glass windows. Inside, thrill to the astonishingly ornate details to tiling, lift doors, chandeliers, mirrors. Modest it is not even though the "Municipal House Hall" label could not be more prosaic if it tried. Opened in 1912, it features the decorative talents of famous Czech artists including Max Švabinský, František Ženíšek, Ladislav Šaloun, Josef Mařatka, Josef Václav Myslbek and Alfons Mucha. The photo captures just a hint of the glamour.

Fun restaurants, terrific concert hall - what else could you want?!?. In English, Municipal House sounds so bland but this building is anything but. If you are an Art Deco or Art Nouveau aficionado you are going to LOVE this place. The French restaurant is in the style of the latter, the Viennese coffee house is Jungenstil, the Czech beer hall downstairs is from the same period and a huge amount of fun. Do not miss the roaring 20's American Bar in the basement - a great place to pretend you are in a by-gone era. After eating/drinking, take in a concert in Smetana Concert Hall - over the top in decor and terrific acoustics. You should not leave Prague without having indulged!

For me this was the best in Prague.. For me this was the best in Prague. If you like the art of the beginning of the 20th century, go there. Nice lamps Jugendstil, beautiful concerthal, amazing painting (fo example Mucha). It was built as an national symbol of the Chech. So many different artist have worked on this building. You have to pay and you go with a guide. Ouders told us so many interesting things. Pay some exta to have the right to take pictures.

Art Neuveau-Deco. Wonderful design, like a movie set from the 1930s. Everything from the chandeliers to the door handles is a masterpiece of design and function. Allow a couple of hours to see this, and enjoy the wonderful cafe within.

Beautiful building, horrible acoustics. The building is a wonderful depiction of Art Nouveau. But seeing a concert in the Smetana Hall was sub-par. The acoustics were horrible which didn't help the struggling symphony.

Art Nouveau splendour!. The prices here may be high end in the kavarna, but coffee and cake at this iconic Prague venue is an absolute must. Sit and soak in all the architectural beauty as you choose your dessert from the trolley and listen as the pianist entertains. Try to do one of the guided tours of the building too. Ask at the information desk and marvel as you are taken into each private salon.An unforgettable experience! Wander downstairs to the American Bar too.
enjoyable. went to a concert good program accoustics weren't something

WONDERFUL CONCERT. Wonderful concert, beautiful building, lovely helpful staff. We went to see The Best of The Classics on 29th March, what a treat! The building from the outside is magnificent lit up at night, we went in the bar on the left, and it was so nostalgic, art nouveau at its very best. The detail in the decor, the wood, the mirrors, the window surrounds, you could imagine in days gone by how the people must have been dressed in all this magnificent splendour, we had pre concert drinks and felt very special, then downstairs to the hall on our left which was strangely enough "pinkish", my husband chose row 11 because if was 800kr whereas row 10 was 1,000, and there about 4ft difference! View was great but seats were hard. Was a little concerned that there was no orchestra set up, only music stands, but what a treat. 7 of the finest chamber orchestra that we have ever heard, the sound was amazing, the enthusiasm of the performers was fantastic; real hair stand up on the back of your neck job, and it lasted exactly an hour, which was great. A wonderful evening, a wonderful venue. Treat yourself you will not be disappointed.

What an astonishing building!. An art deco building with beautiful auditoriums for concerts. Lavishly decorated and with helpful staff. Stairs to all the floors, no lifts. Went to a concert here and had a lovely evening.

Excellent Break.. It is absolutely magnificent inside. Obviously it depends on the performance as to whether you enjoyed your visit. We listened to Verdi mainly so it was quite enjoyable. Worth it to see inside. they also have a great coffee/restaurant where you are accompanied by a trio (piano. sax and base)

More than meets the eye.. Just looking at this building is a pleasure. It is a very fine example of "Art Nouveau". There are two restaurants in it; an every day kind which is beautifully decorated and serves very good wholesome food and a much posher - and more expensive one - opposite it. It has a theater inside and they also hold exhibitions in it.

Pricy but worth it.. Go to the Smetana Hall for a concert just for the atmosphere. Eat in the dininag hall if you have plenty of cash in your pocket - a cheaper option is to go for one of their breakfasts - simple, but worth it for the setting!
Art Nouveau Elegance. Excellent building, make sure you ask for no smoking area if taking tea. Check cakes are fully defrosted.

Overall Pretty Interesting. We went to Municipal House mostly to see Mucha's paintings and did not realize we would have to pay for a tour. Go ahead of time and get your tickets because tours are available at specific times. It's not cheap! The building was very grand and the tour was interesting. You will spend most of the tour enjoying well decorated luxurious rooms. Mucha's paintings are the real star for me here still--they are incredible! The building is rented out as a venue for parties/performances/whatever, and several events were being organized during our visit, which caused some rooms to be difficult or impossible to view--that bummed us out a little. I've also read reviews that mention tourist ripoff performances here, but what you have to remember is that it is a rentable venue, so the building is not to blame for the entertainment you see there.

The parlors are stunning !!. This hall consists of a concern hall, several eateries, and several parlors. You can only visit the parlors and the concert hall with a guided tour. The parlors are simply stunning!! Each room is decorated in beautiful details: the walls, the ceilings, the heating covers, the mirrors, the crystal chandeliers, and curtains. Unfortunately, our tour guide talked to us like school children in the 4th grade for part of the tour -- and luckily she switched to speaking normal about half way through the tour. Also, although we were promised an "English" tour, the tour guide ended up sharing our time with some Czech folks. They also give you a handout to read -- and the tour guide repeats that information. Don't miss it. We ended up being excited by the room decorated by Mucha, and ended up visiting the Mucha museum after.
Municipal House Hall. We took a look inside this beautiful building and enjoyed looking around. The exterior is also a treat and we saw it many times.
beautifully lit at night. the restaurant, and concert hall are lovely, and the outside decorations are beautiful, especially at night with the lights.

Wonderful art-nouveau building.... ... take the tour if you can. (Even if you can't, make sure you at least go downstairs to see the Pilsner restaurant and the American bar, then end up with coffee and cake in the "kavarna" on the ground floor.)

fabulous building. We visted and enjoyed the beautiful building and enchanting music, it is a must see if you visit Prague. It is even more stunning at night. If you do pay for a concert the tickets vary quite a bit and we found that the hall was far from full and people simply moved to the more expensive seats before the music began, which would be annoying if you paid top dollar for your seats. the reastaurants and bars are also very good and reasonably priced for such a place. You would be hard pushed to find the levels of cleanliness and attention to detail in London for example.
nice architecture with french restaurant. novorenesance building where czechoslovak republic independence was declared

art nouveau gem!. Located in Namesti Republiky, the Municipal House is a fine example of Mucha's art nouveau style. Inside are several concert halls where tourists and locals can enjoy short 1 hour concerts at a very reasonable price. back when I was a tourist, I took advantage of this occasional infusion of classical culture into my system. It's a shame that I hardly do this anymore. There is an excellent but rather overpriced french restaurant on one side and a much reasonably priced "cafe" on the other side.
Go for a concert. Absolutely breath taking place! Even those bot real fan of classical musical would enjoy , if not the music, definetly the interior os this place.
Do go on the tour. What an excellent tour! Fantastic building, lots to look at, for Art Nouveau fans. Great tour guide, lovely to end up in the American Bar for a "free" drink! I had a g & t!!

1920s feel - special dinner venue. Great to have a special coffee and cake moment. Beautiful interior with huge chandeliers, high ceilings and fountain. Opposite side of the hall is a very fine restaurant with very fine prices! Easy to get to from Wenceslas Square (head for Old Town Square/Clock and turn right. Municipal house, Theatre, Bank and Powder Tower all in same area)
Art Nouveau Lovers Rejoice!. Simply amazing! The condition of the Municipal House is fantastic. Each chamber or room is different. The French Restaurant inside has some of the best food in Prague!

Beautiful decor. Fabulous chandeliers and very glam interior. Menu was fine for a lunch time snack but nothing very inspiring. Architecture was beautiful - worth seeing - on next visit I intend to go to a concert here

Nice looks from the outside. If you are into architecture this is a building that may not be missed. The outside is well painted and well kept. It is located next to the powder tower, on of the gates to the old town. It can be very crowded around there.
Go if you have time. I went to a classical music concert and was really nice. It's not much impressive in the inside, but worth visiting
Do see if you possibly can. Go on organised tour of this wonderful art nouveau building and take in a show if possible
Well worth a visit!. We attended a concert by the Czech Symphony Orchestra in the Smetana Hall here which was superb. The building is a beautiful setting for concerts and the Cafe is also excellent.
Lovely venue for a concert. The hall was a lovely venue for a concert and the concert itself was very good. The cafe with piano in the afternoons is a good place to while away some time.

Masterpiece. Municipal House is a masterpiece both from the outside and inside. With Prague's Gunpowder Tower attached to it, this couple is even more ostentatious, than Frank Ghery's "Ginger & Fred" building

Top of Prague. Anyone who likes Art Nouveau cannot avoid comming here. I recommend a guided tour of the building to have all the buildning and the abundant and beautiful decorations well explained. Just a visit to this place is worth travelling to Prague.. Hhave your lunch in Kavarna Obecni dum, than you will be happy to be in an outstanding "eating room" and highly enjoy both good food and lovely surroundings. After lunch my advise to you is, go down into the basement to The American bar for an oldfashioned drink. At home again you will for ever long to be back!
Beautiful exterior. Nice inside as well, and often have good exhibits. But definitely worth stopping by to look at the architecture and decoration.
The nicest historical building in Prague. Newly reconstructed with all the original details. Inside, there is a nice shop with souveniers.
Fabulous. Had lunch here which was an experience sat in those beautiful surroundings. Food was lovely and the service was good.
Art Nuveau at its best. This building is breathtaking. Must see while in Prague.

Good value Art Deco cafe. I had read an article in one of the newspapers about the Kavarna Obecni Dum and so we made a point of visiting it. In fact we were so impressed that we went there several times. There is an atmosphere there of the Art Deco period and old world grandeur, with magnificent chandeliers and paintings by Mucha plus white jacketed waiters and waitresses serving delicious (and very reasonably priced) food and drink. It felt like going back in time.There is also a concert hall within the Obecni Dum where we went to a concert (excellent!); a shop and one or two restaurants. I would definitely recommend a visit to the cafe for a cup of tea, coffee, beer, or mulled wine. We didn't try the cakes but they looked absolutely delicious! Next time, perhaps .....
great art nouveau building. Make sure you have lunch or dinner in one of the restaurants..

A majestic meal out. We bought tickets from a street seller (prob not a good idea in hindsight) but it all turned out marvellously. We had meal in the grand old rooms of the Municipal House and the 5 course meal was superb but too adventurous for picky friend. Loved the atmosphere. We were then taken by taxi to another location to watch a soprano and orchestra perform inside some sort of chapel. She was brilliant. Wish I could remember more.

Great interiors, amazing café. The best secular interiors in Prague. I suggest the guided tour which will explain to you the history of the place and allow you to see the beautiful interiors where concerts are done. Do not forget to stop for a cup of hot chocolate in the Café downstairs - if you come in the afternoon, they will play Jazz music, most probably.

Iconic example of Art Nouveau architecture. I loved it. Very impressive building beautifully restored. I had the opportunity to participate in a private guided tour and definitely recommend this. Also the concert hall (Smetana's hall) is amazing and a visit to a concert there is a memorable lifetime experience.

Beautiful building but disappointing orchestral experience. A beautiful setting for the obligatory Mozart and Dvorak Prague experience. However, the extensive markerting and advertising around the city does not state that it is a small ensemble performing the concert and six musicians in the vast space was disappointing. While the music was beautiful I couldn't help feeling that the musicians had had a better offer and were rushing through the programme. Indeed at the end of the programme, long after the musicians had left the stage, most patrons continued to sit silently in their places as if waiting for either the second half or an encore. Very good however to see a very mixed group in attendance and enjoy the usual confusion as to when one shoud applaud.There is a restaurant and bar in the building which are highly and typically decorated in the Art Nouveau period but we did not visit these as they appeared over-priced.
Only saw from outside but looks lovely. We got our bus to the hotel just across the road from here but never went inside - lovely building though and beautiful location

Mucha painting. In the Municipal House are the wall paintings of the art nouveau artist Alfons Mucha which is well-known in France. If you are interested in art nouveau style or this artist don´t miss it! In it is café so you can enjoy it´s unique atmosphere.

Love the building design.. The outside facade of the building is simply amazing. Once you step inside the eyes are full of the marvels of the decor. I did not take a tour but want to the next time I am in Prague. We were going down to the Plzenska Restaurant and all the way down the stairs I just took picture after picture. I absolutely loved the tilework and design. Next time it's concert and sweets in the kavarna.
very nice architecture. nice to walk by, the rooms inside are georgeous. buy a ticket for a concert and enjoy

Not for the ground floor!. To be overwhelmed with package tourists having there included stop over in the cafe is not my idea of fun, and the place is over priced and only so so.However get the tour of the whole building and be amazed.Or go down the stairs to the still little known ( apart from the german tourists) Pilsen restaurant, where the staff can be very nice and the food is acceptable to good. This has to be the best central European art nouveau environment to dine in, really should be called Secession.

High Style in Prague. Although we did not attend a concert, the Municipal House offers fine dining experiences.Formal dining in an elegant Art Deco setting at the Frankouzska. After concert cakes and drinks at the Kavarna (as well as breakfast, lunch and tea).

Arts & Crafts Heaven. For anyone wanting to feast on wonderful Arts & Crafts splenddour this is a must . Wander in and descend to the restaurant , if only for a beer , to enjoy the spectacle of the tiling on the stairs the light fittings and the decor in the massive restaurant itself Fabulous

Gorgeous room, enjoyable orchestra. We went to see the Prague Symphony Orchestra performing on 14/12/2011, although we got a programme it was in czech so we could not really understand what was happening but it did not affect the show at all, it was so enjoyable and the music was a triumph!We got one of the boxes on the lower level and were lucky enough to not have to share, a wonderful view and privacy. Fantastic.
Obecni Dum in Prague. fantastic atmosphere and concert try the cafe and restaurant adjoining both are very good.
Beautiful facade. Looks very impressive from the outside, there is a trendy caffe on the 1st floor.

Vast art nouveau complex. I am by no means an architecture expert, but I thought the Obecni Dum was absolutely beautiful. In Namesti Republiky, it is a very unique and pretty building that is a wonderful contrast with the gothic and baroque architecture in Old Town. The decor is a true delight.There is a kavama where I had a superb hot chocolate & cake; the cleanliness is brilliant, the atmosphere is grand. Staff are efficient & polite but not over friendly, however I think the Czech people may be a little wary of the British - be polite & they do warm to you.

My vote for the most beautiful place for afternoon tea!. This is a truly stunning art nouveau building that also houses an opera house (which I have never visited). Whilst the service, food and drinks are perhaps a whit above average, the interior decor is every bit as impressive as its exterior and should certainly be enjoyed by any visitor to this most beautiful of European cities.
Boxing Day. Very good concert (Mozart & Strauss J) with ballet dancers and opera singers accompanying some pieces.

What a bore!. My tour guide recommended a tour of the Obecni Dum,which was okay at the start but really quite boring and nothing special and do not eat at the attached restaurant- food awful. So I recommend you skip both and go do something else like visiting the Jewish Cemetery or St Vitus Church
Great concerts!. We saw a jazz concert and a classic orchestra concert with vocalists singing Christmas carols in Czech and English. Both were excellent.

Great setting for a concert.. Went to see a classical concert here and was awed by the building as much as by the music. An incredibly good setting for listening to excellent music. Have a nose around and look at the various areas inside if you can.

Absoluely Stunning. A guided tour is a MUST when in Prague. You must check when tours operate as this is the Municipal House and rooms are booked by locals for social events. Tours take place as and when it is possible. Mucha designed some of the beautiful rooms
Art-Nuovo in it´s best. Nice architecture!Great concert hall inside - Smetana Hall.And very posh restaurants on the ground floor.

TRY the Francouska. Is excellent value with serious cuisine at lunch time when there are often special offers. Unusually for Prague spectacular sweets available.For lovers of high art nouveau this must be one of the world's most beautiful restaurants

Coffee and cake in the restaurant - hmmm!. Worth a look! Beautiful absolutely in tact and authentic art nouveau interior! Our jeans and jumpers seemed to make us a less than appreciated client - but we enjoyed it anyway!,

Great for concerts. We visited the Municipal house twice on our stay - once for a classical concert in the main hall and for a jazz concert in one of the smaller side halls. Both concerts were fantastic and reasonable value.Tip: if your going to see a performance, don't pay over the odds for seat near the front (1300CZK) - the seats at the back are cheaper (700CZK) and just as good.

Grand and luxurious. The building really has character and is very easily recognisable with it's painted dome and enormous windows. Our hotel was actually located directly across the street from Obecni Dum, so we passed it several times a day. The "Kavarna" inside (restaurant/café) was very large with well dressed guests and waitors in uniform.
Opera House. This hall is worth a visit even if you don't go to a concert for the wonderful art deco work.

Tour was average. We did a tour of the Municipal House Hall and got to see not only the main halls but small parlours as well but it was average. It wasn't cheap and there's a "complimentary drink" at The American Bar afterwards which was terrible. The cocktails weren't even cold and the bartender was rather rude too. Wouldn't recommended it.

Hugely impressive!. This building literally dominates all around it – with a huge frontage beautifully decorated, it is truly eye catching. Between the Powder Gate and Namesti Republiky, the location is perfect to combine a visit to Smetana Hall with other attractions. There are regular performances on at the hall, so consider a night out at Smetana Hall as well.
Concert Hall. This magnificant building is offering concert every night

Great Place for Lunch!. We stopped here and ate in the more casual restaurant for lunch on our 2nd day in Prague. The food was good typical Czech food with great restaurant surroundings - perfect for people watching.
Tour expensive. Didn't take the tour as twice price we were expecting and seemed unlikely to be worth it - nice tiles in the lobby and interesting exterior

A splendid house, built in Art Nouveau Style. The Municipal House is situated in the Republic Square, and it’s a landmark of Prague.Built at the beginning of the 20-th century, this house have a beautiful mosaic on the fronton, called Homage to Prague, some statuary on the roof, and a splendid wrought iron terrace.Inside, there is a large Smetana concert hall, and a café – Kavarna, also decorated in Art Nouveau style.The nearest metro station is Namesti Republiky.I warmly recommend a visit of this house.

A great place to visit, day and night!. We loved this building ... the interior of the cafe is stunning and very chic and elegant. A lovely place for afternoon tea. We went back the next evening for a cocktail at the Ameriky Bar. This is so unique and the bartender made us all fabulous cocktails... a great start to our evening!

Way overpriced for mediocre performance. Smetana Hall gorgeous.
