It's just a pity that the company running the concerts charges upward of 700 korunas for a ticket to a one hour concert played by uninterested musicians. There were about 40 people in the audience so less than 5% (guess) of the seats were occupied. It would be much more desirable if they chose to charge 1 quarter of the ticket price to bring in more people.If you want to go anyway, I suggest arriving 20 minutes before the concert and bargaining at the box office. Be prepared to just walk away.
free admission area is delightful. if one doesn't have the ca-ching to get inside the resto and the theatre, the free admission area, is still worthy of a long walk about..
Stunning. Go on the daily tour. Excellent tour guide, both knowledgeable and entertaining.Booked concert in the large hall. Incredible acoustics.

The Crown Jewel of Art Nouveau Architecture. Anyone interested in history or just plain beautiful buildings should make Prague's Obecni Dum (Municipal House) one of their must see's in Prague. This is by far the The Crown Jewel of Art Nouveau Architecture in all of Europe. If anyone can argue that, then they must at least admit that is at the very least one of the top 3 Art Nouveau buildings in Europe. Take the time to have a coffee in the Kavarna and then stroll through even the ground level and basement floors. If you have time and the budget, I can highly recommend you to take the tour which is worth the price.

Feast on Art Nouveau. Mucicipal house is the best example of Art Nouveau in Prague. One room was designed in its entirety by Alphonse Mucha including radiator covers, door hardware, drapes and upholstery fabrics. A walking tour in English is available twice a day. It has one of the nicest gift shops in Prague.
Art Deco Bar. Go downstairs to the small but perfect Art Deco bar, and immerse yourself in the ambience.

Dining on a Grand Scale. If you can take your eyes of the visual feast that is Obecni Dum, spot the attire of the waiting staff and have a look at the American Bar which claims to be the oldest in Prague. Great Coffee.
Gorgeous building. Take the time to stop in at the cafe, the interior is beautiful. Attended a concert inside too, this is one of the gems in Prague.

The place to be seen. Take the tour, you'll get to see a lot of superb rooms and of course the Mucha centrepiece, a focal point of Czech national aspirations. All very carefully restored, a triumph: sadly the Blue Guide is mean minded about it, and quite unjustifiably so.

Coffee Break. This is an amazing building and worth checking out we had coffee and cake in the afternnoon and also checked out the French restaurant also inside the building.If you come out of the building and turn right this street will bring you back to the old square on route check out the sweet /chocolate factory.

An experience I would not recommend. Paid about $50.00 for a Sunday evening concert in Smetana Hall that was promoted as two hours-- Actually, it was only one. I left after one hour thinking it was intermission and stepped out onto the sidewalk for some fresh air. When I tried to re-enter the building and climb the staircase back up to the Smetana Hall, I was rudely accosted by an elderly man who who said, "It is not permitted! You cannot go upstairs. The concert over." I won't even mention the failure of the box office to offer the senior citizens' discount that is referred to in the program. Altogether, it was a dreadful experience that tainted what was otherwise a good Prague experience. I think these "concerts" are product, not culture, structured to rip-off tourists. Never again!

Beautiful building, average concert. I think it goes without saying that the building is beautiful and Smetana Hall is very decorated. I decided to catch a concert here, and they are playing Pachelbel, Mozart and Vivaldi - which I thought is safe. And safe it is - I find the performance soulless. I think they are good musicians, but I expect them to put a bit more heart into the performance rather than going through it like it is part of their job. The soloist for Vivaldi's Four Seasons is the only exception. Also, the ticket is grossly overpriced for an 1-hour concert.
Drink & be merry!. Traditional fayre and ambiance within the basement beer hall ... truly recommended experience.
Beautiful. Amazing to walk inside & see the lovely decorations

Lovely Art Deco Building in historic area. Toward the end of our travels we decided to "mop up" some of the areas if Prague we had neglected. We were so glad we took the time to find this amazing building. Although we did not attend a performance here, we were very impressed with the architecture, the stained glass, and the lovely marble interior. It was definitely worth the visit.

Excellent concert.. I went to a lovely concert held at Municipale HOuse on Friday 4th November 2011.It was in a room below the main ground but was a nice room and excellent for the intimate concert.Highly recommend seeing some classical music in such a beautiful building.

A haven of rest!. The Municipal Hall has an outstanding restaurant on one half of the ground floor and a superb cafe in the other half. This has wonderful chandeliers and a musician plays piano all afternoon. The place to go when you are weary of walking around Prague for a coffe, hot chocolate, beer or glass of champagne. they also have a cake trollety to die for!Concerts are held on the oper floors including evenings of Gershwin and jazz.
Great Concert in the Smetan Hall. Beautiful stained glass. Wonderful concert in teh Smetana Hall.

Beautiful restored building, good restaurants. Go downstairs to the traditional Czech restaurant for duck and dumplings, or pork or another Czech dish. Fun place, with live music. Good location next to the Powder Tower.
Art Nouveau. Don't miss the Municipal House with large mosaic out front and wonderful changeliers in the coffee shop. Live Piana music at a light dinner before a concert was perfect.

You must visit this gem. A beautiful building next to the powder tower, an architectural gem outside and inside. Most people visit for a concert or to eat in one of the two restaurants, but they are missing a trick, the real gem here is the American bar downstairs. Pop down and order a classic cocktail (e.g. a Mohito) and drink it in the art deco bar and you"ll be transported back to the high days of Bohemia.
A gem.... Go for the guided tour - it's well worth it. Fantastic 'Arts & Crafts' architecture and decoration and you'll learn a lot from the good guides.

don't miss this spectacular building. the building tour is wonderful and it was also entrancing to go here for a concert. Just seeing the beautiful Art Nouveau detail is well worth the visit and taking the tour is well worth it.

Interesting way to spend an hour. You can pay for a tour - 280 Crowns so it's not cheap, but the guide is very good and speaks good English. Comprises about 8 rooms that you woudn't otherwise see. Tour Groups are limited to about 30 people and they won't let you join once that limit is hit... Worth booking a few hours early. Tours run 2 or 3 times a day, starting around 1ish.

Stunning!!. I never expected to find such a beautifully maintained example of art nouveau architecture. The Kaverna cafe is brilliant, complete with three piece jazz combo. It transports one to another era. A must to experience. The cakes, coffee and pure apple juice were delicious.We did not get into the concert halls but will try the next time.

One of the most significant Art Nouveau buildings in the world. The Municipal House is located in the very centre of Prague, directly neighbouring the Powder Gate. The most significant Czech painters and sculptors of the time participated in the decoration of the Municipal House.Don't miss the excellent French restaurant led by Chef Jacques Auffrays.There is free WiFi in the café.

Art Nouveau at it's best. There is a guided tour around the Municipal House and this is the only way you can get to see the rooms on show...apart from buying concert tickets but even then you only get to see the Smetana Hall.The cost of the tour is approx £10 per person and although I was disappointed with the value for money I was so glad to have seen these magnificent rooms that have been perfectly restored to their original splendor. Don't be conned into paying extra for an official pass to take photos as you go round. There is opportunity to photograph what you want as the guide moves on ahead to each room leaving the group to follow. I thought the guide rushed the group on too quickly without time to soak up the beauty of each room. The tour was supposed to be 70mins but was more like 55-60mins by the time the guide had sorted out information sheets in various languages and the photo passes at the start of the tour. Don't be hurried on...if you want to take longer to look around do so. You will not be disappointed, especially in the room decorated by Mucha. The lighting, furnishings and hand painted wallpapers as well as the ceramic tiles in the basement will leave you inspired at the talent and skill from the period

Beautifull art nouveau object with an impressive grand cafe. Visiting Prague you cann't miss the Municipal House which is indeed is a landmark.Don''t forget (after taking pictures and amiring) to get in the very beautifull grand cafe which is downstairs in the Hall.After the lots of walking you do in Prague , you might be interested in the enormousnumber of different cakes, pies and pastry they are offering.

An Art Nouveau treat. My wife and I took a guided tour of the Municipal Hall after having a visit to the Mucha Museum. We specifically wanted to see the Mayor’s Room with the murals by Mucha which, in my view, were worth the price of the tour ticket alone. The tour takes about an hour and finishes in the American Bar where your tour ticket allows you a free drink. If you want to take photos then you must buy a photo permit when booking your tour. This policy is rigorously policed by the tour guide who stopped several people in our tour group from taking photos because they did not have a photo permit. To be fair, she did explain very clearly before the tour started what the rules were but I guess some people were hoping it wouldn’t be enforced. Bad move.The architecture and interior design is simply wonderful especially for anyone interested in the Art Nouveau scene and is well worth a visit.The number of tours each day is limited to three on a weekend and two on a weekday so you would do best to check in advance when the tours are running to avoid disappointment. The tour is conducted in English and Czech and is very informative. Printed information sheets are available in other languages.
Beautiful. We visited inside here as we were passing and not when there is a concert on. The part we went around was well worth looking at and lovely architechture
Art Nouveau. Visit this cafe/restaurant concert hall to enjoy the art nouveau architecture and visit a classical concert if you like.

Exquisite Art Nouveau Building to visit and have a meal. We stumbled across this concert hall building almost by accident. It is a beautiful art nouveau building with an exquisite interior. Although it is quite expensive to go around the building and concert hall, it is well worth the money.The amount of restoration and detail is amazing. However, you can also just decideto go into the cafeteria, american bar or restaurant. We went to the cafeteria which is wonderful, it has huge wall mirrors, chandeliers and a pianist playing. The first time we had tea and cakes but so enjoyed it that we went again and had a meal , the prices well also surprisingly very reasonable. We also had a drink in the American Bar which takes you back to the high life of the 1930's with a huge mirrored bar and decorated walls. Unfortunately, the restaurant was out of our price league - but if I ever went back I would prioritise a visit and them meal at this wonderful place.This was one of our favourite places to visit in Prague

An Art Nouveau Beauty!. My husband and I bought tickets to a chamber orchestra performance in Smetana Hall while in Prague and felt so privileged to have seen this beautiful place. The glass ceiling of the concert hall was breathtaking, as were the large doorways to the hall, the restaurant, and the facade of the building. After spending so much time admiring Gothic, Baroque and other aged architectural forms, this Art Nouveau beauty impresses in a whole different way.

fabulous art nouveau, but too expensive:(. POSITIVE
whole interior is preserved art nouveau
NEGATIVE
have to buy concert ticket or (expensive) tour to see everything

Should be the #1 spot if you like Art Nouveau!!!. We visited Prague a little over a year ago for four days. We are art nouveau fanatics and came to Prague to enjoy the architecture, Mucha exhibits and everything art nouveau we could. This place simply is the best. The exterior and entrance are amazing. Inside you have the cafe/bar and beer hall in the basement both in nouveau. Plus the two fancier restaurant's on the main level. Great book store/gift shop. You must take the tour to see all the different rooms, plus the amazing Mucha designed room that made my wife cry. It is incredible. We took in a classical concert one evening just to enjoy the hall it was in.Prague has a lot of great art nouveau. This still surpases the Mucha Museum, St. Vitus Cathedral, and the many buildings you'll see.Take in a lunch at the beer hall in the lower level if possible. Also great cucumber martini's in the American Bar in the basement.

What a gem!. Where else can you have a leisurely coffee or a decently-priced meal in such lavish surroundings? We loved this place. The food is good and not over-priced. Service is excellent and very attentive without being annoying - definitely not like the arrogant waiters you get in other cities. The Czech restaurant in the basement serves excellent food if you want a more substantial meal with a wider menu. The roast pork would feed my family for a week! Both cafe and restaurant often have live music while you eat, and you can linger as long as you like and enjoy the ambiance.

Nice looking building. It is a very nice looking building both in and outside while here I had dinner at one of the restaurants inside it was a very beautiful room long and elegant. I wasn't impressed with he food, like i said the building was nice i've seen better. It's in a pretty central location so stop by have a look around. Maybe i would have been more impressed if my group ahead actually seen a performance here.

Must-see Art Nouveau Masterpiece. As soon as you arrive in Prague, sign up for the free tour in English of the magnificent private rooms of the Municipal House. I've done it twice and could happily repeat it twice more. Architecture, interior design, custom textiles, etc. are all integrated in the most exquisite example of Art Nouveau to be found anywhere. Each room is unique and each is perfect in it's own particular way. It's a gem and a well kept secret that very few Americans have even heard of. If time is an issue, it would be better spent here than fighting the crowds on the Charles Bridge.Try to come here at night, as well, when the restaurants are lit up. The French one, in particular, is pure eye candy. The main concert hall (Smetana Hall) has perfect acoustics and is a favorite venue for top classical artists and orchestras.

Concert was a tourist trap. Purchased tickets for a Gershwin Concert based on the program presented at the ticket office at Concert Hall. However, the concert was actually a jazz concert with only one Gershwin song played, and not any of the songs listed on the program. When we contacted them for a refund, they denied it asking us why the other people in the concert didn't get up and leave, as we did. They contacted a member of the ensemble who denied our account, saying they had played the program. They refused to refund our money and finally offered us another concert the next night, which was not the type of music we had originally been interested in.We felt completely taken advantage of as tourists and it marred our visit to the city. We were not able to recover our money and our hotel was of little help. We strongly advise against purchasing any concert tickets at this venue.

Worth a drive by, maybe not a tour. I had heard this was one of the must sees in the area, and was a little disappointed when I got there. It's beautiful on the outside, however you have to pay to see a town hall. This was what I found in various places in Prague. You have to pay to see. I did go inside for a dessert which was ok, and the architecture was beautiful in the restaurant as well. I waited around to hear others talk about their tours as they walked out while trying to make up my mind. None were particularly happy about their tour, and several complained about the waste of money. I opted not to take the tour.

Art Nouveau Masterpiece. Anyone who's a fan of turn-of-the-century Beaux Arts architecture, design, and decor cannot miss this monument to Czech Art Nouveau. The tour is very much worth it. The highlight is the room covered with works by the great graphics artist Mucha, followed by the mammoth Smetana concert hall with its beautiful dome and sculptures. I couldn't stop taking pictures. Exquisite details everywhere.

Great art nouveau building. This is a wonderful place to see and visit--it is classic art nouveau inside and out and has a number of beautiful restaurants and cafes. Also in the area are other examples of Czech buildings from different periods.

a must for visitors to Prague!. When I first was in Prague 30 years ago, the Municipal House was a neglected relic of an architectural style that had fallen into disrepute. The rediscovery of the glories of art nouveau have turned this magnificent building into a must-see for tourists. Definitely take the tour of the building, and eat in at least one of its three restaurants. The most expensive one, called a "French Restaurant", was featured in the recent movie, "I Served the King of England." The Cafe next to it is also a bit pricey but the atmosphere is worth the cost. The "Pilsner Beer Celler" in the basement is a favorite of tourists, and the food is actually quite good. Try the duck--it is a local specialty.

Go for the tour!. Luckily a friend had told us to take the tour of Obecni Dum, don;t know that I would have done it without the prodding and it was one of the highlights of the trip. The restoration is impeccable and it truly is an art nouveau showpiece, not to be missed.One tourist rip off there, they charge extra if you want to take photos on the tour. I didn't pay and now I'm regretting not having photos from the tour.

Stunning art noveau building. I am by no means an architecture expert, but even I can appreciate the unique art noveau style of the Municipal House in Prague. It is a very unique and pretty building that is a wonderful contrast with the gothic and baroque architecture in old town. We did not have time to take a tour (which allows you to see the magnificent theater), but simply walked in the building, looked around the restaurant, cafe and bar and walked around inside a bit. The style seems to be a mix of all sorts of components - green grating, chandeliers that look like a mix of crystal and watch parts, square designs, rounded arches, frescoes, and so on - yet it is all tastefully put together. Overall, a really charming building that's worth a few minutes of your time while walking around new town!

Obecni Dum - art nouveau bar. The Obecni Dum is absolutely beautiful and the tour, although brief allows you to see some of the gorgeous rooms. We had a drink in the American bar in the basement, which I thoroughly recommend - it is a gem of art nouveau and the drinks are reasonably priced. It is terribly under-used - people seem to pop in, look and then leave. It would be lovely to see it full, as it would have been in its heyday.

Omni Town House. Had a superb meal, staff did seem efficient but not over friendly, the cleanliness is brilliant, the atmosphere is grand, we did tip the waitress about 150 corunas.Next day went back for another meal and the service was fantastic, every body was polite and friendly, music from saxophonist & pianist. Yes 4 English guys who wanted to see Prague without the seedy side, I think the Czech people may be a little wary of the Brits, be polite & they do warm to you.The art nouveau decor is a true delight.
